Subject: SUTD Cuesports Intro Workshop and Recruitment
Body:
YOUR CUE TO REST

 

SUTD Cuesports Freshmore Introductory Workshop!
Come and try out a game of pool at root cove, where we take a chill pill from hectic studies. Learn from friendly old-timers who are always around to guide. Whether you are looking for to pick up a new skill or hone an existing one. Everyone is welcomed.

An effective remedial lesson for vectors physics, elastic collision, and conservation of rotational momentum. A.K.A an introductory game of pool. 
Participants will learn breaking and straight shots. Additional guidance can be given if participants are interested in bank, kick, draw, and follow shots with an importance on applied side-spins and angles.

SUTDents must attend the workshop to be able to join the Cuesports Fifthrow.

Session details
Week 1 (13, 15, 17th Sep) & Week 2 (20, 22, 24th Sep)
Mon-Wed-Fri: Session one 6pm – 8pm, Session two 8pm-10pm @ Root Cove
Note: 15th Sep (Wed) will only have one session from 6pm - 8pm to account for your mandatory hostel session afterwards.]

Sign up Details:

Find @SUTD_Cuesports_Bot on telegram and key in your details to book a slot! Feel free to sign up with your friends!

Do note there is a cap of 4 per session. And sign ups must be done at least a day in advance to be considered.

 







 

 

SUTD Cuesports Recruitment Drive!

SUTD Cuesports is once again looking for new members! 

 

SUTD Cuesports is a Sports Cluster Official Fifth Row that aims to provide all SUTDents a haven to play pool both as a form of recreation and to pursue excellence in the sport. Pool Billiards is a table sport that is both an art and a science. It engages players holistically- allowing players to be creative in defensive and offensive shots, enhancing their critical thinking skills, applying different Principles of Classical Physics as well as toning their arm, leg, back and hip muscles in a fun and exciting game of pool. 

 

For Recreational players:

1.	Provides Respite from the rigor of the Uni Life
2.	A social skill that can be used in interacting with colleagues and friends
3.	Train your decision making skills and hone your focus.

 

For Competitive players:

1.	Twice a Term Ranked Competitions
2.	Easy way to training with similar high level players 
3.	Coach with our team Captain (National player)

 





 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

No matter why you join, you will find likeminded individuals to help encourage and support you in your goals! Feel free to come down and try out one of our into sessions!

 

Stay safe and all the best in the new term!

 

 

Kindest Regards

Joshua Tan

 <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fsutdcuesports.wordpress.com%2F&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C54db3b31e6644f88699308d971c39c52%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637665907670836894%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=h%2FJHFbS3%2BcVihtQaqRkqbGRRGzubOkqYODoKcOPop%2Bw%3D&reserved=0>

Subject: TikTok 2022 Singapore Campus Recruitment
Body:
Dear Students, 

 

________________________________



 

Thinking about where to kickstart your career? Look no further as Singapore TikTok Campus Recruitment 2022 is now LIVE with exciting positions from both tech and business fields.

 

TikTok prides ourselves to be a company that champions diversity and fosters a culture of inclusion among our global teams. Our employees are empowered to own their ideas, build fast, explore outside their comfort zone and support one another in the process. 

This is what life at TikTok is all about!

 

Keen to learn more about our open positions?

Learn more about it here at 2022 Graduate Opportunities <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fbytedance.feishu.cn%2Fdocs%2FdoccnuSk5jTtrar8cusNe4XfUPg&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C94f26cc5c1e74ac5616c08d971ae027a%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637665814529660293%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=qq3JGD3kLG76X7jo7ik5zVdbPoQ9vFUZuL1FN%2BIcZhk%3D&reserved=0>  or 2022 Internship Opportunities <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fbytedance.feishu.cn%2Fdocs%2FdoccnhFYuO21dvlpC3ZVg4pTZ50&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C94f26cc5c1e74ac5616c08d971ae027a%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637665814529670286%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=bTYgbchdcnSbV5h%2FLKLBnYyWO%2Byosjqy6PWFvoZeeAA%3D&reserved=0> .

 

We look forward to your applications!

 



 

 

Regards,

Career Development Centre

Subject: PSC Scholarships (Mid-Term) and Master's Scholarships
Body:
Message Classification: Restricted

 

<Sent on behalf of PSC Secretariat>

 

Dear Student,

 

Hello from the Public Service Commission (‘PSC’) Secretariat! 

 

The PSC has been awarding scholarships since 1961. Over the years, we have identified and groomed many talented young men and women with the passion and commitment to serve Singapore and Singaporeans.

 

We offer various scholarship schemes such as the PSC Scholarships (Mid-Term) and PSC Master’s Scholarships for undergraduates and recent graduates with no more than 3 years of working experience in the private/non-governmental sector. More information can be found in the enclosed PSC Scholarships Brochure.  

 

If you are a Singapore Citizen with outstanding leadership qualities, have strong commitment to serve the Singapore community and an interest to explore a Public Service career, we welcome you to attend the PSC Virtual Information Session to find out more about the opportunities available for holders of PSC Scholarship (Mid-Term) and PSC Master’s Scholarships. Besides, you will also have the chance to hear from senior officers from the various public agencies to gain insight into the various career pathways available in the Public Service.  

 

The PSC Scholarships Virtual Information Session will be held on 11 September 2021 from 10.00am to 5.30pm via Zoom. Do register for the session via the link here <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fgo.gov.sg%2Fmeis2021&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7Cc7422fbd306e4ad0b3e908d971ab70b5%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637665803486045422%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=0Bnn1YwtuXebNiDoCMyq%2FqYX%2FywGe63P4JF7BmbL4gk%3D&reserved=0>  or scan the QR code below! Registrations will close on 09 September 2021.

 

You can find more details of the programme below too.

 



For queries related to the PSC Scholarship (Mid-Term) and PSC Master’s Scholarship, you may write to psc@psd.gov.sg <mailto:psc@psd.gov.sg> . For technical difficulties related to the registration for the 2021 PSC Scholarships Virtual Information Session, you may write to Brenda_SEE@psd.gov.sg <mailto:Brenda_SEE@psd.gov.sg> , Ryan_TAN@psd.gov.sg <mailto:Ryan_TAN@psd.gov.sg>  or Nafisah_VIKNESH@psd.gov.sg <mailto:Nafisah_VIKNESH@psd.gov.sg> . 

 

Thank you.

 

Regards,

	
Office of Student Administration

 

 <https://www.sutd.edu.sg/>

Subject: Greenprint's Guide on How to be Sustainable
Body:
Hi SUTD Family!!

We hope summer has been good for everyone! Greenprint has come up with a lazy person's guide on how to be sustainable. You can find it here <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fdocs.google.com%2Fdocument%2Fd%2F11NaBeMKSKWkGIrfoI1gOCJn9OPf_z33MdS0Z5CIkj9M%2Fedit%3Fusp%3Dsharing&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C3cb6c041ff1e49c76bdc08d971a5c964%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637665779473059505%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=m6E6foJVbs%2BwIQfyxLnzI4Hg38Nmn4ckOeyq8ti8tKc%3D&reserved=0> ! Please do check it out if you'd like to find out how to be sustainable by taking small and simple steps in your daily life!

This guide is also meant to be an open guide, so please let us know if you'd like to propose any suggestions or edits! 


Best regards, 







For more updates: 

Instagram @sutdgreenprint 

Facebook @https://www.facebook.com/sutdgreenprint <https://www.facebook.com/sutdgreenprint>

Subject: Riot Games Campus League
Body:
Helo again,


SUTD Esports is looking for players to participate in the upcoming Riot Games Campus League (yes thrs another one) 
Grab your friends and form a team or look for other members on the Esports Discord https://discord.gg/GDhntdUmzm <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fdiscord.gg%2FGDhntdUmzm&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C71e45ce98a5e48254ef108d9713e7234%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637665335634074231%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=LvDVKMcj95pxBBQJ7PbLSvnONRGkgFuQn3EO%2FL6nwbQ%3D&reserved=0> 
You can still sign up even if you don't have a full team, we will try to match you with the others who have signed up without a team as well! (no promises tho)

Incoming freshies are also welcome to join
Sign up through the link below
https://forms.office.com/r/RYTwyLi6Fd <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.office.com%2Fr%2FRYTwyLi6Fd&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C71e45ce98a5e48254ef108d9713e7234%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637665335634084219%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=IoryUYuVIGS2VgJ6YaGSYOxpHJtTQMXl5j%2BlR9QLidE%3D&reserved=0> 
Signups close 17 Sep 2021 5pm

Here be the loot

Valorant
Qualifiers
First place: 9875 In game Credits (1975 per team member)
Second place: 4875 In game Credits (975 per team member)
Third place: 2500 In game Credits (500 per team member)


Playoffs
First: $600 Cash
Second: $300 Cash
Third: $100 Cash

Wild Rift 
Qualifiers
First: 9875 In game Credits (1975 per team member)
Second: 4875 In game Credits (975 per team member)
Third: 2500 In game Credits (500 per team member)


Playoffs
First: $650 Cash + Secretlab X LoL Chairs x5
Second: $450 Cash
Third: $150 Cash

Do note that the prizes will be distributed directly from the organizers ya











Yeetus Maxima,

Jared Lim
Vice President

SUTD ESports Club Executive Committee

Subject: SUTD's Social Media Report (23 Aug - 5 Sep)
Body:
Dear SUTD community

 

This is the latest edition of the SUTD Social Media Report, covering the social media posts created on our various accounts for the period 23 August to 5 September.

 

If you have any interesting activities that will showcase SUTD’s mission, brand, talents and achievements, do reach out to Terence Chia at terence_chia@sutd.edu.sg <mailto:terence_chia@sutd.edu.sg>  

 

Please share any posts that interest you on your accounts and help us create a greater awareness of our stories.

 

Best regards

Zerlina

Office of Marketing & Communications

Subject: New Book by ASD Faculty - Divine Custody: A History of Singapore's Oldest Teochew Temple
Body:
Dear SUTD community

 



 

The Architecture and Sustainable Design Pillar is excited to share that our faculty member, Associate Professor Yeo Kang Shua, has recently published a new book entitled “Divine Custody: A History of Singapore's Oldest Teochew Temple”.

 

The book explores the history of the earliest Teochew temple in Singapore which has intrigued Kang Shua since his involvement in the temple’s restoration efforts back in 2010. Kang Shua’s efforts has led to him receiving the prestigious UNESCO Asia-Pacific Awards for Cultural Heritage Conservation.

 

The book is now available at major online bookstores. Please refer to the eDM for more information.

 

Thank you

 

Sincerely

 



 

https://asd.sutd.edu.sg/

Subject: Global Exchange Programme (GEXP) 2022 - coming to you soon!
Body:
Dear Term 3 Students,

 

Interested to spend a term at an overseas host university? We have 32 partner universities in 16 exciting destinations for you to choose from! 

 

 

About Global Exchange Programme (GEXP) 

 

To better the world, first see and experience the world!

 

GEXP provides SUTD undergraduates a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to experience an international education and cultural immersion. Offered students will be able to spend a term at one of our partner university worldwide after Term 5 (Fall Term) or Term 6 (Spring Term).

 

To live and study in another country is an exciting opportunity that promises a fulfilling and rewarding experience!

 

Online application is open to all Term 3 students in October and students will be informed via email. Stay tuned and look out for more email updates send by Office of International Relations in the coming weeks!

 

List of partner universities

 



 

 

Meanwhile, look us up below:

 

										
		 <mailto:global@sutd.edu.sg> 	
		 <https://wearesutd.sutd.edu.sg/category/exchange/global-exchange-programme/>

	 <https://www.sutd.edu.sg/Global/Student-Exchange/Outbound> 			 <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x9Frk84kcFg&list=PLUWNY6Eg0rRI14AzewwRYMPZbI3ORaZyR>

Subject: Healthcare UROP recruitment
Body:
Dear SUTDents,  

 

We are looking to recruit 1-2 undergraduate students for a healthcare UROP project starting immediately.  

 

In this project, students will work with an SUTD graduate student and Speech Therapists from Sengkang Hospital to develop a specialized thickening bottle for patients with Dysphagia (difficulty with swallowing). Such patients are required to prepare and consume thickened fluids for their regular fluid consumption. Our aim is to create a portable thickening bottle to facilitate quick and effective thickened fluid preparation while on-the-go.  

 

We are looking for students that: 

*	are in Term 6 or later (preferred) 
*	have experience with 3D CAD, physical prototyping, and electronics 
*	can commit 6-12 hours/week over two academic terms (Sept 2021 – Apr 2022) 
	


 


If you wish to participate in this UROP or if you have any queries, please contact Dr. Xiaojuan Khoo at xiaojuan_khoo@sutd.edu.sg <mailto:xiaojuan_khoo@sutd.edu.sg>  or Jeremy Cheong at jeremy_cheong@mymail.sutd.edu.sg 

Thank you and regards, 

Jeremy

From: SUTD-ZJU IDEA 
Sent: Friday, September 3, 2021 2:35 PM
Subject: [Join Us] The 3rd International Conference on Technology and Design (ICTD) 2021 is happening tomorrow on 4 September!

 

Dear SUTD Community,

 

You are cordially invited to the upcoming 3rd International Conference on Technology and Design (ICTD) 2021. ICTD 2021 is hosted by Zhejiang University (ZJU) and co-hosted by SUTD this year.

 

Titled “Technology and Design: The Way We Shape the Future”, ICTD 2021 will be presented over the four Saturdays of September 2021.  The Conference will start on 4 September, at 9.30am, with opening address by ZJU Vice President, Prof He Lianzhen and SUTD Provost, Prof Phoon Kok Kwang. Please refer to the conference website https://design.zju.edu.cn/ictd <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fdesign.zju.edu.cn%2Fictd&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C8b2cbc8cfb1d4ef7a63808d96eebab15%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637662781068965015%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=MB8prtSeM5EHKxXzamIT8giYCBQCfLgnIBz4XXDz0gA%3D&reserved=0>  for the full programme. The conference registration is NOT required. You may watch the live broadcast @ YouTube https://youtu.be/P3RFEJ1JsPA <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fyoutu.be%2FP3RFEJ1JsPA&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C8b2cbc8cfb1d4ef7a63808d96eebab15%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637662781068975008%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=EHqb8jVQNNlH%2BCkG%2F4aTVy8%2B%2BppDy2OeggRxXo%2FcXyY%3D&reserved=0>  and bilibili  https://live.bilibili.com/22340110 <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Flive.bilibili.com%2F22340110&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C8b2cbc8cfb1d4ef7a63808d96eebab15%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637662781068975008%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=yWyhb1sNNeHLHbFvH3PtHHFjYTYUM5I88dd5DGQ8BOM%3D&reserved=0> .

 

As the co-host, SUTD speakers will share insightful thoughts and experiences in various areas. Prof Tai Lee Siang will explain the importance of design in circularity and sustainability, while Assoc. Prof Arlindo Silva share how the Masters of Innovation by Design Programme plays a role in talent development, and Asst. Prof Mohan Rajesh Elara explain more about the design, development and deployment of reconfigurable maintenance robots. 

 

SUTD will also host a half-day session by Prof. Ricky Ang on Day 3, in the morning of 18 September, where Assoc. Provost Prof Ashraf Kassim, Asst. Prof. Carlos Bañón and Syam Kumar Prabhakaran will share on topics related to SUTD Design and AI Programme, Innovation in Sustainable Architecture, and SUTD Sustainability Vision, respectively. In addition, speakers from Surbana Jurong Group, Johnson Controls, and GreenA Consultants have also been invited to share their industry perspectives on sustainability.

 

Besides the speakers from ZJU and SUTD, many speakers from other universities have been invited to give talks at ICTD 2021.  The strong line-up includes Peter Childs from Imperial College London, Prof Xin Xiangyang from Tongji University, Prof Cees de Bont from Loughborough University, Prof Makoto Watanable from Chiba University, Prof Byung-keun Oh from Yonsei University, Prof Yao Lining from Carnegie Mellon University and many more. 

 

Join us for an exciting and insightful September!

Body:

From: Student - Chen Qinyi <qinyi_chen@mymail.sutd.edu.sg>
Sent: Friday, September 3, 2021 6:15:13 PM
To: *All Students <*AllStudents@sutd.edu.sg>; *All Staff Faculty and Researchers <allstafffacultyandresearchers@sutd.edu.sg>
Subject: Come join us at LCC 2021! 
 
Dear SUTD community, 



SUTD's annual Learning Celebration Carnival (LCC) event is right around the corner!

 

LCC is an event where our students can share their experiential learning journeys and showcase their innovations from various programmes, held over the year, with the SUTD family.

 

This year, LCC will follow a hybrid format - physical exhibition and virtually on YouTube, Gather Town and Website and is held on two separate days – 29 September, Wednesday and 01 October, Friday with a refreshed format.

 

What can you expect?

1.	Poster exhibition (Internships, UROP, Special Projects (5th Row) and Overseas Opportunity) held in the campus centre
2.	Keynote addresses, including from external speakers Tan Shao Yen (Group Chief Innovation Officer, CPG Corporation) and Yvonne Tan (Digital Motor Senior Engineering Manager, Dyson)
3.	12 livestreamed talks covering topics such as software engineering, product design, AI and more
4.	Online poster gallery consisting of various posters showcasing internships, UROPs, overseas opportunities, and special projects
5.	*NEW this year* Gather Town Exhibition - interact with our student presenters! 

 

You will also get a chance to vote for your favourite posters. The top posters will win attractive prizes. The voting procedure will be shared later. 🗳

 

So, join us in this year’s very special LCC!

 

To find out more, visit the LCC website: lcc.sutd.edu.sg <https://lcc.sutd.edu.sg/> 


Best, 
Chen Qinyi

 <https://root.sutd.edu.sg/> 

Media and Marketing Director

9th Student Government

Unwavering • Accountable • Collaborative

Subject: Summary of coverage: Highlights of SUTD
Body:
Hi All,

 

Here’s the news coverage: 

 

-          Asia Research News featured a book titled ‘3D Printing and Additive Manufacturing of Electronics: Principles and Applications’, which was written by contributors from SUTD and NTU. The article included a quote from EPD HOP, Prof Chua Chee Kai, who is also the lead author.

-          The Register reported that a bunch of security vulnerabilities, dubbed BrakTooth, was disclosed by the Automated Systems Security Research Group at SUTD. This group is led by ISTD Assistant Prof Sudipta Chattopadhyay.

-          The New Paper featured a recipient of the Smart Nation Scholarship sponsored by the Cyber Security Agency, Mr Sean Kan, who mentioned that he had worked on a coding-related research project under SUTD's Research Mentorship Programme while he was a member of the science society at Dunman High School.

-          Chemical & Engineering News wrote an article about crafting polymer composites in one step using patterned light to cure resin-nanoparticle mixtures. The article included an expert quote from EPD Associate Prof Low Hong Yee.

-          Straits Times reported that five companies were recognised for their work at the ninth World Intellectual Property Organisation-Intellectual Property Office of Singapore IP for Innovation Awards. One of the winners, Mycotech, has three patents related to the development of leather made from mushrooms and the research for these innovations were done in partnership with researchers from Future Cities Laboratory and SUTD.

-          CNA wrote an article on students who left their home as teens to study in Singapore and one of the featured students is ISTD's Presca Lim Ze Li.

________________________________

 

Asia Research News, 2 Sep 2021, Transforming the world with 3D printed electronics (https://www.asiaresearchnews.com/content/transforming-world-3d-printed-electronics <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.asiaresearchnews.com%2Fcontent%2Ftransforming-world-3d-printed-electronics&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C8e7decf3587f44be1e7808d96eb28079%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637662535353868451%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=LYHg5BWYagtmlc7%2FpoDhWBj%2F%2BpJtr2BY7JPcHY4%2BNzk%3D&reserved=0> )

 

In the age of digitalisation, electronics products are becoming increasingly ubiquitous. Over the past few decades, electronic products like computers, smartphones, televisions, gaming consoles and internet of things (IoT) devices have completely transformed the way we interact, live, work and play. In consumer products, the demands for customisation and miniaturisation are two major trends that place technical challenges in designing and manufacturing future electronic products.

 

Three-dimensional (3D) printing of electronics has attracted growing interest because of the unique advantages it offers that are not achievable by traditional electronic manufacturing processes and systems. For instance, on-demand fabrication of highly-customisable electronics, direct fabrication on a wide variety of substrates and conformal surfaces and novel device designs in three-dimensions.

 

Development and understanding of 3D printing of electronics require a combination of multiple disciplines, specifically material science of the functional inks, mechanical-electrical engineering for the digital manufacturing processes and computational engineering for the design of 3D printable electronic devices.

 

Written by contributors ranging from world leading experts and researchers from the Singapore University of Technology and Design (SUTD) and Nanyang Technological University (NTU), 3D Printing and Additive Manufacturing of Electronics: Principles and Applications is designed to be a one-stop guide for anyone interested in the 3D printing of electronics.

 

This book is also an effective textbook for undergraduate and graduate courses that aim to arm students with a thorough understanding of the fundamentals of 3D printed electronics.

 

Written to provide a comprehensive coverage on the principles and applications in 3D electronics printing for students, researchers and engineers, the book explores the various 3D printing techniques, functional materials, substrates, sintering processes, designs and simulations, applications and future outlook of 3D printed electronics. A set of designed problems at the end of each chapter provide undergraduate and postgraduate students with practice on key concepts covered.

 

3D Printing and Additive Manufacturing of Electronics begins with the introduction of conventional electronics manufacturing and an overview of the 3D printing of electronics. A chapter is devoted to the printing processes of the various conventional electronics techniques for printed electronics.

 

Four subsequent chapters are dedicated to the key components of 3D printing of electronics, which are 3D electronics printing techniques, materials and inks, substrates and processing, and sintering techniques for metallic nanoparticle inks. The book next presents a new exciting area which is gaining traction recently, namely the designs and simulations for 3D printed electronics. The last chapter is entirely devoted to the applications of 3D printed electronics, and valuable insights are provided for existing challenges and the future outlook.

 

This book also gives a complete and comprehensive overview of the latest technologies, methodologies and practices, as well as research and development in this sector, for industry practitioners and suppliers.

 

"In this book, we explore a future of fully functional electronic devices which are completely 3D printed," said Professor Chee Kai Chua, lead author and Head of Engineering Product Development at the Singapore University of Technology and Design.

 

"We take readers through the state-of-the-art technologies in 3D printed electronics and delve into present as well as upcoming trends that have the potential to revolutionise this sector".

 

 

The Register, 1 Sep 2021, BrakTooth vulnerabilities put Bluetooth users at risk – and some devices are going unpatched (https://www.theregister.com/2021/09/01/braktooth_vulnerabilities_put_bluetooth_users/ <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.theregister.com%2F2021%2F09%2F01%2Fbraktooth_vulnerabilities_put_bluetooth_users%2F&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C8e7decf3587f44be1e7808d96eb28079%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637662535353878448%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=F48fPdblGk7nfmEOs%2Fqax%2BmVPzVkYleu2q8PR6SB3ng%3D&reserved=0> )

 

White-hat hackers have disclosed a bunch of security vulnerabilities, dubbed BrakTooth, affecting commercial Bluetooth devices - and are raising red flags about some vendors' unwillingness to patch the flaws.

 

"Today we released BrakTooth," said the ASSET (Automated Systems Security) Research Group at the Singapore University of Technology and Design, "a family of 16 new security vulnerabilities (20+ CVEs) in commercial Bluetooth Classic (BR/EDR) stacks that range from denial of service (DoS) via firmware crashes and deadlocks in commodity hardware to arbitrary code execution (ACE)."

 

The team added: "BrakTooth affects major system-on-chip (SoC) vendors such as Intel, Qualcomm, Texas Instruments, Infineon (Cypress), Silicon Labs, among others."

 

Representing an estimated 1,400 or more commercial products, including Microsoft's Surface Pro 7, Surface Laptop 3, Surface Book 3, and Surface Go 2 and the Volvo FH infotainment system, the BrakTooth vulnerabilities are claimed to expose "fundamental attack vectors in the closed BT [Bluetooth] stack." It's not the first time the same team has made such claims, either: ASSET was also responsible for disclosing the SweynTooth vulnerabilities in February last year.

 

While all 16 vulnerabilities have been reported to vendors, the responses received vary considerably. Espressif, whose popular ESP32 microcontroller family was affected, was one of the first to release a patch closing the holes, along with Bluetrum Technology and Infineon. Intel, Actions, and Zhuhai Jieli Technology have confirmed they are either investigating the flaws or actively developing patches.

 

Harman International and SiLabs, by contrast, "hardly communicated with the team," the researchers claimed, "and the status of their investigation is unclear at best."

 

Worse news came from Texas Instruments and Qualcomm, however: the former stated outright that it will not produce a patch for the flaws unless "demanded by customers," while the latter is patching only one of its affected parts - despite the unpatched chips still appearing in brand-new products around the world.

 

Exactly what the unpatched vulnerabilities will let an attacker do varies from device to device, but none of the possibilities are good.

 

The team has shown off arbitrary code execution on an ESP32 microcontroller, commonly found in Internet of Things (IoT) devices which are rarely if ever updated by their manufacturers, denial of service attacks against laptops and smartphones with the Intel AX200 and Qualcomm WCN3390 chips, and the ability to freeze or shut down headphones and other Bluetooth audio devices.

 

To assist vendors in fixing the flaws, the ASSET team has written a proof-of-concept attack tool - but to delay the inevitable has stated that it will be available only to those willing to supply "certain basic information (job role, organisation, and valid email)" proving the legitimacy of their interest.

 

"How should everyone handle the usage of Bluetooth devices, especially if the devices used are affected by BrakTooth? As a start," Yee Ching Tok, handler at the Internet Storm Center (ISC), wrote in an analysis of the disclosure, "one might want to be more aware of one's surroundings when using Bluetooth.

 

"Since BrakTooth is based on the Bluetooth Classic protocol, an adversary would have to be in the radio range of the target to execute the attacks. As such, secured facilities should have a lower risk as compared to public areas (assuming no insiders within secured facilities). Having said that, this could also be a difficult task if an adversary manages to conceal the equipment well, though that would affect the range of Bluetooth connectivity."

 

Full technical details are available on the BrakTooth website. Qualcomm and Texas Instruments were approached for comment on their decisions to leave devices unpatched, but had not responded in time for publication.

 

 

The New Paper, 1 Sep 2021, Smart Nation scholars seek to champion cyber security (https://3dprintingindustry.com/news/defend3d-introduces-new-patented-technology-to-combat-cybercrime-and-ip-theft-195475/ <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2F3dprintingindustry.com%2Fnews%2Fdefend3d-introduces-new-patented-technology-to-combat-cybercrime-and-ip-theft-195475%2F&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C8e7decf3587f44be1e7808d96eb28079%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637662535353888443%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=s3ZpnnTpxzRkvUTrI5Z6Vrtw5WDEpQc3SHz2YLUGEWs%3D&reserved=0> )

 

Although Mr Sean Kan eventually managed to retrieve his account, this "sobering experience" reminded him that anyone can be the victim of a cyber attack.

 

"I was fortunate that I did not lose money and learnt many valuable lessons, but others may not be so lucky," Mr Kan, 20, told The New Paper, adding that he has since used unique passwords and enabled 2FA for important accounts.

 

The Amazon account was compromised from a data leak on another website where he used the same e-mail and password combination.

 

It was this episode that also made Mr Kan, a recipient of the Smart Nation Scholarship sponsored by the Cyber Security Agency (CSA), more determined to pursue a career in cyber security.

 

The scholarship, which was awarded to 14 young people yesterday and jointly offered by CSA, the Government Technology Agency and Infocomm Media Development Authority, drives innovation in the public sector by grooming the youth to take on leadership roles in these three Smart Nation agencies.

 

Mr Kan will be studying data science and analytics at the National University of Singapore after national service.

 

Having developed an interest in technology from a young age, he was a member of the science society at Dunman High School and has worked on a coding-related research project under the Singapore University of Technology and Design's Research Mentorship Programme.

 

Mr Kan believes that information technology (IT) advancements can be a double-edged sword and need to be carefully controlled, and he hopes to play a part in ensuring cyber security for Singaporeans in the future.

 

Another recipient of the Smart Nation Scholarship is Mr Tang Boxuan, 22, a former Hwa Chong Institution student who gave up a career in the Republic of Singapore Navy to pursue his passion in IT.

 

While he previously joined it under the Dual-Track Combat Officer Scheme - which offers opportunities to alternate between combat and specialist roles including in cyber security - Mr Tang eventually decided that he wanted a career that focuses solely on technology and dropped out before commissioning as a naval officer.

 

He told TNP: "It was not a light decision, especially since I put in a lot of effort to join the navy's scheme. Many of my friends were quite surprised, as I am usually a very motivated person during our training, but they were happy for me."

 

Born to engineer parents, Mr Tang was interested in coding and computing even as a boy and attended several online courses to strengthen his coding skills throughout the years.

 

Before heading to Imperial College London in October to pursue a degree in computing, he has taken up two internships during his current gap year - one at a tech start-up and another at the Smart Nation and Digital Government Office.

 

He said: "Cyber security, unlike other aspects of technology which are focused on innovation, is more like a battleground, and I am excited to join the battle against attackers."

 

 

Chemical & Engineering News, 31 Aug 2021, Crafting polymer composites in one step with light (https://cen.acs.org/materials/polymers/Crafting-polymer-composites-one-step/99/web/2021/08 <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fcen.acs.org%2Fmaterials%2Fpolymers%2FCrafting-polymer-composites-one-step%2F99%2Fweb%2F2021%2F08&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C8e7decf3587f44be1e7808d96eb28079%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637662535353888443%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=Wwwi%2F5ysaIzr9zcHDyVmVE3lkuv1Cs9ygJGVCfzFYxs%3D&reserved=0> )

 

Polymer-nanoparticle composites are used in batteries, construction materials, nonstick coatings, and electronic and medical devices. But making them requires multiple steps or a lot of heat and chemicals. Plus, it’s hard to control where the nanoparticles end up in the material, which can hamper its functionality.

 

Now researchers can make such composites in one step, precisely placing nanoparticles, by using patterned light to cure resin-nanoparticle mixtures. “The key here is simplicity and rapidness,” said Ian D. Hosein, a materials science and engineer at Syracuse University who leads the work presented at the ACS Fall 2021 meeting. “We mix the formulation, cast it over a surface, cure it, and it’s done,” said Hosein, whose graduate student Shreyas Pathreeker presented the work in the Division of Polymeric Materials: Science and Engineering.

 

Since it can work with a wide range of mix-and-match materials and generate a variety of carefully controlled nanoparticle patterns, this low-cost technique could enable composites for a variety of applications. The team recently used the method to make superhydrophobic films. These consist of a dense, thin layer of titanium dioxide nanoparticles sitting atop a bumpy polymer surface (ACS Applied Polymer Materials 2021, DOI: 10.1021/acsapm.1c00744).

 

Composites are routinely made by curing light-sensitive monomers. But Hosein and his colleagues, he said, use masks—which are akin to photographic negatives—to spatially control where the resin polymerizes. The researchers also tune the intensity of light to speed or slow polymerization reactions. As the material’s density changes with polymerization, it gathers in some areas and also pushes the nanoparticles to control where they aggregate. “So we can pattern and direct where the nanoparticles are located while we’re synthesizing the material,” Hosein said.

 

To make the superhydrophobic material, they placed a mixture of titania nanoparticles and light-sensitive trimethylolpropane triacrylate monomer on a masking sheet riddled with a regular array of 40 μm wide holes and then illuminated it with UV light.

 

As the light polymerized the monomer through the holes, the material expanded and formed an array of bumps, and the nanoparticles were pushed to the surface. The combination of the micrometer-sized bumps and the nanoparticles makes water bead up and roll off the surface, which would be useful for nonstick and self-cleaning coatings.

 

Hosein said the researchers are using a similar technique to make stable, high-energy lithium-ion battery anode materials composed of silicon-carbon composite pillars with silicon nanoparticles. The team is also exploring light-harvesting coatings for solar cells that consist of metal nanoparticles periodically arranged in a polymer matrix.

 

Hong Yee Low, a materials scientist at the Singapore University of Technology and Design, said one limitation of this technique’s practical application could be the time and energy required for the UV curing. But the technique’s room-temperature process and minimal use of solvents, she said, make it stand out.

 

 

Straits Times, 31 Aug 2021, When ideas take flight (https://www.straitstimes.com/tech/tech-news/when-ideas-take-flight <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.straitstimes.com%2Ftech%2Ftech-news%2Fwhen-ideas-take-flight&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C8e7decf3587f44be1e7808d96eb28079%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637662535353898434%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=RNf6nEHwHDFCLpjo2dgUz%2FLo6DtsIrXvQmeNZZc%2F75w%3D&reserved=0> )

 

In spite of the Covid-19 pandemic, companies have been tapping their intellectual property (IP) to grow, with many using Singapore as a base to manage their intangible assets.

 

Last Tuesday, five companies were recognised for their work at the ninth World Intellectual Property Organisation-Intellectual Property Office of Singapore IP for Innovation Awards.

 

They ranged from a company that turns mushrooms into leather for fashion products, to an online marketplace resembling a video-streaming site for companies to buy and sell rights to their shows.

 

The awards consider factors such as the strength of an organisation's intangible asset and IP portfolio, its business strategy to leverage that portfolio including commercialisation efforts, and the impact on stakeholders, industry and society.

 

Here is a look at the innovations from the winning companies.

 

Using pregnant mother's blood to test if baby has genetic conditions

• IPOS IP for Innovation Champions winner

• WIPO IP Enterprise Trophy

 

Singapore molecular diagnostics firm Inex Innovate, which won two awards, holds 48 patents and 12 trademarks for women's and foetal health diagnostics.

 

These innovations help the company detect genetic conditions in foetuses, as well as ovarian and breast cancers, said the firm's chief executive Kane Black.

 

For instance, Inex has patents related to isolating foetal cells from a pregnant mother's blood for non-invasive prenatal diagnostic tests. These can potentially identify up to 7,000 different conditions that arise in the womb.

 

Inex, which has close to 50 employees, has also developed a liquid biopsy test using micro ribonucleic acid biomarkers for the early detection of ovarian cancer.

 

Unlike other liquid biopsies, which can only predict the likelihood of cancer, the Inex test can confirm the presence of genetic materials that will determine if there are cancerous cells.

 

The ovarian cancer test, which is currently undergoing phase 2 patient study, has so far been able to accurately diagnose over 90 per cent of Asian patients.

 

The intellectual properties (IPs) owned by Inex were developed in Singapore, including innovations co-developed with the National University of Singapore and the Agency for Science, Technology and Research (A*Star).

 

The company's four founders are Singaporeans from A*Star, National University Hospital, National University Health System and England's Southend University Hospital NHS Foundation Trust.

 

The women's and foetal health diagnostic tests are offered in hospitals and clinics here, as well as in the region, including in Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, Cambodia, Myanmar, Bangladesh and India. The patient samples collected here and overseas are tested in Singapore.

 

Sustainable leather made from mushrooms

• IPOS IP for Innovation Champions winner

 

An Indonesia-based firm with a Singapore office established in 2018, Mycotech has three patents related to the development of leather made from mushrooms - specifically the mycelium or "root structure" of the fungi.

 

The mushroom mycelium is grown on agricultural waste and besides being harvested to make leather, it can be used to create building materials such as for furniture.

 

The research for these innovations was done here, in partnership with researchers such as those from the Future Cities Laboratory and the Singapore University of Technology and Design. The patents are owned by the Singapore office.

 

The mycelium leather, Mylea, has been used by fashion brands.

 

One of them, Japanese street-wear label Doublet, worked with Mycotech to launch a collection, including jackets and boots, made using Mylea instead of animal leather. Singapore brand Gege Fashion used Mylea for some of its handbags.

 

Mycotech is piloting the use of its mushroom material with a United States luxury furniture brand whose Asia-Pacific headquarters is located here.

 

Compared with animal leather, Mycotech said mycelium leather technology is environmentally friendlier and more sustainable.

 

The technology has the potential to cut 68 per cent of the global carbon footprint, 70 per cent of the water used, and 90 per cent of the toxic waste produced in making leather from animal hides, it said.

 

Mycotech chief executive Adi Reza Nugroho said the firm will be focusing on the Asian market first, and collaborating with "tens of major global brands" to bring its mushroom materials to market.

 

Marketplace to buy and sell films, TV shows

• IPOS IP for Innovation Champions winner

 

Even before the Covid-19 pandemic, Mr Ian McKee, chief executive of local start-up Vuulr (pronounced "viewler"), and his business partners saw a gap in the market for matching sellers and buyers of films and TV shows.

 

Agents acting as middlemen prefer to fly to larger markets to pitch the rights to shows in face-to-face meetings with broadcasters and streaming sites. Since the process takes time and is costly, smaller markets are often bypassed and underserved.

 

Small show makers have other difficulties.

 

"If you were a talented creator of content, say, in Singapore, it was very hard to get your content distributed," said Mr McKee. "You didn't fit the mould of the old boys' club that Hollywood likes to see," he added, referring to the exclusive social and business network dominated by men in Hollywood.

 

Mr McKee has worked here for years and finds it an easy place to do business. He said Singapore has a good talent pool and infrastructure, and an accessible legal system that protects intellectual property (IP).

 

In 2019, Vuulr launched its online marketplace in Asia, followed by a global launch in January last year. The IP enabling this is owned by the Singapore start-up. Then the pandemic hit. "Everyone moved to doing business digitally and luckily, we were exactly the right proposition at the right time," Mr McKee said.

 

Registered users can browse over 170,000 hours of movies and shows in more than 90 languages on Vuulr. Buyers can put in an offer for broadcast rights through the platform directly to sellers and negotiate a deal. Some 1,800 licensing transactions have been done on Vuulr.

 

Gaining from shift in focus to product development

• IPOS IP for Innovation Champions winner

 

When the Covid-19 pandemic hit last year, Singapore firm Critical Facility Group could not send engineers to service its overseas customers' lightning protection systems.

 

The firm figured out how to do so remotely and with its engineers freed up, it was able to turn its attention to product development and innovation.

 

Critical Facility was previously focused on designing, making and selling products. With the shift in focus, it now has over 10 projects in development and licenses its intellectual properties (IPs) to other firms.

 

The firm has over 20 registered IPs, including patents and trademarks, which it developed. Its main research and development team is located here.

 

With a licensing model where royalties are collected instead of product sale revenues, chairman Andrew Mui said the firm could "expand our business in a much faster and bigger way", without investing in more infrastructure to build products.

 

The firm's products protect a range of things, from telecommunications towers to oil and gas storage tanks.

 

A device for such tanks - the dynamic by-pass conductor - helped Critical Facility clinch an IP award last week, said Mr Mui. It cuts the risk of electrical arcing occurring during lightning storms, which can cause the tanks to explode. Since the device's launch late last year, the firm has received many queries from the Middle East and South-east Asia, he added.

 

Tech giant manages its 5G IP through Singapore

• WIPO Users' Trophy

 

Chinese tech giant Lenovo has research and development (R&D) teams in various parts of the world including China, Europe, Japan and the United States, with over 20,000 patent assets. But a significant portion of their R&D innovations is protected globally through Lenovo Singapore.

 

The office here, with more than 200 staff, is one of the company's global hubs for managing and commercialising intellectual property (IP) assets.

 

Lenovo has over 30 patent professionals across offices in Singapore, China, Germany, Japan and the US who manage its global IP assets and strategy. Among the patents managed here are those for devices and 5G-related innovations from a group in Lenovo that makes and sells consumer products. These include the Lenovo X1 Fold laptop-tablet hybrid and the Lenovo Yoga 5G laptop.

 

When the X1 Fold's single OLED screen is opened and used flat, it works like a tablet. But the screen can bend in the middle such that the device becomes a laptop, with the bottom half working as a virtual keyboard.

 

The Yoga 5G laptop has a proprietary 360-degree hinge that allows the notebook's screen to bend backwards so it functions like a tablet.

 

The two devices can connect to 5G networks with mobile download speeds that can be 10 times faster than with 4G.

 

The decision to have Singapore as a Lenovo global IP hub was an easy one, said Mr M. J Chai, the firm's senior IP counsel.

 

Among other things, the Republic's "accessibility to a diverse pool of talent has also made it easy for Lenovo in recruiting prospective employees for our Singapore operations and also for us in partnering with local IP firms for our IP registration work", said Mr Chai.

SINGAPORE: While in secondary school in Hanoi, Le Minh Giang used to have little respite on school days. Once school ended at 4pm, he had to prepare for cram classes in the evening.

 

But these classes were not related to what he was learning in school; instead, they were tailored to prepare him for the opportunity to study in Singapore — through a shot at a scholarship.

 

Every year, the Ministry of Education awards a variety of bond-free scholarships to students from the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean), China and India, who join Secondary 1, Secondary 3 or Pre-university 1 classes in selected Singaporean schools.

 

The scholarships cover an annual allowance, hostel accommodation, return airfare and school fees. For students like Giang, extra preparatory classes are a small price to pay for a scholarship they covet.

 

The selection process is rigorous and competitive: Shortlisted applicants are required to take a series of English, mathematics and general logic tests. A small number are then invited to the final stage of selection, an interview.

 

Vedant Sandhu, 22, recalls that he was one of three recipients of the Singapore Airlines Youth scholarship for Indian students in the year he applied, out of thousands of applicants.

 

These international scholarship holders make up 0.9 per cent of Singapore’s secondary school and pre-university students, the ministry reported in 2019.

 

Though in some schools, their numbers are more sizeable. Giang, who received the Agency for Science, Technology and Research (A*Star) scholarship in 2015, says he had 31 fellow recipients in his batch in Anglo-Chinese School (Independent).

 

It may be little wonder that they are attracted to Singapore’s educational system. But the idea of studying here also holds different promises for different scholarship holders, who have an array of journeys and dreams. And not all expectations are realised eventually.

 

GOING THE EXTRA MILE FOR A SCHOLARSHIP

For 21-year-old Giang, the seeds of his “dream” of studying in Singapore were planted when his older brother, Le Minh Phuc, was awarded Singapore’s Asean scholarship in 2010.

 

“Before my brother went to Singapore, I didn’t even know it was possible to study abroad before university,” he recalls.

 

Phuc was placed in National Junior College. Through weekly video calls on Facebook Messenger, he relayed details of his overseas school trips and Malay dance co-curricular activity sessions.

 

To Giang, these represented an escape from the “long days of classes after classes” at his secondary school in Vietnam. He was motivated to follow in his brother’s footsteps.

 

“I felt that (S

We’re Getting Closer to Flying Humanoid Robots <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fspectrum.ieee.org%2Fflying-robot&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7Cfc38390a24fd4653d18308d96ea9e15d%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637662498388154820%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=tyDkkFPRC7qRjTOWuCwbnBgHt%2B8ucc0dLwR1vlwFIw8%3D&reserved=0> 

 

TECHNOLOGY

‘Charging Room’ System Powers Lights, Phones, Laptops Without Wires <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fnews.umich.edu%2Fcharging-room-system-powers-lights-phones-laptops-without-wires%2F&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7Cfc38390a24fd4653d18308d96ea9e15d%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637662498388164814%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=wlWnwCj%2BOZhAmJf93tYQxSwC%2F%2BjSohPlKBGfkkLB%2BPA%3D&reserved=0> 

 

TRUST CHAINS

Digital Currency and Trade Systems Are Tearing up the Rules We need a "digital Bretton Woods" to set standards <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fspectrum.ieee.org%2Fdigital-currency&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7Cfc38390a24fd4653d18308d96ea9e15d%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637662498388164814%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=lEqLyOYmzvZPSo9b69DjLKwDPpXjRuwVYzJlt7u2kaM%3D&reserved=0> 

 

VIRTURAL MEETINGS

Turning Cameras Off During Virtual Meetings Can Reduce Fatigue, Uarizona Research Finds <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.eurekalert.org%2Fnews-releases%2F926794&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7Cfc38390a24fd4653d18308d96ea9e15d%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637662498388174816%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=zrHtO5vtFlK0I%2FPK1RFR7J0Y0Vu0%2BgcsiQr1tWxvLkA%3D&reserved=0> 









“a novel humanoid robot that can fly using a ducted fan propulsion system was developed to explore its potential value for search and rescue in complex environments.”

“…researchers at the University of Michigan and University of Tokyo have developed a system to safely deliver electricity over the air, potentially turning entire buildings into wireless charging zones.”

“TThe next big thing in global commerce is "trust chain" digital platforms. Nations are now creating such platforms to allow businesses to execute transactions from anywhere on the planet securely and irrefutably. These platforms—which combine open alliance legal agreements, distributed ledger technology, and end-to-end encryption—can handle not only payments but also finance, trade, tax, and audits in a uniform manner.”

“"There's always this assumption that if you have your camera on during meetings, you are going to be more engaged," Gabriel said. "But there's also a lot of self-presentation pressure associated with being on camera. Having a professional background and looking ready, or keeping children out of the room are among some of the pressures.”

Source: IEEE <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fspectrum.ieee.org%2Fflying-robot&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7Cfc38390a24fd4653d18308d96ea9e15d%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637662498388174816%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=UI2w1v1k%2B4760FOR6srIJjudC%2BwaPNHyoXIIqWxCyns%3D&reserved=0>  (31 August 2021)

Source: University of Michigan <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fnews.umich.edu%2Fcharging-room-system-powers-lights-phones-laptops-without-wires%2F&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7Cfc38390a24fd4653d18308d96ea9e15d%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637662498388184802%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=HNZZak2QDAyVQNfkb86uyzvpb4uJDP8V92noYnwTJcU%3D&reserved=0> (30 August 2021)

Subject: [Join Us] The 3rd International Conference on Technology and Design (ICTD) 2021 is happening tomorrow on 4 September!
Body:
Dear SUTD Community,

 

You are cordially invited to the upcoming 3rd International Conference on Technology and Design (ICTD) 2021. ICTD 2021 is hosted by Zhejiang University (ZJU) and co-hosted by SUTD this year.

 

Titled “Technology and Design: The Way We Shape the Future”, ICTD 2021 will be presented over the four Saturdays of September 2021.  The Conference will start on 4 September, at 9.30am, with opening address by ZJU Vice President, Prof He Lianzhen and SUTD Provost, Prof Phoon Kok Kwang. Please refer to the conference website https://design.zju.edu.cn/ictd <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fdesign.zju.edu.cn%2Fictd&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C6c188bff75e848bc111308d96ea4e8c5%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637662477347661281%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=K91ZPf0%2B5T6UQOoDoetVlYY0ISjg6MwtyUCrKEayaEU%3D&reserved=0>  for the full programme. The conference registration is NOT required. You may watch the live broadcast @ YouTube https://youtu.be/P3RFEJ1JsPA <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fyoutu.be%2FP3RFEJ1JsPA&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C6c188bff75e848bc111308d96ea4e8c5%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637662477347671275%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=F15X%2B3WJvPFkNik6LDs6kxsv8ZFC02GJV%2Bf%2BYYCfxcQ%3D&reserved=0>  and bilibili  https://live.bilibili.com/22340110 <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Flive.bilibili.com%2F22340110&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C6c188bff75e848bc111308d96ea4e8c5%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637662477347671275%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=TOq1%2FSW9DlUCesES9lg9nPibgXysJ0mfeQcn7KOcrp4%3D&reserved=0> .

 

As the co-host, SUTD speakers will share insightful thoughts and experiences in various areas. Prof Tai Lee Siang will explain the importance of design in circularity and sustainability, while Assoc. Prof Arlindo Silva share how the Masters of Innovation by Design Programme plays a role in talent development, and Asst. Prof Mohan Rajesh Elara explain more about the design, development and deployment of reconfigurable maintenance robots. 

 

SUTD will also host a half-day session by Prof. Ricky Ang on Day 3, in the morning of 18 September, where Assoc. Provost Prof Ashraf Kassim, Asst. Prof. Carlos Bañón and Syam Kumar Prabhakaran will share on topics related to SUTD Design and AI Programme, Innovation in Sustainable Architecture, and SUTD Sustainability Vision, respectively. In addition, speakers from Surbana Jurong Group, Johnson Controls, and GreenA Consultants have also been invited to share their industry perspectives on sustainability.

 

Besides the speakers from ZJU and SUTD, many speakers from other universities have been invited to give talks at ICTD 2021.  The strong line-up includes Peter Childs from Imperial College London, Prof Xin Xiangyang from Tongji University, Prof Cees de Bont from Loughborough University, Prof Makoto Watanable from Chiba University, Prof Byung-keun Oh from Yonsei University, Prof Yao Lining from Carnegie Mellon University and many more. 

 

Join us for an exciting and insightful September!

Subject: Invitation to ISTD Pillar Info Sharing Session (1 October 2021)
Body:
Dear Freshmore Students, 

 

We would like to invite you to attend the upcoming ISTD Pillar Info Sharing Session on 1 October 2021 (Friday) 1.30pm – 2.30pm. 

 

We will conduct the info sharing session via the 2 different modes – physical (at Lecture Theatre 1) as well as virtual (via Zoom). To comply with the COVID-19 measure, we can only accommodate 40 students in LT1. Please choose only one of the sessions (physical or virtual). 

 

During this session, you will get to hear from ISTD HoP and other faculty members. Please register and indicate the mode of event you wish to attend here <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.gle%2FLSp9WKgG3rkAy2wa9&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7Cdee9f86156624c54458c08d96ea4ce7c%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637662476433130850%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=2VZcAT3cuVF2ygoSLmS9x3%2Ffvxl1enOpYUjAc%2ByTJb4%3D&reserved=0>  by 13 September 2021, Monday.

Subject: Addendum Letter Copy
Body:
Addendum - For donor supported award recipients

Introduction
SUTD is able to provide scholarships, exchange awards and financial aid awards to our students through the generosity of our donors. As part of the University’s initiative to continuously engage these donors, each beneficiary is required to submit an annual Thank You letter with a profile to introduce yourself for the full tenure of scholarship/award. Your personal note not only conveys your appreciation to the donor for the support of your studies but also provides them with a connection to their contribution. 
The guidelines and format of the profile will be advised at a later time.

Contribution to the University
Recipients are required to contribute service to the university. They may include taking on the role of student ambassador, representing SUTD to give publicity talks, hosting guests, sharing university experiences and any other similar role as and when called upon to do so.
Part of the service to the university can be logged activities organized by the Office of Advancement and Development. Examples of such service include:

• Student Ambassadors for campus visits
• Fifth Row or Individual performances
• Emcee
• Contribution towards design and concepts for events
• Designing and developing tokens of appreciation to donors
• Any other similar activities and contributions

For further details or clarification, please contact the Office of Advancement at Tel. No.: 6303 6684 or email: advancement@sutd.edu.sg.

Subject: IEEE-SUTD Data Structures and Algorithms Workshop
Body:
Heyloo, everyone! 🥳  

We, at IEEE-SUTD, are conducting the Data Structures and Algorithms workshops on 4th and 5th September (Saturday and Sunday). 

If you're a Term 3 student looking at gearing up for Data Driven World (DDW) or if you're a freshmore looking at getting into computer science-y content, here's your basic survival kit.


Please do indicate your availability via the registration link below if you're up for learning or refreshing basic data structures and algorithm concepts for tech interviews (or otherwise). 🙃

Data Structures Workshop:
Date: 4th September, 2021 - Saturday
Title: Data Structures
Time: 19:00 - 21:00 PM

Algorithms Workshop:
Date: 5th September, 2021 - Sunday
Title: Algorithms
Time: 17:00 - 19:00 PM

Both sessions will be virtual and the link will be sent closer to each event. 

Here's the registration link!
https://forms.office.com/Pages/ResponsePage.aspx?id=drd2NJDpck-5UGJImDFiPUKWD5LWMiRFjH3j_yGDQFRURUFMTjZDWEozWEs0QTg3VTJDVUs5QkhaTy4u <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.office.com%2FPages%2FResponsePage.aspx%3Fid%3Ddrd2NJDpck-5UGJImDFiPUKWD5LWMiRFjH3j_yGDQFRURUFMTjZDWEozWEs0QTg3VTJDVUs5QkhaTy4u&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C4f3fc9e38bc9448050ff08d96ea01564%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637662456602329476%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=u5E4VFCUGA%2FhZ4ZzwpYn7Awp8Zz54Ck3RffIbUc6V3o%3D&reserved=0>  

We really hope you join us on this two-day workshop that aims to equip you with the essential skills and foundations needed to work with data structures and algorithms. ✨

P.S. Incoming freshmores are more than welcome to register!

Cheers,
Kaveri Priya Putti
President of IEEE-SUTD

Subject: Participate in this fun reverse engineering activity on 17 September!

 

Hello!

 

Would you like to help us better understand the strengths and weaknesses of reverse engineering in a classroom setting? You can help us by participating in this classroom activity on campus on 17 September 2021, Friday, from 3.45 to 5.45 pm! It will be a fun and interesting activity and there is a possibility that a Minister may drop by!

 

To volunteer for this activity and study, please read the attached Participant Information Sheet (PIS) and register at https://forms.office.com/r/4Vf765MFYN <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.office.com%2Fr%2F4Vf765MFYN&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C5091464956674869d0c708d96ea023b4%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637662456506365031%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=ehlrS8atOopAErRjL2xzAP7MC2rR8oLdMYJKGDtEor4%3D&reserved=0>  by 3 September 2021. All information will be kept confidential and any identifiers will be deleted before data analysis.

Subject: LKY CIC Brown Bag Lunchtime Talk: Trusting Cultural Similarities when Sharing Knowledge - Monday, 27 September 2021

Subject: Greenprint Online Info Session 2021
Body:
Hello SUTD Family,

Are you passionate about the environment🌳? Looking for like-minded individuals to work together on projects in this field or just a place to meet new friends? Look no further, SUTD Greenprint is having its online intro session on the 8th of September from 8-9pm. Learn about what’s going on currently in the field of sustainability and ongoing projects by Greenprint. We will be posting the zoom link soon in our tele chat which you can join using the link below.  

 

2021 Greenprint Introduction Session 8 Sep 8pm - 9pm: https://t.me/joinchat/Fgl41tVMd_xkMWQ1 <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Ft.me%2Fjoinchat%2FFgl41tVMd_xkMWQ1&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C2574a7bc11bf46828edf08d96e827070%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637662329070871355%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=fmmJLDgOQW0VmE3yaxd2QILQaWm6GjPA7a8%2BMLo4Yto%3D&reserved=0> 

 

In addition, if you'd like to find more about composting and experience it first hand, Greenprint is organising its first virtual composting workshop on 11 Sep 2021, 11am - 12pm! Feel free to indicate your interest here: https://forms.office.com/r/c5qFyexQYa <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.office.com%2Fr%2Fc5qFyexQYa&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C2574a7bc11bf46828edf08d96e827070%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637662329070881342%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=qjd9ATK6D2TVSuraty6ZA57FT8NjYeiSxjWtNIj%2F5Cs%3D&reserved=0> 

 

Hope to see you there,

SUTD Greenprint



 

 

 

PDPA Disclaimer
The QR code/link will direct you to the 2021 Greenprint Introduction Session Chat Group. By agreeing to join this chat group voluntarily, your contact number may become visible to other participants inside the chat group so enter with caution.

Ensign Technical Graduate Programme
Ensign is launching their Technical Graduate Programme (TGP), with their first intake planned for 2022.

Ensign is a cyber-company with warmth and soul. They are ambitious, propelled by their vision to be the cyber defender of choice, and fueled by the dedication and camaraderie of individuals who are eager to make a difference, and leave their footprints in the industry.

Join them to find out more about their TGP! Interact with cyber professionals from their FOUR different business units and learn more about what they do. Read more <https://drive.google.com/file/d/14BenN03eCaD6LJDdQVKtDuvX0Q5wz6z9/view?usp=sharing>

Career Tips & Advice	

 

Anatomy of a Winning Resume 
The elements of a resume have evolved greatly over the years; back in the day, candidates would include their heights and weights on their CVs! Thankfully, those days are behind us, but that doesn't mean that the proper format of an effective resume is crystal clear.  Read more <https://access.vault.com/recordurl?nid=266399&wid=274402&vid=1> 


Click HERE  <http://access.vault.com/career-insider-login.aspx?aid=274402>  for full access and more career resources on Vault.com.
The service is free of charge for SUTD students and Alumni.
5 Common Interview Mistakes and How to Fix Them
You’re ready for a new challenge. You did your research, sent out applications, and eventually interviewed. When you finally heard back, you were told you were a great candidate, but your application just didn’t stand out. Why? Read more <https://access.vault.com/recordurl?nid=265911&wid=274402&vid=1>

Subject: Seminar: Venture Creation: NUS Strategy for Deep Tech Start Ups and their access into the Greater Asian Markets
Body:
Dear All

 

We are pleased to invite you to an interesting seminar by Professor Freddy Boey from NUS, who will share with us on the topic of Venture Creation: NUS Strategy for Deep Tech Start Ups and their access into the Greater Asian Markets. 

 

Prof Boey is the Deputy President (Innovation & Enterprise) of the National University of Singapore (NUS), overseeing the University’s initiatives and activities in the areas of innovation, entrepreneurship and research translation, as well as graduate studies.

 

Pls click the link below to register if you are interested to attend.  

https://sutd-edu.zoom.us/webinar/register/WN_F7eQiE4JSLm9ovLBRihmgQ

 

After registering, you will receive a confirmation email containing information about joining the webinar.

 <https://sutd-edu.zoom.us/webinar/register/WN_F7eQiE4JSLm9ovLBRihmgQ>  

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 


Talk Abstract

 

Over the past three years, NUS embarked on a broadened strategy to significantly increase the creation of NUS start-ups based on deep technology IP, through the creation of start-ups.  

 

Prof Freddy Boey will elaborate on this strategy and  introduce selected start-ups birthed from the strategy.   He will also present recent NUS collaborative expansion into China and ASEAN to access their huge markets. 

 

Speaker’s Biography

 

Professor Freddy Boey is the Deputy President for Innovation & Enterprise. He oversees the University’s initiatives and activities for innovation, entrepreneurship and research translation. 

 

An alumnus of NUS, Professor Boey was the Deputy President and Provost of Nanyang Technological University (NTU) from 2011-2017. During his tenure as the Provost, he helped transformed NTU into a world class Research University, jumping from 74th in 2011 to 11th in the world in the QS 2017 University World Ranking to be No.1 in Asia. NTU College of Engineering was also ranked 4th in the 2017 QS world subject ranking. He also led in building Singapore’s 3rd Medical School, the Lee Kong Chian Medical School, with Imperial College London. He was conferred the 2016 National Day Public Administration Gold Medal for this effort.

 

He was the Chair of NTU’s School of Materials Science and Engineering (MSE) from 2004 to 2010, transforming it into NTU’s top research school and became known as one of the world’s foremost MSE institution. Although MSE only started in 2000, it ranked 6th in QS world subject ranking and 2nd in US News world ranking in 2015 & 2016, with an outstanding reputation for generating start up technologies that can be commercialized. Professor Boey won the Singapore National Day Public Administration Silver Medal in 2010 for his achievement in building the School of MSE. 

 

A keen inventor, Professor Boey pioneered the use of functional biomaterials for medical devices in Singapore. He was conferred Singapore’s highest Scientific Award, the Singapore President Science & Technology Medal (PSM) for lifetime achievement, and the prestigious Imperial College London Faculty of Medicine Fellow award, both in 2013, for his biomedical research achievements. His research team also won the 2014 President’s Technology Award (PSTA) for using nanostructures with a novel drug delivery approach to combat blindness from glaucoma. 

 

He has developed 127 patents and founded several companies to commercialize his cardiovascular, ocular and surgical implants. His customizable hernia mesh has received US and China FDA approvals and received US & China funding as a US company. His fully biodegradable heart stent company, Amaranth, has been substantially funded by a Silicon Valley VC, EDB and the top US Medical Device company, Boston Scientific, for a series of advanced US FDA clinical trials in several hundred patients worldwide. His most recent company, Peregrine, is based on a nano based drug delivery system to treat Glaucoma, which has been successfully deployed in human trials. Prof Boey’s research has been published in over 347 top journals with 23,555 citations and he has an H-Index of 71. 

 

He previously served as director on the boards of the Government Technology Agency of Singapore and Defense Science Organisation. He remains a Director for the Health Sciences Authority and also contributes on many boards of nationally-funded research centres. He is a Fellow of the Institute of Materials (UK) and the Institution of Engineers Singapore, and a Founding Fellow of the Academy of Engineering, and had been a member of the National Cybersecurity R& D Laboratory and Singapore Rail Academy Board.

 

Important Notes:


•          All participants must be fully vaccinated, i.e. has received the full regimen of Pfizer-BioNTech/Comirnatry, Moderna or

             WHO EUL vaccines, with an additional two weeks for the vaccine to be fully effective.
•          Only full vaccinated participants are allowed to attend the event physically. Else, participants have to attend the event virtually. 
•          Masks must be worn at all times. Safe Management Measures, including safe distanced seating, will be enforced during the event. 

•          This webinar will be recorded for the benefit of those who missed the live session.

•          By registering for this event, you acknowledge that you have to comply with the appropriate Covid measures at the event. 

 

We look forward to having you at the seminar.  Thank you.

 

Best Regards

Office of Research

Subject: DDI Seminar on Machine Learning for Sustainable Building Design - 15 September 2021 at 4pm SGT
Body:
Dear all,

 

You are cordially invited to join the Data-Driven Innovation Lab seminar on Machine Learning for Sustainable Building Design and Real Estate Development. Please register here <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.office.com%2FPages%2FResponsePage.aspx%3Fid%3Ddrd2NJDpck-5UGJImDFiPQx1gnHA9rtFvR7iAWd84ZFURUxCUFZPSFgyQzVCWFdFR1NTSklUS0E0WS4u&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7Ccb862ad1d654457d838d08d96daa5d44%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637661400953661353%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=urkBywmk%2FnPv3aFuDelltEV2CZ3CYexIdTak%2B0M9WcE%3D&reserved=0> .

 

Date: 15 September 2021, Wed, 4pm, SGT

Title: Machine Learning for Sustainable Building Design and Real Estate Development

Speaker: Sayjel Patel, Co-Founder and CTO, Digital Blue Foam

 

Zoom Link: https://sutd-edu-sg.zoom.us/j/98162774168?pwd=UWNhMTVlQXZFaTkyejhLMG1Rd2ZIQT09 <https://sutd-edu-sg.zoom.us/j/98162774168?pwd=UWNhMTVlQXZFaTkyejhLMG1Rd2ZIQT09> 

Meeting ID: 981 6277 4168
Passcode: 594143

 

Title: Machine Learning for Sustainable Building Design and Real Estate Development

 

Speaker:
Sayjel Patel

Co-Founder and CTO, Digital Blue Foam

Singapore



 

About the Speaker:

Sayjel is Co-Founder and Chief Technology Officer of Digital Blue Foam — a software startup creating ML-powered tools for the sustainable urban design and real-estate development, and a founding Assistant Professor of the Dubai Institute of Design and Innovation. Previously, he was a researcher with the SUTD Digital Manufacturing and Design (DManD) Center, where he developed “Voxel Harvest'' an award-winning 3D printing design software, and the MIT Digital Structures Research Group, where he developed new computation methods for generating performative of textures and microstructures using 3D scan data. Sayjel holds a Master of Architecture from MIT (M.Arch ‘15) and an Honours Bachelor of Architectural Studies (HBAS ‘11) from the University of Waterloo.

 

Synopsis: 

The building construction industry faces an existential crisis. It is one of the least digitized industries and the world’s leading producer of C02 emissions. With rising temperatures around the globe and mass migration to urban centers, there is a dire need for a digital disruption that will enable more sustainable ways of working. 

How can we accelerate the building industry's transition to carbon zero to meet strict and urgent climate targets?  

In this talk, Sayjel will present his entrepreneurship journey as a co-founder of Digital Blue Foam; a Singapore-based software company pioneering a variety of ML-powered tools for sustainable building design. He will share a variety of recent projects, experiments, mis-fires and inspirations, as well as the story of his transition from academia to the start-up world.

 

We look forward to seeing you at the seminar!

 

Best Regards,

SUTD Data-Driven Innovation Lab | https://ddi.sutd.edu.sg <https://ddi.sutd.edu.sg/>

Ensign is launching our Technical Graduate Programme (TGP), with our first intake planned for 2022.  

 

We are a cyber company with warmth and soul. We are ambitious, propelled by our vision to be the cyber defender of choice, and fueled by the dedication and camaraderie of individuals who are eager to make a difference, and leave their footprints in the industry.

 

We seek to cultivate the next generation of Cybersecurity leaders through this programme. 

 

Join us to find out more about our TGP! Interact with cyber professionals from our FOUR different business units and learn more about what we do.

 

Date* :

Session 1 – 20 Sep 
Session 2 – 22 Oct

Time :

20 Sep – 9.30am – 12pm SGT

22 Oct – 1.30pm – 4pm SGT

Format*:

In-person or online

* The in-person session is only available to the first 30 successful registrants for each session. Subsequent registrants will be eligible for online participation. You will receive a confirmation email on your format of participation.
