Subject: Invitation to Participate in a Study on Voice on Assessment Methods
Body:
Dear Undergraduate Students, 

 

I am writing to invite you to participate in a research study aimed at understanding students, alumni and instructors’ perspectives and opinions on the adoption of e-exams and e-assessments and the applicability and relevance of current exam format to their future jobs. We will also investigate students’ understanding of plagiarism in open-book exams. 

 

Your participation in this study will help us better understand the reasons for the low uptake of e-exams and the preference of paper-based vs oral vs electronic exams from various stakeholders. The results obtained will also be used to design and create effective e-exam and e-assessment system and format that are more holistic, authentic and reflective of jobs that graduates are likely to do at their workplace.  

 

In this study, you will complete a 20-min long online survey. You can also participate in a 30-min long follow-up interview for us to better understand your response. To volunteer for this study, please read the Participant Information Sheet (PIS) and complete the online consent form found at [OneDrive link to PIS, consent form and survey questions] <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.office.com%2FPages%2FResponsePage.aspx%3Fid%3Ddrd2NJDpck-5UGJImDFiPRoA8Hzsd3hGiozOSMDYZBJUNE9CR1NCQktEWkdPRUQ4MkowVkozRlRKWi4u&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C29adc2be7c47446d33f608d964859558%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637651347371377531%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=%2BbNGvJFvGkIL%2F5W5RhYu11zxr4SBqQNG5HhexcAMsIs%3D&reserved=0> . All information will be kept confidential and any identifiers will be deleted before data analysis. 

 

In appreciation for your participation, participants, who complete the survey only, will receive a $5 NTUC gift voucher at the end of the study. Participants, who complete the survey and participate in the interview, will receive a $10 NTUC gift voucher at the end of the study. Kindly note that there is limited quantity of NTUC gift vouchers available (while stocks last). Therefore, issuance of NTUC gift vouchers are limited on a first come, first serve basis, subject to the availability of funds.

 

Participation 

Reimbursement Per Participant

Quantity

Survey only 

$5 NTUC gift voucher

251

Survey and Interview 

$10 NTUC gift voucher

49

 

The survey closes on 29 August 2021.

 

Please contact the Principal Investigator, Apple Koh (apple_koh@sutd.edu.sg <mailto:apple_koh@sutd.edu.sg> ), if you have any queries. 

 

Thank you,

Apple

Subject: Summary of coverage: Highlights of SUTD
Body:
Hi All,

 

Here’s the news coverage: 

 

-          Straits Times wrote an article on the historical value of a bungalow on Meyer Road, which included an expert insight from ASD Associate Prof Yeo Kang Shua.

-          Yahoo! News wrote about an anonymous poll conducted by AcademiaSG, which revealed that close to 78% of Singapore academics report at least "moderate" interference by non-academic actors in decision making at their respective institutions. This questionnaire was sent to 2,061 academics affiliated with five local universities, of which SUTD is one of them.

-          Channel NewsAsia published an article on elderly being unable to discern between real and fake news/scams online. HASS head, Prof Lim Sun Sun also contributed her expert opinions in this article.

-          Straits times did a feature on life after the Olympics for Singapore athletes and the article included quotes from ASD student and Olympian Jonathan Chan.

-          Radio station CNA938 Q&A programme interviewed LKYCIC research fellow, Dr Samuel Chng, for his views on why it is important to celebrate or commemorate National Day.

________________________________

 

Straits Times, 20 Aug 2021, 'Mr Toilet' Jack Sim's Meyer Road bungalow is a slice of local history (https://www.straitstimes.com/life/home-design/mr-toilet-jack-sims-meyer-road-bungalow-is-a-slice-of-local-history <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.straitstimes.com%2Flife%2Fhome-design%2Fmr-toilet-jack-sims-meyer-road-bungalow-is-a-slice-of-local-history&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C34b0af440fde46398cbb08d963c44cd9%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637650517211944805%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=U4YEHV9uoKQOxdr9DxrtIgWonRvjn1ppPsdUKch%2FhIc%3D&reserved=0> )

 

SINGAPORE - While others saw a ramshackle house in Katong that was ready for the wrecking ball, Mr Jack Sim - also known as Mr Toilet - saw endless possibilities.

 

The founder of the World Toilet Organization, who is also a passionate advocate for preserving all things heritage, says he could not bear the thought of losing a slice of local history to redevelopment and decided to buy the decrepit house.

 

He forked out $902,000 for the 6,000 sq ft property in 1992. Today, it is estimated to be worth about $13 million.

 

"The property in Meyer Road had been languishing on the market for almost 10 months with no takers until I bought it," says the self-made millionaire, who founded the organisation in 2001.

 

He made his fortune in the construction business at the age of 24 and retired at the age of 40, in 1997.

 

"I guess I have a knack for seeing good in the bad," says the 64-year-old with a smile.

 

He lives in the bungalow with his wife Julie, 60, and their four children, who are in their 20s.

 

He also owns three other heritage properties - two conservation shophouses in Serangoon Road and Race Course Road, and a shophouse in Malacca's Heeren Street called Malaqa House, a museum and shop featuring Peranakan and Malay antiquities.

 

After acquiring the Meyer Road house, he paid another $330,000 to extend the land behind it so that he could squeeze in a pool, a small pavilion and a rock-hewn waterfall.

 

He also spent more than $500,000 on renovation, engaging a contractor and restoring the property without guidance from conservation architects, based only on his "gut feel" about what the house needed.

 

The house now has seven bedrooms, a study and two cavernous living rooms.

 

The property has had three owners since it was built. Records are unclear about when exactly construction began, but from Colony of Singapore court-filed property papers, the first owner was Arab merchant Shaikh Omar Abdullah Bamadhaj, a trustee of the management committee in the 1920s at Haji Yusoff Mosque in Hillside Drive, off Upper Serangoon Road.

 

In 1936, he sold the house for $7,000 to Madam Rahma Ezekiel, widow of Singapore's first optometrist, Manasseh Isaac Ezekiel.

 

After her death in 1941, she willed the property to her sons Elias and Abraham Ezekiel, who held it in a trust until it was sold in 1992.

 

According to the National Heritage Board (NHB), the house is neither a national monument nor a conserved building.

 

An NHB spokesman says that judging from maps from 1932 and 1954, the building could be dated as far back as the late 1920s.

 

According to newspaper reports published between 1932 and 1936, the house was known as Parkview, a European kindergarten and preparatory school.

 

But who designed the original structure and submitted the architectural plans to the British Municipality in the early 1900s?

 

Records in the National Archives of Singapore show that "additions and alterations" were made in 1936 by a little-known British architect, Eric Vernon Miller, who ran a professional practice in Singapore, E.V. Miller and Company, for about a decade, starting in the 1930s.

 

He had earlier designed a row of terraced shophouses in Petain Road in 1930 in a hybrid Chinese-Peranakan style for a businessman named Mohamed Haji Omar.

 

Associate Professor Yeo Kang Shua, from the Singapore University of Technology and Design, says more research is needed to determine the architect of Parkview.

 

"We still do not know who the original architect is," says the architectural conservator and president of the International Council of Monuments and Sites Singapore, a professional body that the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization consults on matters related to World Heritage Sites.

 

"Mr Miller was the architect for the alterations, which include reinforced spiral and circular staircases and reinforced concrete bathrooms.

 

"This might explain why the architecture of the house is so different from what he is known for - his Modernist style - but, as with most architects, exceptions were known.

 

"A case in point would be his Petain Road townhouses."

 

According to architectural historian Julian Davison, Mr Miller was an alumnus of Singapore's Raffles Institution, which suggests he was probably Singapore-born.

 

There is no indication of where or how he received his architectural education, but he was likely to have had some sort of professional training in order to secure the job of assistant architect with the local Municipality in 1920.

 

"Mr Miller quit the Municipality and, in 1930, he was working for an architect called J.M. Jackson, which is when he designed the Petain Road townhouses," says Dr Davison, who has penned several books on Singapore architecture, including Swan & Maclaren: A Story Of Singapore Architecture (2020).

 

"In 1934, he set up a private practice called E.V. Miller and Co at 9 Robinson Road.

 

"Regarding Mr Sim's house, the surviving drawings are for 'additions and alterations' and are dated 1936. However, the house was clearly built in the mid- to late-1920s, even possibly the early 1930s, so it may well be that Mr Miller was also responsible for the original structure. But we still need to be sure and more research is needed."

 

Dr Davison adds: "Back then, if modifications to an existing building were in order, usually the architect of the original design would be commissioned to carry them out - unless it was the architect's poor performance the first time round which made the subsequent alterations necessary."

 

Mr Sim says he had his work cut out for him after buying Parkview.

 

"The roof was in tatters because it had been ravaged by termites," he says, recalling the arduous undertaking of making the house liveable again.

 

"The entire living room floor had caved in due to repeated flooding, which was common in the Katong area before the Government built Marina Barrage in 2008, which stopped the stormwater runoff.

 

"Back in 1992, we had to raise the floor by 45cm, construct a new roof, replace most of the old and damaged ceramic tiles with hardier granite flooring and rebuild the entire house. It took more than six months to complete."

 

The only parts of the house that had weathered the decades of disrepair were the main staircase and the second-storey floorboards, which were made of balau wood, a resinous Malaysian hardwood which was typically used since the 1800s in South-east Asia and ages well.

 

Mr Sim also engaged carpenters to restore all 22 cast-iron windows, which had become rusty. They were replaced with chengal wood, which is water-resistant and more suited to tropical climes.

 

Over the years, he has been filling the home with his art collection, which includes granite sculptures of stone drums salvaged from the old Pulau Ubin quarry. There are also more than 35 bronze busts of Singapore's first prime minister Lee Kuan Yew, which are produced by workshops in Thailand from his graphite pencil sketches.

 

"I was always fascinated by colonial houses built by the English, French and Europeans, especially how the architecture was tropically adapted for the region," adds Mr Sim, who was the subject of a feature-length documentary titled Mr Toilet: The World's #2 Man, which premiered in Toronto, Canada in 2019.

 

"Eventually, I may have to sell this house, so I hope the fourth owner will not tear it down. The first owner was a wealthy Arab merchant, the second was a prominent Jewish optometrist and the third, a Chinese businessman turned sanitation champion."

 

With such a storied past, Mr Sim hopes his home, which he affectionately calls "Fort House", will continue to stand the test of time. He named it after the nearby Fort Tanjong Katong, one of the oldest military forts constructed by the British colonial government. It stood from 1879 to 1901.

 

"If more of Singapore's historical sites make way for redevelopment, it is analogous to fumigation - you end up killing the good bugs along with the bad," he says. "Then we run the risk of ending up with a very modern but sterile built environment."

 

 

Yahoo News!, 19 Aug 2021, 78% of Singapore academics report at least 'moderate' interference: poll (https://news.yahoo.com/78-percent-singapore-academics-report-moderate-interference-poll-034122978.html <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fnews.yahoo.com%2F78-percent-singapore-academics-report-moderate-interference-poll-034122978.html&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C34b0af440fde46398cbb08d963c44cd9%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637650517211954795%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=v6E3wSzSKBLOdlXUSxEjNebKd3opXxOqg4u2YJye%2FmQ%3D&reserved=0> )

 

Some 77.5 per cent of Singapore academics report at least "moderate" interference by non-academic actors in decision making at their respective institutions, with almost 22 per cent claiming "extensive" interference, according to a new survey.

 

More than a quarter of those polled reported consistent restrictions such as censorship and self-censorship in academic exchange and dissemination in at least some disciplines. The survey results on academic freedom in Singapore were released on Wednesday (18 August).

 

And more than a third know of cases where colleagues have been told to withdraw or modify research findings for non-academic reasons, with almost 70 per cent believing that the reasons were political or ideological.

 

"Explicit signals from supervisors and/or peers, as well as their own reading of the political environment, are major reasons why Singapore academics feel inhibited in their activities," said a report on the survey, authored by academics Cherian George of Hong Kong Baptist University and Shannon Ang of Nanyang Technological University.

 

For example, 71 per cent of respondents reported receiving advice from peers that pursuing a specific research project would not be politically welcome.

 

"The survey findings suggest that most of the constraints on academic freedom are not felt as direct, external interventions. Political constraints have been institutionalised within universities," concluded the authors. 

 

Examples include internal rules and guidelines requiring faculty to obtain permission before engaging with the public, as well as adding an avenue for political checks to supplement standard research ethics clearance procedures. In other cases, political checks are not formalised, but take the form of collegial advice from supervisors. 

 

"While departmental or university administrators may exercise the most immediate and direct controls, academics affected believe that the ultimate source of pressure is the state."

 

198 responses out of 2,061

 

The anonymous poll was conducted by AcademiaSG, a collective of Singaporean academics, from April to May 2021. It set out to answer, among other queries, how prevalent in Singapore universities is the sense of being constrained, and what are the mechanisms through which academic work is restricted.

 

A questionnaire was sent to 2,061 academics affiliated with humanities, social science, business, and law schools of five local universities (National University of Singapore, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore Management University, Singapore University of Technology and Design, and Singapore University of Social Sciences). 

 

Of these, 198 unique responses were received. The study did not aim to cover all academics but only those in the humanities, social sciences and certain professional schools.

 

Acknowledging that the response rate appeared low, the authors stressed that they had contacted virtually the entire population of academics within the target areas/schools. They added that, all things considered, a response rate of 9.6 per cent was "reasonable".

 

Political pressures are not random

 

While political pressures do not affect the majority of academics, it is also clear that the distribution of pressure and punishment is not random, said the authors. "It affects research topics perceived to be politically sensitive, mostly concerning Singapore society; and activities that bridge the gap between the ivory tower and the wider public."

 

This, said the quartet, is likely to have led to a systemic under-capacity in Singapore academia’s ability to contribute to society in precisely those national debates that need to be more plural and better informed. 

 

They warned, "Any such under-contribution is not likely to be detected in global university rankings, but its social impact may be long-term and profound."

 

Several respondents also referred to the "open secret" in higher education in Singapore: the practice of political vetting in hiring and tenure decisions. "Academics’ awareness of this opaque vetting system – which apparently extends to work permit and residency applications for foreign faculty – is probably the main inhibitor of their exercise of free inquiry and communication."

 

One respondent wrote, "What strikes me most as a relatively new faculty is the power of self-censorship at both the individual and university level. The university is primarily concerned about reputation management, with little incentive to back faculty who engage in more sensitive or controversial research."

 

Self-censorship is key

 

Self-censorship was a key theme at a webinar discussing the findings of the survey on Wednesday evening. Panelist Walter Theseira, Associate Professor at the Singapore University of Social Sciences, said the most striking finding of the survey was the low response rate, which suggested that most do not think it worthwhile to engage on academic freedom.

 

"With apathy, a negotiated community consensus on academic freedom is impossible," said Prof Theseira, who added that such apathy will substantively affect the quality of education and teaching. 

 

Panelist Linda Lim, Professor Emerita at the University of Michigan, noted that she had been advised by friends to "better be careful" about her involvement in the survey. "Nobody really knows what it refers to but you are expected to internalise it."

 

Prof Lim noted that one of the key roles of an academic is to challenge the status quo. "If we observe hidden OB markers or red lines…we are all the poorer for it."

 

 

Channel NewsAsia, 18 Aug 2021, Fake news, scams and extremist views: Should we be concerned about what older family members are doing online? (https://www.channelnewsasia.com/singapore/fake-news-scams-online-elderly-internet-facebook-2107146 <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.channelnewsasia.com%2Fsingapore%2Ffake-news-scams-online-elderly-internet-facebook-2107146&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C34b0af440fde46398cbb08d963c44cd9%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637650517211964789%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=oItsm6B6dyaVpQzq4X2qsPm3NCg8K%2Bp%2BEDVYOVQL2kk%3D&reserved=0> )

 

SINGAPORE: What do you do when an older family member shares fake news with you or when you find out they get their news updates from dubious sources? 

 

Knowing that they might not be as Internet-savvy as you are, how do you make sure they don’t fall prey to scams or buy fake products?

 

Sarah (not her real name) found out that her father was making xenophobic, racist and nationalistic comments on Facebook. After seeing a notification on his phone, she also found out that he follows very conservative pages and news sites. 

 

The 26-year-old logged into his account and followed more progressive sites and voices to make his Facebook newsfeed more balanced. 

 

Her father also buys items online from sponsored ads on Facebook without researching the product first, and often shares fake news with their family. He spends about one to three hours on the platform each day. 

 

“I don’t think he has the capacity to research and to fact check. Because of that, the only alternative is to trust what he reads online,” she said. 

 

Growing up, millennials like Sarah were constantly warned about the dangers of the Internet. 

 

“Be careful of what you click on. Don’t talk to strangers. You don’t even know what could be out there,” their parents said at the time. 

 

In turn, those who grew up with access to the Internet and social media platforms now have concerns about what their parents might find online – fake news, extremist views, online scams and deals that are too good to be true. 

 

FAKE NEWS 

A study by the Institute of Policy Studies (IPS) last year found that more than two-thirds of Singaporeans cannot discern between real and fake news, especially seniors and those living in smaller public flats. 

 

The study’s authors interviewed 2,011 respondents, who were shown a manipulated news article and asked to determine its trustworthiness. 

 

Only 32.5 per cent of respondents correctly said that the article was not trustworthy.

 

In the study, respondents were divided into four groups – informationally disengaged, informationally overconfident, informationally diffident and informationally savvy. 

 

The first group, which had the lowest use and lowest trust in media and the second-highest rate of confirmation bias, had the highest proportion of seniors. Of this group, 73.1 per cent trusted the manipulated article. 

 

Experts CNA spoke to agreed that older generations seem to have more trouble with verifying information online. 

 

This could be because older generations are more trusting in general, while younger generations are more sceptical, said Associate Professor Edson Tandoc Jr of the Wee Kim Wee School of Communication and Information at the Nanyang Technological University (NTU). 

 

“One thing interesting that we found is that those who trust traditional media were also more likely to believe in fake news … And if you look at the profile of those who trust traditional media, it’s usually the elderly,” he added. 

 

However, that does not mean younger digital natives do not fall prey to fake news. 

 

"I think sometimes (we are) too confident of our skills ... Basically when we compare our perception of our capability to detect fake news with our actual capabilities, sometimes there's a mismatch, where some people overestimate their capability to protect themselves from falsehoods", said Assoc Prof Tandoc. 

 

Older people tend to be more vulnerable to such issues because of a lack of technical skills, he added. 

 

Their social networks are also smaller and less diverse in insights and expertise, said Professor Lim Sun Sun, who teaches media and communication at the Singapore University of Technology and Design. 

 

“If you consider someone in their 50s who's still gainfully employed, the opportunity for them to continue learning on the job … with regard to new technological platforms, to have colleagues to check their knowledge against, verify their uncertainties,” she said, adding that these people would also share information with them via social media platforms. 

 

Elderly people who live with younger family members have access to “warm experts” who help verify information, she said. 

 

This is not the case for those who live alone, and especially those who do not have much of a social network, said Prof Lim. This is a “very fundamental hindrance” to their learning about social media platforms, the Internet and best practices online, she added. 

 

In a 2020 survey, the Cyber Security Agency (CSA) found that the elderly, or those aged 55 and above, had generally lower awareness and adoption of good cyber practices like strong passwords and enabling two-factor authentication. 

 

The survey polled 1,052 Singapore citizens and permanent residents aged 15 years old and above on their general attitudes and behaviours towards cybersecurity practices and incidents. 

 

Although the overall perceived awareness of phishing increased, about one-third of respondents aged 55 and above were unaware of what phishing was, said the agency. 

 

RELYING ON FAMILY OR FRIENDS 

Public servant Chris Lim's mother used to often send fake news to her group chats on WhatsApp. The 29-year-old usually corrected her immediately and warned her not to spread such information. 

 

“My mum is the more typical kind of information-illiterate aunty. She’s educated and everything, but she’s the very embarrassing type that will forward fake news on WhatsApp groups,” he told CNA, adding that his mother is happy to be corrected. 

 

When the Protection from Online Falsehoods and Manipulation Act (POFMA) was introduced, she stopped sharing articles from unreliable or alternative sources, said Mr Lim. 

 

“I have scolded her so many times for just forwarding fake news and then correcting her ... because she knows both her sons are educated in an information-literate way, we won’t hesitate to correct her information, and we’ve been proven right on many occasions.” 

 

The opportunity to correct her usually comes up when the family is watching TV at home. When she comments on the news, Mr Lim and his brother correct any inaccurate information that she mentions, he added. 

 

Among the elderly, there is a heavy reliance on peers or groups as a way to verify information, said Assoc Prof Tandoc. 

 

Younger people would verify information by searching on Google and reading traditional media articles, but the elderly would check with their friends and family members about whether something is true, he added. 

 

“They rely a lot on their groups for authentication. Most of the time in these groups, either their friends would confirm, or if people don’t say anything then they also take that as no one is challenging this information,” said Assoc Prof Tandoc, who is also the director of the Centre for Information Integrity and the Internet.

 

This reliance on one’s peer group and social network is increasing the elderly’s vulnerability to fake news, said Assoc Prof Tandoc.

 

False information related to the COVID-19 pandemic is also a cause for concern. A 2020 survey by the National Centre for Infectious Diseases found that six in 10 Singaporeans have received fake COVID-19 news on social media, said the Media Literacy Council.

 

With people spending more time at home and more time online amid the pandemic, their exposure to online risks has increased, said the council in response to CNA's queries. 

 

UNDERSTANDING THE INTERNET

Sarah’s father is not familiar with how algorithms work on social media platforms like Facebook, she said. 

 

“He doesn’t realise that these things are confirming his beliefs. I’m not sure if it’s exacerbated his conservatism over the past few years,” she added. 

 

“I think I’m concerned because it’s wrong, and these things (conservative pages) do push you subtly further right, and that’s not good to have as a father or a person,” she told CNA. 

 

“I did try to get him to follow the more progressive Islamic leaders. But then I realised it didn’t work because when I scrolled through his Facebook again, it was still all these conservative news sites,” she told CNA. 

 

“Then I realised that even though I followed them, he never clicks on them.” 

 

There are studies that have found that most people are actually exposed to a diverse set of perspectives online, said Assoc Prof Tandoc. 

 

“But what I think they're missing is ... I might be exposed to a diverse set of perspectives, but what I will remember or what I will obsess about is the one that confirms my pre-existing beliefs,” he added. 

 

Having grown up in the era of social media, most young people understand how profit-oriented social media models work, said Prof Lim. 

 

They understand that “generating eyeballs” plays a part in how content is generated and pushed to different users, she added.  

 

Fake news, scams and extremist views being disseminated on the Internet are novel situations that are unprecedented for older generations, she added. 

 

“Fake news has been around for centuries. But the way it is now being made so compelling, the way it’s now being shared so widely by virtually anyone – I think that’s unprecedented so that’s novel,” said Prof Lim. 

 

Scams are also novel because they are presented in a sophisticated way with sites that look authentic, she added. 

 

Extremist news sites are similar to fake news as they use “certain modes of framing” to win readers over with their credibility, she added. “Also the fact that they are being algorithmically pushed to you based on previously viewed content, that also is novel.” 

 

“The elderly at the moment are really in quite uncharted waters so I think we can afford to be a bit more forgiving,” said Prof Lim. 

 

“I don’t think any previous generation of elderly faced such a heavy concoction of different kinds of novel content packaged in very alluring ways that are clearly manipulable and that have the weight of big data and algorithmically driven push behind them.” 

 

WHAT CAN BE DONE? 

The SG Cyber Safe Seniors Programme was launched in June this year, aimed at reaching out to 50,000 seniors between 2021 and 2023 to raise their awareness of cybersecurity and encourage good cyber hygiene practices, said CSA in its statement. 

 

The programme is “still in its early stages”, but CSA has “observed positive feedback” on the campaign. The agency did not provide figures on the take-up rate for the programme. 

 

Since 2013, the Media Literacy Council has created resources like videos and information sheets to “provide guidance” on issues like online scams, data protection, digital footprints, sharing content responsibly and discerning false information. 

 

It also works with the Singapore Digital Office under the Infocomm Media Development Authority to disseminate tips and resources to seniors. 

 

“Being digital natives, we do see the younger generation guiding their older family members to use mobile phones and computers, and teaching them how to use social media platforms and popular apps such as messaging apps, online shopping apps and digital payment apps,” said CSA. 

 

“In the same vein, they should also teach their older family members how to safeguard their personal or financial information online.” 

 

“For parents it's a bit difficult to accept that your children or people much younger than you are correcting you, or telling you what you should or shouldn't do ... especially in a society like Singapore and in most parts of Asia,” said Assoc Prof Tandoc. 

 

“Seniority is still very strong, and so that's why young people hesitate to correct, and also why older people feel a bit uncomfortable when they are corrected.” 

 

When Sarah advised her father that he should research the information online, he became “quite defensive”, she said. 

 

“I told him you need to Google it, you need to fact check first, this is all fake news. And then the next time, he just won’t listen to that advice,” she added. 

 

She has also tried to speak to her father about his views and what he consumes online – usually when he sends articles or posts to her. 

 

It’s important to explain how social media platforms work to drive content towards users, and that content that is most likely to draw eyeballs is most likely to draw an emotional reaction, said Prof Lim. 

 

“So a lot of the fake news videos they receive from friends would actually be manufactured in that field. That’s where it’s important for them to know what are the typical devices out there to get people to share, like and be outraged.” 

 

Gentle nudging and explaining can be helpful, and younger digital natives should be proactive about talking to their older family members about these issues, she added. 

 

“It basically takes explaining how the Internet works in very accessible terms.”

 

 

Straits Times, 17 Aug 2021, Life after the Olympics - S'pore athletes back in training, school, and pigging out (https://www.straitstimes.com/sport/life-after-the-olympics-spore-athletes-back-in-training-school-and-pigging-out <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.straitstimes.com%2Fsport%2Flife-after-the-olympics-spore-athletes-back-in-training-school-and-pigging-out&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C34b0af440fde46398cbb08d963c44cd9%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637650517211964789%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=NXUpX8r2QwPpEPG6jRRarxp7eoPD3LvLOq8gL4RA2iM%3D&reserved=0> )

 

What swimmer Quah Ting Wen did when she got home after completing her 14-day quarantine on Monday (Aug 16) was unpack her luggage from the Tokyo Olympics.

 

And then she started packing again. The 28-year-old is heading to Naples, Italy, on Sunday to represent United States-based team DC Trident in the International Swimming League, a short-course inter-team competition.

 

She also went for a much-needed haircut before returning to training at the OCBC Aquatic Centre on Tuesday.

 

Over the last two weeks, Singapore's 23 athletes who competed at the July 23-Aug 8 Tokyo Games - some of whom are still serving their stay-home notice (SHN) in hotels - have been busy making to-do lists, taking spin classes, indulging in their favourite foods and catching up with family and friends.

 

Quah had also spent her time in quarantine doing cardio and weights workouts, using equipment like a stationary bike and resistance bands, four to five times a week.

 

There was also plenty of time for self-reflection, as she said: "I learnt (in Tokyo) that... the mind can push you further but your body and mind have to work together.

 

"Just watching people make the most out of the situation... We saw some out-of-this-world swims. It sucks with Covid-19; some people who were expected to perform fell short, but we had a lot of surprise swims by people you didn't expect.

 

"It goes to show these have been an interesting two years and kudos to the swimmers wh

Subject: 3MT contest - Master program in Urban Science, Policy and Planning
Body:
Dear all, 

Have you ever wondered what kind of research our master students in Urban Science, Policy and Planning produce? The 3MT contest is a great opportunity to discover it. 

Please encourage our students by watching their videos and voting for your favorite one. The hightened alert measures posed great challenges for students' research, so they do need some encouragement!

Also, do not hesitate to share the link to the contest as widely as possible as the vote is open to the public.

 

The 3MT videos are now ready for viewing via the link: 

https://urbanscience.sutd.edu.sg/news/3mt-your-thesis-in-3-minutes-contest-2021/ <https://urbanscience.sutd.edu.sg/news/3mt-your-thesis-in-3-minutes-contest-2021/> 



The voting will close by Monday August 23rd at noon (in 3 days). If you have any queries or issues to access the videos' site, please contact Christina Koek (christina_koek@sutd.edu.sg).




Thank you to Aaron Vicuna and Christina Koek for their help with organizing the contest.




Vote for your favorite 3MT video now!


Best regards,


Olivia NICOL



-- 


Olivia Nicol
Assistant Professor of Sociology
SUTD
Email: olivia.nicol@sutd.edu.sg <mailto:olivia.nicol@sutd.edu.sg> 
Tel.: +65 91780247 <tel:+65%209178%200247>

“By monitoring in real time how defects called dislocations evolve in a 2D form of silicon, the researchers uncovered a way of “healing” these defects that could yield fresh insights into how to accommodate similar irregularities in other nanomaterials.”

“Cornell researchers took a middling monomer and, by using a special catalyst, they created a tougher polymer that can form long chains. The polymer can then be easily depolymerized back to the monomer state with an acid catalyst, resulting in a chemically recyclable thermoplastic that competes with the most popular plastics, polyethylene and polypropylene.”

Source: Cornell UNIVERSITY <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fnews.cornell.edu%2Fstories%2F2021%2F08%2Fpolymer-enables-tougher-recyclable-thermoplastics&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C4f0a597c22dd40b58ded08d96386ca7d%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637650253219597678%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=3HH3K%2FdosyK6Hu74hSBvC2pVYHSocqiIIPpJZqBpld8%3D&reserved=0>  (13 August 2021)

 

ROBOTS

Faster Path Planning For Rubble-Roving Robots <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fnews.umich.edu%2Ffaster-path-planning-for-rubble-roving-robots%2F&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C4f0a597c22dd40b58ded08d96386ca7d%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637650253219607673%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=g6ZmbtbJupr%2FAAqJRfZRcuLWPDf9TmeTiNlgxSdcyps%3D&reserved=0> 

 

ROBOTICS

Robotic Floats Provide New Look At Ocean Health And Global Carbon Cycle <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.mbari.org%2Fobserving-global-ocean-productivity%2F&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C4f0a597c22dd40b58ded08d96386ca7d%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637650253219607673%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=fzNCqKnJ8gRkZgnuR2lHaNIpL9eTSYl%2BXcwiVtjVLD8%3D&reserved=0> 

 

SUSTAINABILITY

Touted As Clean, ‘Blue’ Hydrogen May Be Worse Than Gas Or Coal <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fnews.cornell.edu%2Fstories%2F2021%2F08%2Ftouted-clean-blue-hydrogen-may-be-worse-gas-or-coal&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C4f0a597c22dd40b58ded08d96386ca7d%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637650253219617670%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=HzX55QuSO8TLxB75huCox3EA7XCpXiOPNwxRUzdLPCc%3D&reserved=0> 

 

X-RAY

X-ray Technique Sheds Fresh Light On Correlated Metals <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fphysicsworld.com%2Fa%2Fx-ray-technique-sheds-fresh-light-on-correlated-metals%2F&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C4f0a597c22dd40b58ded08d96386ca7d%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637650253219617670%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=JXKdg9A5qhYyW0hQogJy7ySkfT6BS2XpiLRpZtmVm7k%3D&reserved=0> 



\





“A new algorithm speeds up path planning for robots that use arm-like appendages to maintain balance on treacherous terrain such as disaster areas or construction sites, U-M researchers have shown. The improved path planning algorithm found successful paths three times as often as standard algorithms, while needing much less processing time.”

“MBARI researchers demonstrated that a fleet of robotic floats could provide important insight into ocean primary productivity on a global scale. Data from these floats can be used to improve computer modeling of Earth’s carbon cycle, climate change predictions, and ocean health.”

““Blue” hydrogen – an energy source that involves a process for making hydrogen by using methane in natural gas – is being lauded by many as a clean, green energy to help reduce global warming. But Cornell and Stanford University researchers believe it may harm the climate more than burning fossil fuel.”

“Researchers at the Paul Scherrer Institute (PSI) in Switzerland and the Brookhaven National Laboratory (BNL) in the US have employed an advanced X-ray spectroscopy technique to study the complex electronic properties of so-called correlated metals for the first time.”

Source: University of Michigan <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fnews.umich.edu%2Ffaster-path-planning-for-rubble-roving-robots%2F&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C4f0a597c22dd40b58ded08d96386ca7d%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637650253219627656%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=lyCTj05dnKmrA0ZLd4zHV%2B1QxWzcOip9KElV4ZAX%2F3k%3D&reserved=0>  (13 August 2021)

Source: MBARI <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.mbari.org%2Fobserving-global-ocean-productivity%2F&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C4f0a597c22dd40b58ded08d96386ca7d%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637650253219627656%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=hh1lrAsu%2Fv4fgK%2FNpRmK25TEidPxv773jsVrpP4AIvQ%3D&reserved=0>  (16 August 2021)

Source: Cornell University <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fnews.cornell.edu%2Fstories%2F2021%2F08%2Ftouted-clean-blue-hydrogen-may-be-worse-gas-or-coal&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C4f0a597c22dd40b58ded08d96386ca7d%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637650253219637655%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=R9%2Bqz6slEVH%2BFbGlCNe2X61n14l1gquMcaNKxrbDaa4%3D&reserved=0>  (12 August 2021)

Source: Physics World <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fphysicsworld.com%2Fa%2Fx-ray-technique-sheds-fresh-light-on-correlated-metals%2F&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C4f0a597c22dd40b58ded08d96386ca7d%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637650253219647647%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=Vi7owCiPCn8TZ1WBzqP2k4Q5YsDHOqxtJJBGISz2zXE%3D&reserved=0>  (13 August 2021)

Seniors from ASD, CSD, EPD & ESD 


	
Career Tips & Advice	

 

How to Stand Out at Virtual Career Fairs
It isn’t easy to stand out at in-person job fairs, and leaving a lasting impression with employers at virtual job fairs can be just as challenging. However, if you follow the eight tips below, you’ll have no difficulty making meaningful professional connections and differentiating yourself from other candidates. Read more <https://access.vault.com/recordurl?nid=263280&wid=274402&vid=1> 


Click HERE  <http://access.vault.com/career-insider-login.aspx?aid=274402>  for full access and more career resources on Vault.com.
The service is free of charge for SUTD students and Alumni.
How to Change Your Job-Search Approach and Turn Rejections into Offers
Regardless of whether you find out at the beginning or end of the hiring process that you didn’t get an offer, it's a mistake not to change your approach going forward. If you keep taking the same approach, you'll likely keep getting the same results. Read more <https://access.vault.com/recordurl?nid=259390&wid=274402&vid=1>

Subject: RE: Freshmore Term 3 Electives Enrolment
Body:
Message Classification: Restricted 

 

Dear Freshmore Students, 

 

For the upcoming Term 3, you will be assigned to (new) cohort classes based on your choice of electives.

 

Information on your class assignment and timetable will be available in MyPortal from 03 September 2021 onwards.

 

For queries and assistance, please contact studentadmin@sutd.edu.sg <mailto:studentadmin@sutd.edu.sg> .

 

Thank you.

 

 

Best Regards

Office of Student Administration

 

 

 

From: Student Admin 
Sent: Monday, April 26, 2021 12:16 PM
To: Student Admin <studentadmin@sutd.edu.sg>
Subject: Freshmore Term 3 Electives Enrolment

 

Message Classification: Restricted 

 

Dear Students, 

 

In preparation of your upcoming Term 3 elective enrolment, you are required to select your combination of 2 electives by ranking them. You will subsequently be allocated one of the combinations indicated in your choices. You will only be allocated the subject combination if you have met the pre-requisite(s), if any. 

 

Electives and Combinations Available

*	10.019 Science and Technology for Healthcare <https://sutd.edu.sg/Admissions/Undergraduate/Unique-Curriculum/Freshmore-Subjects/Science-and-Technology-for-Healthcare> 
*	10.020 Data Driven World <https://sutd.edu.sg/Admissions/Undergraduate/Unique-Curriculum/Freshmore-Subjects/Data-Driven-World> 
*	10.023 Designing Energy Systems <https://sutd.edu.sg/Admissions/Undergraduate/Unique-Curriculum/Freshmore-Subjects/Designing-Energy-Systems> 
*	10.024 Spatial Design World <https://sutd.edu.sg/Admissions/Undergraduate/Unique-Curriculum/Freshmore-Subjects/Spatial-Design-World> 

 



 

 

Please submit your choices via this link: https://forms.office.com/r/jXXQuBJL6W <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.office.com%2Fr%2FjXXQuBJL6W&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C1d142b368d844a313cc808d962e694f7%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637649564813091899%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=RoVbahJVeIi0os8rnM3NTa4PmNMX6gpJtwFhUL2dM68%3D&reserved=0> . (Please sign in using your SUTD email address and password if required)

 

The deadline for submission is 7 May, 05:00PM. If you wish to amend your choices after submission, you may resubmit before the deadline and the latest entry will be processed

 

For queries and assistance, please contact studentadmin@sutd.edu.sg <mailto:studentadmin@sutd.edu.sg> .

 

Thank you.

Subject: Peer Evaluation - Let Your Voice Be Heard
Body:
Dear SUTDents,

 

We are a group of SUTD undergraduate students and faculty working to develop a new peer evaluation system.

 

There are many group projects in the courses at SUTD and peer evaluation will be a good platform for students to evaluate their group members as well as to self-reflect. However, peer evaluation is often seen as a tedious process, so we hope to streamline this process for both the students and the instructors.

 

We are hoping to gather feedback from you through a 5-min survey to find out your views on user interface features and attributes important in peer evaluation, to help design an user-friendly and useful peer evaluation system.

 

For more information about this project, please refer to the Participant Information Sheet and complete the 5-min survey here https://bit.ly/3j8cC8x <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fbit.ly%2F3j8cC8x&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7Ce49b47c163de44168cd208d962d54d3d%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637649490625645613%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=xlW6KPGJdk%2FJytka68mZNKePYzPsVYZf1zE2%2FCBehro%3D&reserved=0> 

If you have any queries, please contact the Principal Investigator, Apple Koh (apple_koh@sutd.edu.sg <mailto:apple_koh@sutd.edu.sg> ).

 

Thank you!

 

Regards,

Oka

Subject: Recruitment Drive: The Young SEAkers (SEAkers@Uni)
Body:
Dear SUTD Students,

 

We are happy to collaborate with The Young SEAkers to share opportunities for our students to gain insight and perspectives into ASEAN & China! 

 

About The Young SEAkers

The Young SEAkers (TYS) is a regional non-profit youth start up established in April 2020 amidst the COVID-19 pandemic, and one of the season 2 winners of the National Council Youth Action Challenge. To date, they have a chapter in 8 countries within ASEAN (enroute to reaching all 10 nations and China by the end of 2021). With their regional network and three step journey - network, experience and mentorship process - they develop cross-cultural intelligence and soft skills competence in ASEAN youths.  TYS is a regional one-stop-shop for youths to access the region.

 

Amongst a host of other opportunities, here are some exciting opportunities TYS offer to prepare youths for their future careers together and spark long-term friendship:

*	SEAkers Go! 

	*	Learning journeys to China and different ASEAN countries that include both corporate and cultural visits. 

*	SEAkers Meet & Mingle 

	*	Social-Professional lunch and dinner conversations between ASEAN youths and working professionals. 

*	SEAkers Mentoring 

	*	1-1 mentorship program connecting youths with professionals from regional backgrounds 

*	SEAkers in Dialogue 

	*	Dialogue sessions with ASEAN/China experts, where they share their insights on selected topics. 

*	SEAD and Connect 

	*	Peer-to-peer networking programs to expand their youth networks 

Interested? How to Participate?

TYS is currently looking to expand their team and would like you to join them in the planning and execution of the events for SUTD students. Your attendance to be part of their team is valuable and they hope to make a difference to the SUTD community by helping them tap of the potential of the opportunities available in the ASEAN-China region. 

If you are keen to be part of The Young SEAkers, you can reach out to Arshad, who is currently the SUTD Club President of SEAkers@Uni, a subsidiary of The Young SEAkers Singapore <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.theyoungseakers.com%2Fsingapore&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C28af4ad96e9345668bf008d96232e121%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637648793012325933%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=mFnr5UAT9yre5x3aEsdURzRSCVA4VuNqMU7JxcVVVQ8%3D&reserved=0> .  He is contactable at Mohamad_arshad@mymail.sutd.edu.sg <mailto:Mohamad_arshad@mymail.sutd.edu.sg>  or on his Telegram: @mhmdrshd97

 

We hope that you will take up the challenge and journey on this path towards closer regional collaboration with TYS.

 

Best regards,

 

Office of International Relations

Singapore University of Technology and Design

Subject: HAVE YOU REGISTERED for DESIGN and AI in the DATA DRIVEN WORLD  virtual event?

Have you registered for the DESIGN and AI in the DATA DRIVEN WORLD” virtual event that’s happening on 7 & 8 Sep 2021?

It’s your chance to hear from industry experts on how Design and AI is making significant changes in organisations in the industry PLUS you can participate in the challenge and win up to $1000 of shopping vouchers!!

Cheers!

Zerline

To: Tan Sze Ling Zerline <zerline_tan@sutd.edu.sg>
Subject: [SUTD Virtual Event] DESIGN and AI in the DATA DRIVEN WORLD - 7 & 8 Sep 2021

 

Dear SUTD Freshmores (Class of 2024)

 

The Design and Artificial Intelligence (DAI) programme invites you to join us at this upcoming “DESIGN and AI in the DATA DRIVEN WORLD” virtual event that’s happening on 7 & 8 Sep 2021.

Come find out the potential of Design and AI! Listen to industry experts and gain hands-on experience in creating AI algorithms in our workshop. Take part in our challenge and win up to $1000 of shopping vouchers!! 

 

If you are unsure of what the DAI programme is about, this virtual event will actually give you a glimpse into what you'll learn in the DAI programme. :)

 

For virtual event's programme, speakers' profile, challenge terms and conditions, please visit: https://www.sutd.edu.sg/About/happenings/Events/2021/9/Design-and-AI-in-the-Data-Driven-World

Subject: Survey on Virtual vs In-Person Classes
Body:
Dear F02 Freshmores

 

Hope you all are doing well and have a fruitful break over the summer! A few of our colleagues, including myself, have recently embarked on a project to study how technology facilitates students’ learning and we would like to seek your help to take part in this 10 minutes anonymous survey to help us understand this. Your insightful responses based on your prior experiences in online classes (SS Physics, SS Math, or classes you have taken elsewhere) will be extremely helpful for us to understand the challenges and opportunities in such mode of learning.

 

The results from this survey will potentially help us to better design pedagogies and more effective use of technology beyond the pandemic to support the changing learning environment (physical, online, and hybrid). More importantly, we hope that whatever we come up with eventually is grounded on the needs of fellow students like yourself. 

 

Here is the survey link.

https://forms.gle/QP4qj5uLXCC7RKFX7 <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.gle%2FQP4qj5uLXCC7RKFX7&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C88e4795dacde4a220d0108d961fb873c%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637648555203911419%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=Oh9Uu8XcNsDbp0z81YVk2ZeRJ8wO%2BvtrDthcFfiNgLo%3D&reserved=0> 

 

I personally thank you in advance for your help on this! Hope to see you all around physically in 3 to 4 weeks time! 😊

 

Regards

Da Yang

 

P.S. If you are interested in the results of the survey, please feel free to reply me directly and I will drop you the results when ready.

P.P.S. For the few of you who was in my SS Physics class, this is the same survey that I have sent out a moment ago.

Body:
Dear Students,

 

 

 



 

Warm Regards,

Career Development Centre

Customer Spotlight	 
Zoom and Taraji P. Henson Raise $550,000 for BIPOC Mental Health <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fclick.zoom.us%2Fe%2F84442%2F50000-for-bipoc-mental-health-%2Fc3lhnk%2F3510787366%3Fh%3DDYZbGF9cJgVnr51R9baDIzhA3H48W69M4rBDtbAuhFs&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C5cc03aa1d5dd4fd4125708d961bd7fe1%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637648288795643775%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=6hS%2BR%2FHMtoTH%2FQNio1uY%2FtQDdGJAPEgs43HUuFHh0yA%3D&reserved=0> 	 
 <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fclick.zoom.us%2Fe%2F84442%2F50000-for-bipoc-mental-health-%2Fc3lhnk%2F3510787366%3Fh%3DDYZbGF9cJgVnr51R9baDIzhA3H48W69M4rBDtbAuhFs&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C5cc03aa1d5dd4fd4125708d961bd7fe1%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637648288795653767%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=YMf1p6OB0RGijGXI1qw%2FCwQZx9sgZJnMV15hh4SBe%2BE%3D&reserved=0> 	 
As part of Black, Indigenous, and People of Color (BIPOC) Mental Health Month in July, Zoom partnered with the Boris Lawrence Henson Foundation (BLHF) <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fclick.zoom.us%2Fe%2F84442%2F2021-08-17%2Fc3lhnf%2F3510787366%3Fh%3DDYZbGF9cJgVnr51R9baDIzhA3H48W69M4rBDtbAuhFs&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C5cc03aa1d5dd4fd4125708d961bd7fe1%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637648288795653767%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=lNEC2evqXtazta1fChnqqJd5O7yASwidlldsv8lCjm0%3D&reserved=0>  to host “A Write to Education!: My Mental Health Matters,” a live awareness and fundraising event. With Zoom’s $250,000 matching grant, BLHF’s fundraising strategy, and Pledge’s live donation <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fclick.zoom.us%2Fe%2F84442%2F2021-08-17%2Fc3lhnh%2F3510787366%3Fh%3DDYZbGF9cJgVnr51R9baDIzhA3H48W69M4rBDtbAuhFs&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C5cc03aa1d5dd4fd4125708d961bd7fe1%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637648288795663762%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=43%2B92itxmnpp2%2FoRU01LgXVaVukcqFTVpYMl3P6D%2BCs%3D&reserved=0>  PledgeCam, the virtual event raised over $550,000.	 
Read More    <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fclick.zoom.us%2Fe%2F84442%2F50000-for-bipoc-mental-health-%2Fc3lhnk%2F3510787366%3Fh%3DDYZbGF9cJgVnr51R9baDIzhA3H48W69M4rBDtbAuhFs&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C5cc03aa1d5dd4fd4125708d961bd7fe1%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637648288795663762%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=yCUHHAeBJwNw3WkIkQrsWy9VTjdwpizpYqrjK1ZIxmM%3D&reserved=0>

Subject: Whatz Newz by Office of Student Life
Body:
Registration closes on 20 August 2021

Registration closes on 31 August 2021

 

 





Registration closes on 1 September 2021

Registration closes on 14 September 2021

 

 



Registration closes on 15 September 2021

 

Please refer to the PDF documents (attached) for more information.

Please note:

• Safe management measures are to be adhered to while participating in the respective activities.
• The activities/events/conferences indicated in this email are optional and are for students to explore on their own accord.
• Please ensure that you have checked your timetable and exam dates to avoid clashes prior to registering for the activities/events/conferences.

 

 Brought to you by 
Office of Student Life

Subject: [Inviting all students for CASE Logo Design Competition]
Body:
Dear Students, 

 

In celebration of CASE 50th Anniversary, they have launched a Logo Design Competition. Please refer to the below email and attachment for more information. 

 

Thank you. 

 

Warmest Regards

Office of Student Administration

If you have received this email in error, please inform the sender immediately by reply e-mail or telephone, reversing the charge if necessary. Please delete the message thereafter. Thank you.

 

 

 

The Consumers Association of Singapore (CASE) is celebrating our 50th anniversary this year, and we have launched a Logo Design Competition to invite entries by the students for a new logo for our next chapter!

 

Please see attached for the details and Terms & Conditions of the Competition. Information on the Competition can also be found on our website (https://bit.ly/3AF5aXX <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fbit.ly%2F3AF5aXX&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C8765407e57b44a0f508208d96148df3f%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637647788182235916%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=hxKzzqD77ysi71oLBVZBAZSaPQDBkpQ%2F51Tly5Ad6f8%3D&reserved=0> ).

 

The Competition will end on 30 September 2021, and the winner will receive an attractive cash prize of S$800.00.

 

We would appreciate it if you could assist to disseminate information on this Competition to the relevant student groups/bodies and faculties/schools within your school. To facilitate the dissemination, you may use the following copy below:

 



 

If you have any questions, feel free to reach me at my email address [yiting.chew@case.org.sg <mailto:yiting.chew@case.org.sg> ] or contact number below.

 

Thank you for your consideration and we look forward to receiving the entries. 

 

 

Best regards,

 

CHEW Yi Ting | Senior Executive, Marketing & Communications | Consumers Association of Singapore

ADDRESS: 170 Ghim Moh Road #05-01, Ulu Pandan Community Building, Singapore 279621

TEL: 6100 0315 | DID: 68091212 | FAX: 6467 9055 | www.case.org.sg <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.case.org.sg%2F&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C8765407e57b44a0f508208d96148df3f%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637647788182235916%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=p3jSIoYgKFzBW1WoJZRvHGuTEwIUB1FtLLO9wlQ0rJ0%3D&reserved=0>

Subject: Topological Solitons for Quantum Operations - 30 Aug (Mon) IAS@NTU Discovery Science Seminar
Body:
Dear all,

 

Forwarding the following invite for IAS@NTU Discovery Science Seminar on “Topological Solitons for Quantum Operations” by Professor Christos Panagopoulos.

 

Should you have any interest, please do register.

 

Thank you!

 

Best,

Esther Peh

 

From: Institute of Advanced Studies - Events <IASEvents@ntu.edu.sg <mailto:IASEvents@ntu.edu.sg> > 
Sent: Monday, August 16, 2021 4:47 PM
Subject: Topological Solitons for Quantum Operations - 30 Aug (Mon) IAS@NTU Discovery Science Seminar

 

 

Dear All

 

You are cordially invited to attend the following webinar:



 

Register now <https://ntu-sg.zoom.us/webinar/register/WN_eyIg2oPPRb-JPdcycTdHGA> 

 

We look forward to having you at our webinar.

 

Best regards

IAS NTU and the Graduate Students’ Clubs of SPMS and SCSE

Subject: <Call for Application> Fully sponsored TF-NUS LEaRN Youth Asian Leaders Initiative
Body:
Dear Student,

 

FINAL CALL: APPLICATION CLOSES TODAY, APPLY NOW <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.office.com%2Fr%2FWsLup7FPNw&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7Cb6d4fc7b257d42ee183d08d9607661cf%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637646884078932296%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=7sDwI4kuy0gzxC4oWSGKxsAIOsTa4pSNvKndNGAhofQ%3D&reserved=0> ! 

 

Be part of the inaugural TF-NUS LEaRN Youth Asian Leaders Initiative (YALI), a fully sponsored exclusive virtual programme by Temasek Foundation and National University of Singapore. Limited to only 10 slots for SUTD students. Refer to email below.

 

 

From: global@sutd.edu.sg <mailto:global@sutd.edu.sg>  
Sent: Thursday, August 5, 2021 5:31 PM
Subject: <Call for Application> Fully sponsored TF-NUS LEaRN Youth Asian Leaders Initiative 

 

 

Dear Student,

 

 

We are excited to invite you to participate in the inaugural TF-NUS LEaRN Youth Asian Leaders Initiative (YALI), a fully sponsored exclusive virtual programme by Temasek Foundation and National University of Singapore. 

 

Be part of the distinguished network of 120 local NUS/NTU/SMU/SUTD and ASEAN student leaders to interact, discuss and engage in Internationalisation at Home, over 10 weekly online (Zoom) sessions between September to November 2021! 

 

Participants will receive exclusive TF-SUTD LEaRN gifts (tshirt, totebag, notebook, bottle etc), and a certificate of completion which will value add to your resume.

 

 

APPLY NOW <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.office.com%2Fr%2FWsLup7FPNw&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7Cb6d4fc7b257d42ee183d08d9607661cf%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637646884078932296%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=7sDwI4kuy0gzxC4oWSGKxsAIOsTa4pSNvKndNGAhofQ%3D&reserved=0>  BY 16 AUGUST 2021!

 

 

 <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.office.com%2Fr%2FWsLup7FPNw&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7Cb6d4fc7b257d42ee183d08d9607661cf%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637646884078942292%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=ALx3BhooNyutWX6DLcQml%2Fb%2BQ8zmMgPvs%2Ff05bYXwsM%3D&reserved=0> 

 


Programme content:

 

Developing holistic resilience (physical, mental, social, and emotional), intrapersonal and intercultural skills and understanding

Preparing you for the future of work in Asia

Building necessary skills and mind sets to finding and securing employment

Interactive discussions for you to network with peers from the ASEAN region

Participants will enjoy full sponsorship of Programme fees 

 

Participants and mode of delivery:

 

120 participants (60 local NUS, NTU, SMU and SUTD students and 60 ASEAN students), only 10 slots for SUTD students

10 weekly online (Zoom) sessions between September to November 2021 

Full schedule and course outline as attached

 

Programme requirements:

 

Participants must join a programme-related Facebook group for networking purposes

Participants must submit an experience report of at least 500 words

Participants must achieve at least 80% attendance

If all is fulfilled, participants will receive a certificate of completion which will value add to your resume

 

Selection criteria:

Academic performance

Co-curricular records and community involvement

Successful applicants will be informed via email, where they will be guided on the next steps.

Any queries? Connect with us at global@sutd.edu.sg <mailto:global@sutd.edu.sg>  

 

 

APPLY NOW <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.office.com%2Fr%2FWsLup7FPNw&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7Cb6d4fc7b257d42ee183d08d9607661cf%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637646884078942292%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=ALx3BhooNyutWX6DLcQml%2Fb%2BQ8zmMgPvs%2Ff05bYXwsM%3D&reserved=0>  BY 16 AUGUST 2021!

 

 

Warmest Regards

 

Office of International Relations

Singapore University of Technology and Design (SUTD)

Subject: Notice for Students (13 August 2021)
Body:
Message Classification: Restricted

 

 

Dear Students,

In line with the national stance and the Ministry of Education (MOE)’s latest Safe Management Measures (SMMs), our university will adopt the following measures for the continued safety and well-being of students and staff. 

 

(A) Teaching Plan 

 

1.     (a)  ILP classes (bridging lessons for early matriculated students), Freshmore remedial classes (Bootcamp), Term 8/Term 9 (MArch)/PG revision classes, can be conducted on campus from Monday, 16 August 2021 (Week 14) to Friday, 10 September 2021 (Bootcamp period).

(b)   Final examinations (Week 14) will be conducted on campus.

(c)   Mode for Term 1/Term 3/Term 6/Term 10(MArch)/PG classes will be determined during the week of 23 August 2021, and will adjust further based on the situation at that time.

 

2.           Class size of all physical lessons is capped at 50 pax (including instructors).  Any classes with more than 50 pax (including instructors) will go online. The respective subject lead and pillar/cluster will inform the students for these classes of the arrangements, if any.

3.           Group discussion/activity is capped at 5 pax per group, (regardless of the individuals’ vaccination status), and with SMMs in place.

*         Faculty/Students should have their mask on at all times, and maintain a safe distancing of at least 1 metre between persons (or between groups of not more than 5 persons for group activities/team-based labs/projects/ASD studios). No intermingling between groups.

 

4.           Graduate students performing research are to work-from-home by default. However, for those who cannot effectively perform research work from home, (e.g. as you need to access specialized-systems / lab-equipment), need to seek clearance from your advisors/project-PIs/lab managers when you would like to return to campus. Please refer to the attached email circular by Office of Graduate Studies: Important Notice for PG students (effective 26 July 2021) - Research Activity on the SMMs for working in labs.

 

5.           Freshmore and Junior students are on Vacation / Internship / Summer Programme during the term. If there is a need to come to campus for any physical activities/events, the students shall get the approval from IMT through the programme and activity owner (e.g. Faculty, Pillar, OIR, CDC, UGS, OSL) at least two weeks before the physical activities/events.

 

Note for (1) to (5): 

 

*         As the situation is fluid and teaching plan can change in a short span of time, please refer to the instruction from the faculty, pillars, clusters, departments or offices for the latest and specific arrangement. 

*         Please refer to the attached PDF for the operating hours at the respective academic spaces and facilities. The operating hours is subject to changes in response to the evolving situation. Students shall refer to the latest notice from the respective departments or offices (e.g. Library/Fab lab/Capstone Office)

 

(B) Safe management measures

 

The university will continue to adhere to safe management measures to keep our SUTD community safe.  As the situation continues to evolve, we will provide updates in response to new advisory from the related government agencies. Please continue to observe the measures on the days when you are on campus. You will need to do the following:

 

(I) Before you come to campus

 

Please check in using the TraceTogether token or app before you are allowed entry onto campus. You should have your TraceTogether token or app with you throughout.

 

Please do not come onto campus if you or

*         your household members are unwell, with flu-like/respiratory symptoms or on Home Quarantine Order/Stay Home Notice

*         your roommate is unwell, with flu-like/respiratory symptoms or on Home Quarantine Order/Stay Home Notice (applicable to students staying in hostel’s twin-sharing room)

 

Do refer to the attached list of scenarios where students will apply for Leave of Absence via MyPortal.

 

When you are not able to attend classes due to the above or medical reasons, please do:

*         inform your faculty of your absence

*         submit your leave of absence via MyPorta <https://myportal.sutd.edu.sg/psp/EPPRD/?cmd=login&languageCd=ENG> l> NavBar> Navigator> Self Service> Leave/Withdrawal Request> Leave of Absence Application.

 

(II) When you are on campus

 

1)    Masks must be worn at all times except when you are eating or drinking.

2)    Please check-in at Campus Centre or Lobby F for temperature screening and completion of TraceTogether-only SafeEntry at least 20 minutes before the scheduled class time. For those who are driving or riding in, you will check-in at Entrance C (2nd vehicular entrance along Changi South Ave 1).



 

3)    The start and end time of each class must be strictly adhered to.  If you are unwell with dry cough, fever and tiredness, do not come to class but visit the Public Health Preparedness Clinic (PHPC).

4)    You are required to do your online temperature and daily health and contact declaration via the Temperature and Travel Declaration System at https://tts.sutd.edu.sg <https://tts.sutd.edu.sg> .

5)    You will only be allowed on campus on the days when you are scheduled for classes and/or related academic activities.  The security will have the class list for verification.

 

(III) Teaching venues

 

1)       You can only be on campus for the duration of the class instructions and related academic activities. 

2)    Venues designated for teaching will have the requisite social distancing measures in place.

3)    The university would need to keep records of students’ seating arrangements (e.g. Faculty taking photos at the start/end of sessions) to allow affected students to be identified quickly in the event of a confirmed case and for subsequent contact tracing.

4)    Once the class instructions and related academic activities are over for the day, please do not loiter around the classroom. For those who are hostel residents, please return to the hostel; for the rest, please leave campus as soon as possible.

5)    Please observe personal and environmental hygiene with regular hand washing.

 

(IV) Consumption of food

1)    Food must be consumed at the allocated seats in the designated refreshment area only (cordoned off area at the canteen). Individuals are not allowed to have any social interactions while eating, mask up immediately after eating, and leave the designated refreshment area after finishing your meals.

2)    Please clear your table after the meal.

 

As these measures are to ensure the safety and wellbeing of everyone, compliance is mandatory.  Disciplinary actions will be taken against the student(s) for any violation.

 

 

Best regards,

Office of Student Administration

Subject: Weekly Discovery: Brain Connectivity Can Build Better AI, A Dissolvable Smartwatch Makes For Easier Electronics Recycling & More 9 – 13 August 2021
Body:
Weekly Discovery
We SHARE to inspire and ignite ideas! 

 

9 – 13 August 2021

 

 

The Library publishes 9 alerts focusing on Topics relevant to growth and research areas to SUTD. 

 

Stay up to date by subscribing to any of these 9 Topical Reports - CLICK HERE TO SUBSCRIBE NOW <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.office.com%2FPages%2FResponsePage.aspx%3Fid%3Ddrd2NJDpck-5UGJImDFiPY4N9Bppv-lDrynkQwwfyzxUQUxVOTQxUkwzRTJTMVQ1WjU2OFZRQkdPQi4u&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C8210fad29f234c46494f08d95e20b762%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637644317068254563%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=Jsxn%2BLkPrFZUM65nJXiUzvuj7iGhjx87fXT2kzc6AA8%3D&reserved=0> 

 <https://mylibrary.sutd.edu.sg/node/1489> 

 

AI

Brain Connectivity Can Build Better AI <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.mcgill.ca%2Fnewsroom%2Fchannels%2Fnews%2Fbrain-connectivity-can-build-better-ai-332268&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C8210fad29f234c46494f08d95e20b762%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637644317068264556%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=R8uuuLZFFl4tTf42qietVjYd9qECVEtsYITYoPUX3Cs%3D&reserved=0> 

 

BIOTECH

Bio-inspired, Blood-Repelling Tissue Glue Could Seal Wounds Quickly <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fnews.mit.edu%2F2021%2Fbarnacle-glue-wound-seal-0809&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C8210fad29f234c46494f08d95e20b762%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637644317068274553%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=g8ZAe2UTw17TD7DGpSFfMLS1dYjRPv%2F2Rng2%2BTp5zcE%3D&reserved=0> 

 

BUILDING 

Slam The Door Shut: Improving Building Energy By Evaluating Building Airflow <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.eurekalert.org%2Fnews-releases%2F924877&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C8210fad29f234c46494f08d95e20b762%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637644317068274553%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=Q50UHoWdBY4b1%2B1CI4cIZuHChgbkYwc4uqrxel6Aegc%3D&reserved=0> 

 

COVID 19

Biosensor Permits Ultra-Fast And Cheap Detection Of SARS-Cov-2 <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.eurekalert.org%2Fnews-releases%2F925003&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C8210fad29f234c46494f08d95e20b762%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637644317068284551%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=WvYx%2FfYwCjtNBhtKKoYwd0FJVs80RKEdN8CxMhGPRM8%3D&reserved=0> 









“A new study shows that artificial intelligence networks based on human brain connectivity can perform cognitive tasks efficiently.”

“Inspired by the sticky substance that barnacles use to cling to rocks, MIT engineers have designed a strong, biocompatible glue that can seal injured tissues and stop bleeding.”

“Scientists identify the contribution of air leakage pathways such as building envelopes and residential entrance doors to heating energy demands in multi-family high-rise buildings.”

“The result of the analysis can be ready in 30 minutes, for a laboratory-scale cost of less than 1 US Dollar per genosensor. The components of the impedance analyzer, a durable part of the device, cost less than USD 200. The device already exists at the laboratory scale, and the technology can be transferred to any company with the wherewithal to mass-produce it.”

Source: MCGill <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.mcgill.ca%2Fnewsroom%2Fchannels%2Fnews%2Fbrain-connectivity-can-build-better-ai-332268&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C8210fad29f234c46494f08d95e20b762%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637644317068284551%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=%2BO794hkZ9D%2FYezdvVtbYduuD5OV6a3bPYMmd35251xg%3D&reserved=0>  (9 August 2021)

They demonstrated the circuits in a prototype transient device — a functional smartwatch that dissolved within 40 hours.”

“A new approach to producing metamaterials draws on kirigami techniques to make three-dimensional, reconfigurable building blocks that can be used to create complex, dynamic structures. Because the design approach is modular, these structures are easy to both assemble and disassemble.”

Led by Zahra Fakhraai at the University of Pennsylvania, the researchers used an intense X-ray source to reveal extremely dense, highly stable structures within the films, which transitioned to more conventional bulk liquids above a certain temperature.”
