Subject: Summary of coverage: Highlights of SUTD
Body:
Hi All,

 

Here’s the news coverage: 

 

-          Nanowerk did a special highlight on a ground-breaking modelling toolkit that can predict current of new type of memory. This research was led by SMT Assistant Prof Desmond Loke and his team.

-          Straits Times reported that SUTD president, Prof Chong Tow Chong, is a recipient of this year’s Public Administration Medal (Gold). This was announced during National Day.

-          Straits Times wrote multiple articles on how the Singapore team did in the Olympics, which included quotes from ASD student and Olympian Jonathan Chan. The second article was a feature on his experience juggling life, school and sports.

-          Channel NewsAsia published an article on the growing polarisation of online discourse in Singapore that included a quote from HASS head, Prof Lim Sun Sun.

-          Straits Times takes a look at whether national symbols can better rally Singaporeans. The article included a quote from SUTD freshmore student Syarifuddin Azhar Rosli, who is also a member of the Citizens' Workgroup for National Symbols.

________________________________

 

Nanowerk, 11 Aug 2021, A ground-breaking modeling toolkit to predict current of new type of memory (https://www.nanowerk.com/spotlight/spotid=58605.php <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nanowerk.com%2Fspotlight%2Fspotid%3D58605.php&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7Cb761604df5724ae5ca0508d95e1a77be%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637644290186416912%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=KKdvV2FlGl5cNO0Nse5jwXxqI%2BDx6mgBeds3KxLH5gQ%3D&reserved=0> )

 

Resistive-switching memory (RSM) is an emerging candidate for next-generation memory and computing devices, such as storage-class memory devices, multilevel memories and as a synapse in neuromorphic computing.

 

RSM devices have gained significant attention due to their simple metal-insulator-metal (MIM) structure, which composes a dielectric material sandwiched between the top electrode (TE) and bottom electrode (BE).

RSM operation is based on resistive switching, which is generally known as set process if the device switches from high resistance state (HRS) to low resistance state (LRS) and reset process if the device switches from LRS to HRS.

 

Such processes depend on the amplitude and polarity of applied voltage in the unipolar and bipolar-switching modes, respectively. Applying a voltage between the TE and BE leads to the formation of nanoscale conduction filament (CF) in set process and the rupture of CF in reset process.

 

The formation of CF in RSM devices is typically based on electrochemical metallization (ECM) effect, valence-change memory (VCM) effect, thermochemical memory (TCM) effect and other effects. Aluminum-nitride-based RSM device exhibits bipolar switching. The growth of CF is governed by VCM effect and CF is formed by nitrogen-vacancies.

 

Traditional physical-based models based on CF growth are generally used to model the RSM device characteristics. Conventional physical-based models consider various assumptions such as the shape, growth direction and temperature distribution of CF to describe the switching behaviour of RSM devices.

 

However, the assumptions could also lead to less reliable, less accurate and too device-centric models to describe the switching behaviour. Therefore, it is essential to model CF growth of RSM devices using new methodologies to accurately model the switching behaviour.

 

In this report (AIP Advances, "Modeling electrical conduction in resistive-switching memory through machine learning"), we present an alternative ML approach in which we avoid the need to solve traditional physical-based equations by directly learning the relationship between other-device-parameters to compute the CF-related compliance current (CC) value i.e., we establish a ML-CO model.

 

We show that this relationship can be learned via a data-driven approach and with excellent accuracy for many different samples to describe CF growth. Furthermore, we show that it can immediately be applied to real-device sampling by computing the CC value of RSM devices with just a few device parameters.

 

Moreover, as we have already implemented the approach with common aluminum-nitride-based RSM devices and verified the developed ML models on SiOx and TiO2 RSM devices, this can now be performed on a much wider range of RSM devices.

 

We have achieved three significant results in this work:

*         Notably, we sidestep the accuracy issues by directly learning the CC and other-device-parameters relationship via a data-driven approach and with high accuracy for various types of devices.

*         We demonstrate, for the first time, ML modelling of CF-growth behaviour of RSM devices using general machine-learning (ML) algorithms, e.g., neural-network-based multi-layer-perceptron (MLP) algorithm, and bootstrap-aggregating-based random-forest (RF) algorithm.

*         ML-CO models were evaluated using the mean-square error (MSE) value and a comparative analysis revealed that RF algorithm tends to perform better than MLP algorithm for CF growth modeling. The MSE value of RF algorithm is ∼0.0014, which is about an order of magnitude lower than a compact-physical-based-modelling MSE baseline of 0.0142.

 

By applying ML algorithms to learn the relationship between other-device-parameter values to compute the CC value, the proposed ML-CO model allows accurate prediction of CF growth to describe the switching behaviour. The data-driven ML approach can also be implemented and performed on a much wider range of RSM devices.

 

Additionally, achieving an appropriate CC value in a dynamic manner using AI-engine plugin could pave the way for programmable memory applications, e.g., in-memory computing. And this work would be of significant interest to the research community, including material scientists, electronic engineers, device manufacturers and computer designers, as a tool for discovery of new RSM materials and rapid screening of nanomaterials suitable for RSM, which could drive RSM commercialization.

 

Source: Provided by Singapore University of Technology and Design as a nanowerk exclusive

 

 

Straits Times, 9 Aug 2021, Public Administration Medal (Gold) (https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/public-administration-medal-gold <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.straitstimes.com%2Fsingapore%2Fpublic-administration-medal-gold&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7Cb761604df5724ae5ca0508d95e1a77be%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637644290186426913%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=Jkq3pIUJQRUqJjoXO%2F1F7o6OoCCRmWZhxkqhKfNmmwk%3D&reserved=0> )

 

PROFESSOR CHONG TOW CHONG

President, Singapore University of Technology and Design (SUTD)

 

Professor Chong Tow Chong, 67, has walked every step of SUTD's journey, from fledgling institution with no faculty to one embarking on its next phase of growth supported by artificial intelligence and data science.

 

He is especially proud of setting it up from scratch in 2009, with first-of-its-kind interdisciplinary education and research, and a strong focus on design. Today, it has over 1,000 partnerships with various agencies, and a host of internships and exchange programmes for students.

 

There are "good employment prospects and strong demand" for them, he says, noting that they have been snapped up by employers such as the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore, Dyson, Citi, IBM and the Ministry of Defence.

 

"I want to thank my team of SUTD colleagues who have worked hard with me to build the university from scratch. This award would never have been possible without their relentless effort and commitment," he said, adding that the board of trustees and Ministry of Education have provided support and guidance.

 

He previously led A*Star's Science and Engineering Research Council and Data Storage Institute. He has been SUTD president since April 2018, and was its founding Provost from 2010 to 2018.

 

 

Straits Times, 8 Aug 2021, Olympics: Passion is not always enough for sustained appearances at sport's top table (https://www.straitstimes.com/sport/olympics-passion-is-not-always-enough-for-sustained-appearances-at-sports-top-table <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.straitstimes.com%2Fsport%2Folympics-passion-is-not-always-enough-for-sustained-appearances-at-sports-top-table&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7Cb761604df5724ae5ca0508d95e1a77be%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637644290186436902%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=3dVoREskQikXmTCFhpf3Y8r99zpQZikt66m2xTcA63c%3D&reserved=0> )

 

For some in the Team Singapore contingent at the Olympic Games, scoresheets will soon be traded for resumes and mundane water cooler chats in the office could replace fiery pep talks by coaches.

 

The sun is setting on the Games here and with it, the elite-level sporting pursuits of some Singaporeans in the Japanese capital.

 

The Republic was represented by 23 athletes - 17 of whom are debutants - across a record 12 sports at these Olympics.

 

And while this diversity has been lauded, a handful of these athletes have already stated that Tokyo 2020 would represent their final involvement at the Olympics, with academic or job pursuits being their main reasons for calling time.

 

This is not new. Since the Sydney Games in 2000, Singapore has sent 89 different athletes to sport's top competition. Less than a third of them - 26 - have been to multiple Olympics.

 

At Saturday's (Aug 7) campaign review, Singapore Sport Institute (SSI) chief Toh Boon Yi said addressing this attrition and extending the longevity of elite athletes is high on the agenda.

 

"There's a lot of learning that goes on, and those lessons should ideally not go away after one cycle," he said. "You have to campaign for multiple cycles in order to do well, because experience (at the Games) really counts."

 

This, said chef de mission Ben Tan, requires a "maturing" of the sports eco-system and culture in Singapore, where young adults are expected to concentrate on academia and forging a career.

 

Singapore National Olympic Council (SNOC) secretary-general Chris Chan said the attrition rate will remain until athletes are assured "bread and butter" issues are unaffected by the Olympic pursuit.

 

Jonathan Chan, 24, who is the first Singaporean male diver to compete at the Olympics, is one of those ready to throw in the towel.

 

He has spent more than half his life juggling sport with schoolwork or national service, and even had to work on his final-year project in the Olympic Village in the days leading up to his event.

 

The final-year architecture major at the Singapore University of Technology and Design said: "People think just because we reach this level that we are full-time athletes. But in reality we are just stretched like crazy… Where can sport take us if we don't have school or a job?"

 

The SSI, stressed Toh, has several support schemes in place to support national athletes.

 

Of the 23 in Tokyo, 13 are spexScholars who receive a monthly stipend of between $1,800 and $8,400, with Olympic-level athletes in the highest tier. Almost 70 scholars are working towards Paris 2024, said Toh.

 

But the scheme does not cover all athletes.

 

Non-scholars, for example, get carded funding which might amount to "a few hundred" a month, which can be wiped out with just one sports massage or chiropractor session per week, one Olympian told The Sunday Times.

 

A host of companies have also joined the spexBusiness network, which was set up as an avenue for national athletes to get career development support such as employment opportunities.

 

Toh noted that a significant mindset shift is still needed as the eco-system does not comprise just the SNOC and SSI.

 

"People's attitudes need to change, whether they are parents, the individual athletes themselves, employers, or the general public," he said.

 

Deloitte South-east Asia, part of the spexBusiness network, has hired over 110 athletes since 2014, including windsurfer Amanda Ng, who competed in the RS:X event.

 

Its sports business group leader James Walton said he has had only positives from his experiences with athletes-turned-colleagues, observing they tend to be driven and adept at thinking on their feet when solving problems.

 

Still, there are challenges, for example, managing the expectations of an athlete joining the workforce at a later stage than his peers. Walton recounted one instance where an athlete was hired at 32 years old, having graduated from university nine years before.

 

"Effectively they were a fresh grad… so are they OK with the fact that is their (entry) level? You can't bring them in at an eight-or nine-year level, which is a manager level, when they have no actual work experience," he said.

 

"It's a question of mentality, the psychology of the person and… how they deal with that."

 

Fortunately, parents of athletes, while concerned for their children's future, are beginning to understand what such pursuits mean to them.

 

Abdul Rahman, 56, the father of epee fencer Kiria Tikanah, said he would not disapprove if she wanted to aim to qualify for Paris 2024, even if she delays pursuing specialisation or getting a job after she completes her degree.

 

Kiria, 21, is a second-year chemistry student at the National University of Singapore (NUS).

 

"Through my own experience I know how it felt when my classmates found a job and I hadn't, and what more during this difficult time (of the pandemic)," said the former chief operating officer of a financial institution, who now does consulting work.

 

"But as long as she is happy and that is what she wants to do, I will support her. As a parent, watching her on the world stage in Tokyo also made me very proud."

 

Some feel tertiary institutions can play a big role in aiding the athletes.

 

Diver Freida Lim, 23, said her experience in the United States was vital in her making it to Tokyo. She graduated from the University of Georgia in May with a double degree in dietetics, and culinary science and nutrition, and praised the support she got as an National Collegiate Athletic Association student-athlete.

 

If her grades slipped, an academic adviser would call offering to schedule a tutor to help arrest the slide. When diving meets clashed with classes or papers, exemption forms were at the ready. And when she was not able to attend class, note takers were on hand to keep her clued in.

 

"In the US, I worked hard and did well and my sports (career) improved as well," she said. "If I had stayed in Singapore... I would have still worked hard and still not have done well."

 

Former national swimmer Mark Chay, a Nominated Member of Parliament who competed at the Sydney and Athens Games, said: "Our universities need to take a hard look at themselves and what their philosophies of education are.

 

"Is it just a narrow one, where you develop the individual only in the confines of a classroom? Or do they count the development outside of it, for a more holistic (philosophy)?

 

"We should see sports, and arts for that matter, as co-curricular, not extra curricular."

 

Marathon swimmer Chantal Liew, a communications and new media undergraduate at NUS, said the higher education system is "inadequate" in supporting sporting pursuits. But while she had intended to quit after Tokyo, she is weighing the idea of pressing on.

 

Liew, 22, said: "The culture we have sometimes makes you feel like an athlete's career path is worthless. With everything against me doing sport, and me entertaining thoughts of wanting to continue, I must really love it."

 

Chay agreed, noting that the individual athlete's drive is most crucial. With the standard of the Olympics today so high, it would require a sustained commitment level of a professional for an individual to be in the frame for repeat appearances at the Games.

 

Only the athlete can decide if he or she is willing to take the steps and sacrifices such as securing financial backing through sponsors or even crowdfunding, needed to get there. Rower Joan Poh, a nurse at Tan Tock Seng Hospital, who was also in Tokyo, is a familiar tale.

 

"The reality today is that the Olympics are the pinnacle of sports, with the best athletes. And if the best are seeing it as a career... then you have to do that to," he said.

 

 

Straits Times, 7 Aug 2021, Chan's fine balancing act (https://www.straitstimes.com/sport/chans-fine-balancing-act <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.straitstimes.com%2Fsport%2Fchans-fine-balancing-act&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7Cb761604df5724ae5ca0508d95e1a77be%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637644290186436902%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=DmoYElYkWOucw91OcGstaV9qM1Dw5tp2nmn%2FMKyrsLQ%3D&reserved=0> )

 

A weight was lifted off diver Jonathan Chan's shoulders yesterday.

 

Not only because he executed his dives "to expectation" in the men's 10m platform preliminary round at the Olympics, becoming the first Singapore man in his sport to do so.

 

But also because earlier that day, his Final Year Project (FYP) concluded with a presentation that his group mates graciously agreed he could skip.

 

"Earlier they texted me that our presentation went well, and they said jiayou (good luck in Mandarin) for later," he said in the media mixed zone after his dives.

 

The 24-year-old scored 311.15 over six dives at the Tokyo Aquatics Centre, finishing 26th in the field of 29.

 

This meant that he did not qualify for today's semi-finals.

 

China's Yang Jian led the semi-finalists with 546.90, while 18th-placed Kim Yeong-taek from South Korea took the last spot with 366.80 points.

 

On his performance, Chan said his first five dives "could have gone better" but added that they were not out of the ordinary from what he had been executing in training.

 

"So it was within expectations. I'm quite satisfied with it," he said.

 

The final-year architecture major at the Singapore University of Technology and Design also revealed that he even did some of his FYP work at the Singapore National Olympic Council's office in the Olympic Village - where athletes and officials reside - in the days leading up to his competition.

 

This act of balancing sport with academics - and also national service - is why he felt relief after everything was said and done yesterday.

 

"It's been quite a long journey with both school, Covid-19 and training over the past two years, especially with the (one-year postponement of the Olympics)," he explained.

 

"I think now, other than finishing my finals, I'm ready for a good break before I decide on anything else."

 

It is also why Chan, who was the first Singaporean to qualify for the Tokyo Games in September 2019, is ready to quit the sport for good.

 

He added, however, that he would use his post-Olympics rest period to seek "a clearer picture" on his next step.

 

Asked why he wanted to leave sport, he said: "It (the whole diving career) has been too long… It's been non-stop school, training, army, training…

 

"I didn't have a 'break' break where I could decide if I wanted to continue or not. For this break, I will."

 

Chan was the last member of the 23-strong Team Singapore contingent - spread across a record 12 sports - in Tokyo to compete.

 

On Wednesday, teammate Freida Lim contested the women's 10m platform preliminary round as the Republic's first diver to compete at the Games.

 

 

Channel NewsAsia, 7 Aug 2021, IN FOCUS: ‘Boomer, snowflake, oppie, pappie’ - unpacking the growing social media polarisation in Singapore (https://www.channelnewsasia.com/singapore/in-focus-social-media-polarisation-singapore-online-discourse-2085511 <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.channelnewsasia.com%2Fsingapore%2Fin-focus-social-media-polarisation-singapore-online-discourse-2085511&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7Cb761604df5724ae5ca0508d95e1a77be%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637644290186446897%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=zqmpiQK%2B8R%2Bxtj7pMBghof2YsXHQYVXYhqyBeI%2Bny2w%3D&reserved=0> )

 

SINGAPORE: To concoct a typical example of social media discourse in Singapore, start with the key ingredient - a thorny issue. 

 

Think racism, immigration, gender equality, meritocracy or, in more recent times, getting vaccinated. 

 

Sometimes, it could be something that might seem a little less heavy, such as whether the McDonald’s BTS meal or Michelin-starred hawker food is overrated. 

 

What begins as an exchange of views quickly morphs into a minefield of sarcasm and snark, with comebacks punctuated with Internet slang, perhaps to generate "likes" and retweets or to simply stir the controversy. 

 

“The reason why I don't vote oppies.” 

 

“This is so tone-deaf. Check your privilege, boomer.” 

 

In June, the People's Action Party's (PAP) Amrin Amin said on his Facebook page, in response to a commenter, “Don’t take offence too easily, snowflake.” 

 

The commenter had said that even though Mr Amrin didn’t think the People’s Association (PA) misusing a Malay couple’s wedding photo for a Hari Raya standee was racist, it didn’t mean other minorities agreed with him. 

 

Mr Amrin’s "snowflake" comment drew flak. One commenter replied, “See la what you have done. Bongok", using a term that implies someone is stupid or dumb.

 

Replying to the "bongok" comment, another commenter defended Mr Amrin: “Why a personal attack? Are you even from Singapore? Your page has not much information about yourself and your last check-in is in Yangon, Myanmar??”

 

Several comments down, no one was discussing the original incident anymore.

 

Such a turn in discussion, with polarised views and insults being hurled, is not uncommon in Singapore. It is also a situation that some people perceive to be getting worse. 

 

According to a YouGov survey conducted for CNA among 1,055 respondents, 64 per cent indicated that they have observed increased polarisation of views online in Singapore in the last five years. 

 

The survey defined polarisation of views as people who hold differing opinions becoming divided into contrasting groups based on these views, where the views they hold drive these groups further apart over time, such as through personal attacks towards each other.

 

The same survey showed that 27 per cent of respondents had become involved in personal attacks - on the giving end, receiving end, or both - when trying to argue an issue online. 

 

Speaking to CNA over Zoom, MP Tin Pei Ling (PAP-MacPherson), who is also the chairperson of the Government Parliamentary Committee on Communications and Information, said that she has seen a rise in polarising views online. 

 

“I see some beginning of that phenomenon where you have groups of people on the same issue, but at very far ends of the spectrum. Each side comments with a certain conviction, and some even have a personal anecdote that they share to enrich the story or their position,” she said. 

 

Referring to recent racist incidents as an example of what triggers polarising responses, Ms Tin said getting upset over “brazen behaviour” is “a good sign”. But excessively polarising responses can “chip away” at Singapore’s model of a multicultural, multiracial society. 

 

“The thing is, these subtle changes over time - you don’t notice it on a day-to-day basis, but one day when you reach the tipping point, you realise, my gosh, there’s so much misunderstanding and such deep-seated emotions and undercurrent, it might be too difficult to address,” she said.

 

WHAT DRIVES POLARISATION?

The growing level of education in Singapore is one factor that has resulted in “more overt and pronounced” polarisation, shared Lim Sun Sun, Professor of Communication and Technology at the Singapore University of Technology and Design (SUTD). 

 

“People are more exposed to different viewpoints from around the world. People have also gotten more comfortable with asserting their opinions on social media platforms. This convergence of multiple factors has actually led to greater expression of political views in the online space.” 

 

And while some may assume that age is an important factor in influencing people’s viewpoints, Prof Lim argued that this is a reductionist perspective. 

 

“Many people in the boomer category (people born in the 1950s and 60s) are very liberal, just like there are young people who have very right-wing, conservative viewpoints, possibly because of religious beliefs. The more meaningful variable to think about would be education.”

 

MODERATE VIEWS LACKING, IN-FIGHTING A CONCERN

Respondents in the YouGov survey were also asked to name public personalities or platforms in Singapore that they felt encouraged polarised views. 

 

The top two individuals identified were former Nominated MP Calvin Cheng and blogger Wendy Cheng (better known as Xiaxue), while the most mentioned online platforms were The Online Citizen and Wake Up, Singapore. 

 

One of Mr Cheng’s recent Facebook posts that drew polarising comments was written after the PA incident that had evoked Mr Amrin’s "snowflake" response. He said: “Extremists in Singapore want Chinese people to feel guilty about being Chinese, because they have ‘Chinese privilege’. This is an extreme ideology imported from America.”

 

One commenter supported Mr Cheng: “Certain minorities are tactically playing the ‘victim’.” 

 

A couple of commenters asked him to explain his “flippant and incendiary” comment, while another suggested that he “try being a minority first then understand what they go through”. 

 

In response to such retorts, another commenter jumped in with a defence: “People like Snowflake Sarah who like to play victim and clearly want to link everything to racism. PA, vendor, MP all already apologised for that culturally insensitive and stupid mistake yet she just wants to stir and stir to cause more hatred and conflict.”

 

As for Ms Wendy Cheng (Xiaxue), the social media influencer’s own allegedly racist posts were dug up when she said on Instagram that MP Raeesah Khan (WP-Sengkang) was stirring racist sentiment in the run-up to the 2020 General Election. 

 

When Ms Cheng was dropped from a show she had been slated to host on Clicknetwork as a result, Clicknetwork’s Facebook statement drew polarising views. Some commenters supported the move against “racism, bigotry and hate”, others expressed disappointment that a long-standing relationship could be discarded so easily.  

 

Certain topics also tend to result in greater polarisation, such as politics, race and even lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender (LGBT) issues, noted Prof Lim.

 

“Essentially, communities that have been marginalised, that have felt that they are less than fairly represented by the mainstream media, would seek alternative platforms to project their views. And that's when the complications of the public space will result in different kinds of viewpoints being aired,” she said. 

 

“Moderation seems so hard to find on both sides,” shared Facebook user Gary Yeo over the phone with CNA.

 

The 43-year-old, who considers himself more pro-establishment, noted “some common areas” between groups on both ends of the spectrum. People typically share opinions in a closed environment and both sides are echo chambers, with similar viewpoints being made.

 

However, irrespective of whether he has articulated opinions which might be seen as pro- or anti-establishment, the online reaction has often been emotional. 

 

“I used to think the opposition had a lot of anger. Essentially when you disagree with them, they will shut you down and try to silence you. And I thought the pro-establishment side was better. Like maybe they’re less harsh and use less insults,” he said. 

 

“But when I once disagreed with the Government’s views - for example, when I felt that ‘race’ should be taken out of the NRIC - (someone in the pro-establishment group) tried to silence me, even though it was just a minor disagreement.” 

 

But similar attacks were thrown at Mr Yeo when he sided with pro-establishment perspectives. Some opposition supporters would “outright argue or insult” him. They have also suggested he is a member of what has been described as the People’s Action Party’s Internet Brigade (PAP IB), a group of people believed by some to be ready to jump online to fight the ruling party’s corner.

 

“Saying ‘PAP IB’ is the most common and fastest insult. The moment you disagree, you become a PAP IB. I mean, I'm not even a PAP member or involved in grassroots. They also insult you by calling you stupid,” he said. 

 

And polarising views aren’t just hurled across the aisle. In-fighting also occurs among people supposedly from the same camp.

 

“It’s not so much ‘in-fighting’ as it is just different opinions being put on the table. That’s just an inevitable consequence of the fact that, regardless of which side of the political spectrum you’re on, there’s bound to be disagreements on the specificities of certain socio-political issues,” explained Mr Paul Jerusalem, a 27-year-old researcher pursuing a masters in communication and new media at a local university. 

 

Sometimes, this friction might be due to “identity politics”, he added. 

 

Mr Jerusalem, who is a known social media figure among the younger "left-leaning" online crowd, recounted an incident where a Singaporean mainstream media journalist “momentarily fell out of favour” with some people on Twitter. She had expressed a view that, while not in opposition to theirs, was misconstrued as such, even though her old tweets would have suggested she held “similar political sympathies” to them. 

 

“I think the fact that she has (her publication’s name) on her handle leads people to make certain assumptions about her, in addition to other visible identity markers such as race,” said Mr Jerusalem, whose research areas of interest include online discourse and cultural studies.

 

Making snap judgments out of convenience about someone’s position on an issue by looking at visible identity markers, such as their gender, age or race, is part of identity politics, he explained.

 

“When people talk about identity politics, a lot of it is fear mongering and bogeyman politics. But I think there are instances where assumptions are made based on apparent indicators of your positionality; not everyone is going to dig into the history of what you’ve said and come to nuanced conclusions on where you stand,” he added.

 

ONLINE SLANG: HELP OR HINDRANCE?  

Any social media user knows snap judgements are often effectively expressed through online slang, but language can also hinder communication. 

 

“Language, including slang and colloquial terms, add to discrimination and polarising views. But this is neither new nor precisely a social media phenomenon,” observed Assistant Professor Saifuddin Ahmed from Nanyang Technological University’s Wee Kim Wee School of Information and Communication. 

 

He added that slang can signal “alienation”, implying one group is more “in the know” than others, which can worsen social relations between groups.

 

What social media does, he noted, is broadcast such language to a broader audience, “aggravating the alienation of out-group members”. 

 

Moreover, different groups of people might have different assumptions around a particular term, leading to misunderstanding, said Prof Lim. 

 

“A lot o

Subject: MPA 2021 Mid Term Scholarship
Body:
Dear students,

 

Please note MPA offers undergraduate scholarships and the application is now open for the mid-term cycle for current undergraduate students. MPA would like to specially invite current SUTD students who aspire to be part of the maritime sector to apply.

 

Please click on the link here <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fbrightsparks.com.sg%2Fprofile%2Fmpa%2Fmpa-scholarship-programme.php%3Fschid%3D9281&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7Cbf5acf2930c24520629e08d95e07bac3%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637644210445171589%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=eX3sdXDpLlof9yUJmej0Nebci%2ByUIuTF8E8%2FdXgafnI%3D&reserved=0>  for full details of the scholarship programme.

 

Deadline: 31st Aug 2021, Tuesday

 



 

 

For enquiries, please email to:

 

Geraldine – geraldine_goh@mpa.gov.sg <mailto:geraldine_goh@mpa.gov.sg> 

Min Hui – Ang_Min_Hui@mpa.gov.sg <mailto:Ang_Min_Hui@mpa.gov.sg> 

 

 

Thank you.

 

 

Regards,

Office of Student Administration

Subject: Student Monthly Season Parking (September 21 to December 21)
Body:
Dear students,

 

Please be informed that the registration of student season parking for the next term (September 2021 – December 2021) is now open, kindly register by 23rd August 2021. 

 

Application may be subjected to balloting exercise if applications exceed available quota.

All successful/unsuccessful applications will be notified via email. 

 

Please note the following admin instructions for the respective parking schemes.

 

1.       Monthly Season Parking Scheme at $260.00 (after GST) for 4 months

 

*         Please click on the link below and fill up the application form. 

https://forms.office.com/Pages/ResponsePage.aspx?id=drd2NJDpck-5UGJImDFiPQP4FF0lAM5Ol0GGlZwlwH1UREEwRkMyUDFaVTNIVFlFRzIzTlpOQVpXSi4u <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.office.com%2FPages%2FResponsePage.aspx%3Fid%3Ddrd2NJDpck-5UGJImDFiPQP4FF0lAM5Ol0GGlZwlwH1UREEwRkMyUDFaVTNIVFlFRzIzTlpOQVpXSi4u&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C9dc5c0c380124d37bba108d95e04804f%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637644195921776593%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=P5SsCuC2CE7qtnTxHGn2UtawBgULf6%2BUynakZOVjKWs%3D&reserved=0> 

*         Student Monthly Season Parking is sold in blocks of 4 months only, following the academic calendar, refer to email subject title for current block period.   

*         Student will be notified on the status of his/her application via email after the deadline. 

*         Upon receiving notification, he/she will be required to make a payment of $260.00 at the carpark office by NETS/Paynow/Paylah before collecting the new season parking ticket. 

*         Application for Student Season Parking Ticket is on a semester basis and is subjected to a balloting exercise when applications for season parking are oversubscribed. Receipt of advance payment of student Season Parking Ticket beyond each approved period is not tacit approval of student Season Parking Ticket for the next period.

 

2.       Casual Parking Scheme, Daily Capped Rate of $5.00 (before GST)

 

*         Existing casual parking holders need not reapply. 

*         Please click on the link below and fill up the application form. 

https://forms.office.com/Pages/ResponsePage.aspx?id=drd2NJDpck-5UGJImDFiPQP4FF0lAM5Ol0GGlZwlwH1UREEwRkMyUDFaVTNIVFlFRzIzTlpOQVpXSi4u <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.office.com%2FPages%2FResponsePage.aspx%3Fid%3Ddrd2NJDpck-5UGJImDFiPQP4FF0lAM5Ol0GGlZwlwH1UREEwRkMyUDFaVTNIVFlFRzIzTlpOQVpXSi4u&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C9dc5c0c380124d37bba108d95e04804f%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637644195921786589%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=H0QlwlrOJjQpV76XPb5a9rQg8tvfp4%2FRx6KpbIkKjfo%3D&reserved=0> 

*         No approval is required. 

*         Student is required to email to SUTD-Wilson@wilsonparking.com.sg <mailto:SUTD-Wilson@wilsonparking.com.sg>  after registration. 

*         Processing may take up to 3 working days.  

 

3.    Motorcycle Season Parking at $15.00 (after GST) per month

 

*         Existing motorcycle season parking holders need not reapply. 

*         Please click on the link below and fill up the application form. 

https://forms.office.com/Pages/ResponsePage.aspx?id=drd2NJDpck-5UGJImDFiPQP4FF0lAM5Ol0GGlZwlwH1UNDBVUU5CMjNVVzlYVjY2RDVXRkNZUzBMWC4u <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.office.com%2FPages%2FResponsePage.aspx%3Fid%3Ddrd2NJDpck-5UGJImDFiPQP4FF0lAM5Ol0GGlZwlwH1UNDBVUU5CMjNVVzlYVjY2RDVXRkNZUzBMWC4u&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C9dc5c0c380124d37bba108d95e04804f%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637644195921796576%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=HkIdge6bSeFjLURRkxl%2BWdg06xdsN7gLQdZuOTaFJqI%3D&reserved=0> 

*         Student is required to email to SUTD-Wilson@wilsonparking.com.sg <mailto:SUTD-Wilson@wilsonparking.com.sg>  after registration. 

*         Motorcycle season parking may be subjected to balloting exercise when applications are oversubscribed. 

*         Payment of $15 to be made at the carpark office by NETS/Paynow/Paylah. 

 

Carpark Office Operating Hours:

Monday to Friday, 9am to 5pm

Saturday, 9am to 12pm

Close on Sunday and Public Holiday

 

Things to note for all students applying for season parking:

 

1.      Season Parking is strictly for parking of vehicles in the designated car park, it is not transferable nor refundable, and must not be used for any other commercial purposes.

2.      Student Monthly Season Ticket Holders will not be allowed to park their vehicles in the sheltered lots in the basement car park and MPH car park on weekdays between 7.00am to 7.00pm.

3.      Student Monthly Season Ticket Holders will be charged visitor rate if their vehicles are parked in the basement car park on weekdays between 7.00am to 7.00pm.

4.    Student Monthly Season Parking area is restricted to the open lots next to Block 55 and is valid on weekdays between 7.00am to 7.00pm only.

5.      Student Casual Season will only be allowed to park in the white car park lots at the basement car park.

6.      The vehicle log card and identity card / Certificate of Incorporation / Business registration Certificate may be required to be produced for verification of the vehicle's ownership upon application.

7.      For student who previously registered online with us and wish to change options at this point of time, he/she will need to submit a new application via the link above.

8.    An administrative fee of $20 may be applicable for any change in season parking scheme. 

 

 

Regards,

 

Joel

Office of Campus Infrastructure and Facilities

Subject: <Call for Application> Fully sponsored TF-NUS LEaRN Youth Asian Leaders Initiative
Body:
Dear Student,

 

APPLICATION CLOSES ON 16 AUGUST 2021, APPLY NOW <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.office.com%2Fr%2FWsLup7FPNw&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7Cc6046a5322ea4792562d08d95dfcfdd7%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637644163689611154%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=oUWIrGeOGqWVc8BpgMkHKc%2Fu2W4rtG%2FZ%2B2lujFrluWs%3D&reserved=0> ! 

 

Be part of the inaugural TF-NUS LEaRN Youth Asian Leaders Initiative (YALI), a fully sponsored exclusive virtual programme by Temasek Foundation and National University of Singapore. Limited to only 10 slots for SUTD students. Refer to email below.

 

 

From: global@sutd.edu.sg 
Sent: Thursday, August 5, 2021 5:31 PM
Subject: <Call for Application> Fully sponsored TF-NUS LEaRN Youth Asian Leaders Initiative 

 

 

Dear Student,

 

 

We are excited to invite you to participate in the inaugural TF-NUS LEaRN Youth Asian Leaders Initiative (YALI), a fully sponsored exclusive virtual programme by Temasek Foundation and National University of Singapore. 

 

Be part of the distinguished network of 120 local NUS/NTU/SMU/SUTD and ASEAN student leaders to interact, discuss and engage in Internationalisation at Home, over 10 weekly online (Zoom) sessions between September to November 2021! 

 

Participants will receive exclusive TF-SUTD LEaRN gifts (tshirt, totebag, notebook, bottle etc), and a certificate of completion which will value add to your resume.

 

 

APPLY NOW <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.office.com%2Fr%2FWsLup7FPNw&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7Cc6046a5322ea4792562d08d95dfcfdd7%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637644163689611154%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=oUWIrGeOGqWVc8BpgMkHKc%2Fu2W4rtG%2FZ%2B2lujFrluWs%3D&reserved=0>  BY 16 AUGUST 2021!

 

 

 <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.office.com%2Fr%2FWsLup7FPNw&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7Cc6046a5322ea4792562d08d95dfcfdd7%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637644163689621148%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=aU7U58OfQ1UnvPk3LjYzlDbhvkzqp%2F1G1P%2B2rQNurbY%3D&reserved=0> 

 


Programme content:

 

*         Developing holistic resilience (physical, mental, social, and emotional), intrapersonal and intercultural skills and understanding

*         Preparing you for the future of work in Asia

*         Building necessary skills and mind sets to finding and securing employment

*         Interactive discussions for you to network with peers from the ASEAN region

*         Participants will enjoy full sponsorship of Programme fees 

 

Participants and mode of delivery:

 

*         120 participants (60 local NUS, NTU, SMU and SUTD students and 60 ASEAN students), only 10 slots for SUTD students

*         10 weekly online (Zoom) sessions between September to November 2021 

*         Full schedule and course outline as attached

 

Programme requirements:

 

*         Participants must join a programme-related Facebook group for networking purposes

*         Participants must submit an experience report of at least 500 words

*         Participants must achieve at least 80% attendance

*         If all is fulfilled, participants will receive a certificate of completion which will value add to your resume

 

Selection criteria:

*         Academic performance

*         Co-curricular records and community involvement

*         Successful applicants will be informed via email, where they will be guided on the next steps.

*         Any queries? Connect with us at global@sutd.edu.sg <mailto:global@sutd.edu.sg>  

 

 

APPLY NOW <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.office.com%2Fr%2FWsLup7FPNw&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7Cc6046a5322ea4792562d08d95dfcfdd7%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637644163689621148%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=aU7U58OfQ1UnvPk3LjYzlDbhvkzqp%2F1G1P%2B2rQNurbY%3D&reserved=0>  BY 16 AUGUST 2021!

 

 

Warmest Regards

 

Office of International Relations

Singapore University of Technology and Design (SUTD)

Junior Software Engineer (Java) 
Our APAC cross-border Emerging Engineers Academy (EEA) is a specially designed 3-month program that aims to identify, groom and catapult junior technologists into digital architects of the future through a comprehensive and structured methodology that focuses on innovation, collaboration and leveraging new technologies to deliver engineering excellence. 

They are now looking for young and energetic Java trainees to join our next intake for the EEA program in Singapore. Read more <https://www.epam.com/careers/blog/epams-inaugural-emerging-engineers-academy-program-in-singapore> 

 <https://www.epam.com/careers/job-listings/job.62365.junior-software-engineer-java_singapore_singapore>

Career Opportunities with iTrust
iTrust is looking to fill several positions in the area of machine learning and cyber-physical systems. Read more <https://itrust.sutd.edu.sg/join-us/research-positions/software-engineers/> 

Applicants who meet the qualifications indicated below may apply:

-	Bachelor’s degree in any field of engineering
-	Demonstrated proficiency in high level programming (Python preferred)
-	Good working knowledge of computer networks

 <mailto:nsoe_destsci@sutd.edu.sg>  

Seniors from CSD & EPD 


	


Recruitment Talks 



 

 

 

SLA Logistics Industry Webinar 
Gain insights into the logistics industry and its offerings in internship and full-time career opportunities. Read more <https://drive.google.com/file/d/1Bg6gLd-CfMoiz-tqiVLSVxnLKVlAA18B/view?usp=sharing> 

19 Aug 2021| 1230 – 1400hrs | Virtual Platform 

Register via this QR Code
 

 <https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSeL45mo1m6iEC8AqkwEvKP-P1mDZtPFwx_ySJ-kZ3yMOLuJEA/viewform>  

Apply by 13 August 2021

All students
Discover EY Parthenon (Consulting) 
Are you interested in bringing unconventional yet pragmatic thinking together to provide actionable strategies and create real business impact for clients? Find out more at this session. Read more <https://drive.google.com/file/d/1uNN_0Gwi1GXOeIcFJZVqs_na1W0J1ufU/view?usp=sharing> 

2 Sep 2021 | 1800 – 2000hrs |Virtual Platform 

Apply by 13 August 2021

 <https://forms.office.com/pages/responsepage.aspx?id=mT-XW99360uyfaoMcLhILPC4girup9tAqeN2KxzFIUtUQ0xFS0MxQzc3OFpNTklLVjBSVUIxTjdJUC4u>  
Juniors and Seniors from CSD & ESD 

Intelligent Decarbonisation
Recruitment Talk 
Do not miss this talk on how digitalisation and artificial intelligence (AI) can help to address the current challenges involved in the complex decarbonisation process. It will concentrate on one of the projects – ‘The World Avatar’, which intends to capture the idea of representing every aspect of the real world in a digital "avatar" world using knowledge graph and AI technologies.

‘The World Avatar’ will be recruiting permanent and internship roles.
Read more <https://drive.google.com/file/d/1oYpIi4rq17hVyPioz5RNQXjCJ4GoOD_B/view?usp=sharing> 

23 Aug 2021 | 1600 – 1700 Hrs | 
Virtual Platform

 Apply by 16 August 2021

 <https://forms.gle/WLS9a6BpXxw3TQdc7>  
Students from CSD, EPD & ESD 

 
 

The Certis Experience | Our Future Workplace 
Hear from our experts on the necessary skills you need to know to kick-start your career. Learn how you can make a difference and drive impact in the community. 

25 Aug 2021 | 1700hrs – 1800hrs | Virtual Platform 

Apply by 15 August 2021

 <https://drive.google.com/file/d/15g3tbG93Z64w4ZTT8SV8mLblk0W_MYhn/view>  

Seniors from CSD, EPD & ESD 

SAF C4I Career Sharing
The SAF C4I community brings together C4 and Intelligence units and personnel from across the SAF. They gather the best people under one roof, to transform the SAF into a networked and knowledge-enabled force. Join them for this talk and you may find C4I to be the right career choice for you.

26 & 27 Aug 2021 | 1000hrs – 1100hrs | Virtual Platform 

 <https://c4icareer.webex.com/meet/careersharing>  
Seniors from CSD, EPD & ESD








	
Other Opportunities 	


 
 

Dare to #GoBeyond SG
You are invited to #GoBeyond – a virtual career fair co-organised by Enterprise Singapore and Singapore Global Network

There will be insightful dialogues and interactive storytelling sessions where you can learn more about pursuing internship / job opportunities in the ACI region (ASEAN, China and India). 
Read more <https://drive.google.com/file/d/1yly7x4m9R3V5ujiGh1JUgrKmE0e3rG60/view>  

10 Sep 2021 | 0900hrs | Virtual Platform 

 <https://go.gov.sg/x1fv0n>  
Seniors from ASD, CSD, EPD & ESD 

SEMICON Southeast Asia Hybrid 
The premier electronics manufacturing event will be hosted on a virtual platform from 23 – 27 August. 

Register for your complimentary student virtual pass! 
Read more <https://drive.google.com/file/d/1E7WselbewuAdkNGa9TUbijeXNSP2ey_k/view?usp=sharing>  

23 – 27 Aug 2021 | Virtual Platform 

 <https://www.gevme.com/SEMICON-SEA-2021>  
Students from EPD 


	
Career Tips & Advice	

 

5 Tips for AI-Powered Interview Success
AI-powered interviews are quickly growing in popularity due to their ability to save employers time and money during the recruiting process. And if you’re apprehensive about your upcoming AI-powered interview, you’re not alone. In-person interviews can be nerve-wracking enough, and when you also have artificial intelligence looking over your shoulder, analyzing your every word and facial expression, your anxiety can ramp up quickly. Read more <https://access.vault.com/recordurl?nid=263753&wid=274402&vid=1> 


Click HERE  <http://access.vault.com/career-insider-login.aspx?aid=274402>  for full access and more career resources on Vault.com.
The service is free of charge for SUTD students and Alumni.
What to Ask During a Networking Interview
Each professional connection you make is an opportunity for mentorship and potentially the foundation of a future job, so it's important to keep cultivating these relationships no matter what stage of the job search you’re at. Read more <https://access.vault.com/recordurl?nid=256581&wid=274402&vid=1>

Subject: IES ML and QML Workshop
Body:
Hi everyone! 




IES is proud to announce a 5 Part Workshop Series on the basics and application of Machine Learning and Quantum Machine Learning. The workshop is open to all students.  

Timeframe of Workshop:
Date:14/08/21
Title: Introduction to Machine Learning 
Time:18:30-21:30 SGT


Date:15/08/21 
Title: Introduction to Neural Networks 
Time:18:30-21:30 SGT



Date:21/08/21 
Title: Python for Machine Learning and Neural Networks
Time:18:30-22:00 SGT



Date:22/08/21 
Title: Introduction to Quantum Computing
Time:18:30-22:30 SGT



Date:28/08/21 
Title: Introduction to Quantum Machine Learning
Time:18:30-22:30 SGT

Subject: 3.007 exhibition / Touch up projects on website and re-submit images
Body:
Hi all,

 

We hope that you have all been staying well. It’s fantastic that many of you took up to opportunity of the ARCASIA Student Competition, and it is also great that many of you looked for other design awards and submitted your projects.

 

We need to ask you for a favour? We had to take down files from the website that were too large and exceeding the available space. 

 

Can you please check your web pages, particularly submission part 4? And, can you upload any missing images? Before you do so, can you make reduce file sizes to less than 1MB.?

 

Your projects are short-listed and we would like to exhibit some of them at URA Gallery for a few weeks. We will decide within the next few days if we can show some images and bits of text on small posters (+ QR tags linking to web pages), or if we only display QR tags that link to the website. 

 

We would appreciate your support in this.

 

Thanks and all the best wishes,

Michael.

Subject: RE: GIC Virtual Networking Fair - 24 August 2021, 5-7pm
Body:
GIC’s recruitment season is here once again! 

Their Virtual Networking Fair is taking place on Tues 24 Aug, 5-7pm SGT. 

There will be business representatives hosting department sharings and networking sessions during the fair and it will be open to all undergraduates. Register here <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fdiscovergicnetworkingfair2021.seemecv.com%2F&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7Ca27fd2b9cdbd4c9c5bc808d95d48f7d1%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637643391532951723%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=rHLg6pwJA%2B1bJRQyvnLS3iw5lDSW2vwlL365HC12yE0%3D&reserved=0>  to learn more about opportunities they offer.

Subject: SUTD's Social Media Report (26 Jul - 8 Aug)
Body:
Dear SUTD community

 

This is the latest edition of the SUTD Social Media Report, covering the social media posts created on our various accounts for the period 26 July to 8 August.

 

If you have any interesting activities that will showcase SUTD’s mission, brand, talents and achievements, do reach out to Terence Chia at terence_chia@sutd.edu.sg <mailto:terence_chia@sutd.edu.sg>  

 

Please share any posts that interest you on your accounts and help us create a greater awareness of our stories.

 

Best regards

Zerlina

Office of Marketing & Communications

Subject: "Asking questions"
Body:
Hello Students,

 

Trust you guys are doing well.

Getting ready for the new term?

 

As some may know, CDC is now busying following up with students who are doing their compulsory internship now.

Checking with them and their supervisors about their experiences.

We will be doing the same to you when you are doing the similar program.

 

I would like to stay in touch with you guys and also share something I observe chatting with the supervisors.

I am very happy to receive many positive comments from the supervisors especially on the interns' technical ability and self-study ability to solve many technical challenges.

I will skip all the good things, and jump straight to 1 common comment from the supervisor; the “hunger for knowledge”.

I find that many supervisors are very enthusiastic and ready to teach and share, however they feel a little lacking from interns’ approach.

 

Questioning Technique.

 

“ . .I was hoping they are more questions . . .”

“ . . .spent too much time researching, when asking 1 question could speed things up . . .”

“  . .. . too sky / not daring to ask question, even in doubt. . . .”

“ .. . .no preparation before asking question . .. “

 

I deduce the below conclusion;

Be curious: Somehow, I believed many of you (if not all) have it.

In fact, this is 1 DNA we should have as engineers.

(Engineer should never satisfy with the solution produced, they MSUT be room for improvement!)

The problem I feel is that many are not daring to ask?

Example;

“Do you know, what your favourite uncle / aunty is working as? . .”

PROBING QUESTIONS è How did they get there?

LEARNER-CENTERED QUESTIONS è Can you tell me more about . . . .

 

“Why must we do Test A and Test B separately? Isn’t it more cost and time effective if we combine them, like a 3-in-1 ??”

(or we rather accept and follow what the Predecessor left for us?)

Be bold and propose your ideas.

You will be surprised that many supervisors welcome that.

Plus it demonstrates your analytical thinking.

 

 

Next is “dare to ask a question”.

I believed many of you (if not all) have the questions in mind.

1 of the biggest hindered is the fear of making a fool out of ourselves. You are not alone.

Ask a question (even you think or anybody thinks it is silly) è it clears your doubt. You learn.

You might be laughed at “once”. It might be hurtful, but the pain will be even more as we age.

Imagine a 2-yr-old, 12-yr-old and a 22-yr-old, ask “what is 1 + 1 . .. “

1 trick I use on myself is to start by asking to only 1 person (instead of a group)

As you “practise” more, you will learn how to brush off (or escape) the silly response (if any).

For example

“Can I get free coffee from the pantry?” ==> rolled-eye or shocking response ==> “well, some company have, no worries, just checking! Perhaps we should propose to the management.”

 

 

1 last thing to share is the level of preparation (before asking a question).

If a younger person comes to you and telling you that he / she can’t do the maths question.

You will also check how much they have try, right?

Whether you do it for him / her, lead them, or work with them, it is your style (your teaching methods).

You will also adjust yourself, to the learner too.

It will be more or less the same, the other way round.

 

Different people (supervisors) would have different types of expectations and working styles.

Some want to get things done fast; some are willing to let you discover on your own, some perhaps “spoon-feed” (very instructional).

And you also, being unique, also have a different learning style.

You will have to learn how to adapt. Main balancing factors are timeline and your learning capability.

 

 

Again, I leave the rest of the creativity thinking to you.

 

Just a reminder “Do the right thing, in the right place at the right time” (with the right people)!

 

=====  =====

Appreciate but No_need_reply (NNR), unless you have questions.

 

Thanks in advance.

 

Best Regards

 

Desmond Foo

Career Coach | SUTD Career Development Centre

 

 

 

 <https://www.sutd.edu.sg/> 

T: (65) 6499 4847

	
8 Somapah Road, Building 5 Level 3

Singapore 487372

 <https://www.facebook.com/sutdsingapore/>    <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fsg.linkedin.com%2Fschool%2Fsutd%2F&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C4161126ca7c44689785908d95d45766d%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637643375212318506%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=GT0Z0d%2B315tXrNs2gjJcf35yMf8zj1KzZSSLu8RaPIo%3D&reserved=0>    <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Ftwitter.com%2Fsutdsg&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C4161126ca7c44689785908d95d45766d%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637643375212318506%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=YvhcNKP5LoGJxW2V8xS9GHQEKbG4GEYKt09ceLs2Z6Y%3D&reserved=0>    <https://www.youtube.com/user/SUTDSingapore>    <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.instagram.com%2Fsutdsg%2F%3Fhl%3Den&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C4161126ca7c44689785908d95d45766d%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637643375212328496%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=QQqTp8K8w1TwV7DCMenKymodHULpt5oyYD1RWEa4xAM%3D&reserved=0>

Subject: Invitation to Participate in Psychology Experiment
Body:
Dear students, 




We are researchers from the Language and Social Cognition (LASC) Lab in SUTD. We are writing to you to describe a research study on social cognitive development. In this study, we are interested in examining a variety of social-cognitive abilities across the human lifespan.  

  

We would like to invite normal healthy individuals who are at least 18 years of age to participate in this study. You will take part in 1 or 2 sessions, each lasting for approximately 60 minutes (including short breaks). During this study, you will be asked to play some searching games and computerized tasks and fill in a questionnaire about your language background in our lab on campus at an agreed time. You will have the opportunity to be reimbursed S$10 per hour for your time.  

 

Venue: Behavioral Design Lab in IDC (Room 3.305, Level 3, Building 3) 

  

If you are interested in participating in the study, please go to the link below to register.

https://forms.office.com/r/cbuwVRiPNU <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.office.com%2Fr%2FcbuwVRiPNU&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C52fcc81faa904b6069b408d95d3746d2%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637643314336904517%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=SkW4h%2FMPUSu19azEtHKBtiwdbts8e00%2BnmZHrbGuLHw%3D&reserved=0> 


 

This is a project by Assoc Prof Yow Wei Quin. For more information, please contact us at Tel: (65) 6486 7022 or psychlab@sutd.edu.sg. 

  

We look forward to hearing from you soon! 





Best regards,


Xiaoqian


on behalf of the Research Team

To view the projects available next term, follow the instructions below:

From: global@sutd.edu.sg <mailto:global@sutd.edu.sg>  
Sent: Thursday, 5 August 2021 12:18 pm
Subject: [Call for Application] 2021 ZJU Alibaba Design Hackathon
Importance: High

 



Dear Students,

 

Call for application: 2021 ZJU Alibaba Design Hackathon – Campus Asia Design Workshop

 

Exciting opportunity to show off your design skills & to work with International students and companies such as Alibaba! 

 

We are pleased to inform you that Zhejiang University (ZJU) is inviting our students to participate in their 2021 ZJU Alibaba Design Hackathon – Campus Asia Design Workshop!

 

Better Responsibility Initiative – Design for Good Earth (BRIDGE) *Attached the full info sheet FYIP.

 

Hackathon background - Since the United Nations proposed the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, the significance and importance of the 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) have been increasingly growing and wide spreading. The outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020 has particularly started to make people think more about what on earth the “normal” world would be. 

 

In view of this situation, Zhejiang University is hosting BRIDGE (Better Responsibility Initiative - Design for Good Earth) Sustainable Design Action this summer. The BRIDGE Action is a design hackathon workshop focusing on working toward the SDGs and bringing together the design talents from universities and industries around the world to address the SDGs using the design language, attempting to "construct" a bridge to a sustainable future through the lens of design.

 

 

There are 3 stages for the workshop: Vision, Design, Action. ZJU is inviting us to join the Design Hackathon & the Action stage.

 

*         Design Hackathon Date: 4 Sep –11 Sep 2021

Available slots: 10 students

The best group will be awarded the trophy from ALIBABA DESIGN. All the participants will be awarded the certificate.

 

*         Action stage: Sep 12 – Dec 2021 (Optional)

The extremely outstanding students/teams have the opportunities to work with expertise mentors to improve the design proposals and put it into practice. 

 

Due to the long duration, we make it optional for students to join the Action stage however, if you are selected, do consider the pros of participating in such projects with companies like Alibaba, Cainiao, Tmall, etc..

 

Keen students please submit your name, Pillar, student ID, contact number via email by 11 Aug (Wednesday), before 5 pm.

 

2020 ZJU Alibaba Design Hackathon video: Here! <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.instagram.com%2Ftv%2FCSLXo9DHqj9%2F%3Futm_medium%3Dcopy_link&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C3ad358f40c694724c81508d95ca82e8b%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637642699728756116%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=sDqGgLQUD8zFyJmN6JDSqN1c0KqV1byLbiRZxteq8BY%3D&reserved=0> 

 

Tentative schedule:





 

Thank you.

 

Warm regards,

Office of International Relations

 

Any queries? Connect with us at global@sutd.edu.sg <mailto:global@sutd.edu.sg>  

 

 <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.instagram.com%2Fsutdsummer%2F&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C3ad358f40c694724c81508d95ca82e8b%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637642699728766113%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=LQonhxxi5gIopOJLIl7KChKnyY93aqqCr6dbw11rQH8%3D&reserved=0>         <https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCrhQNW4JY6XGx789gma9lXA?view_as=subscriber>       <https://wearesutd.sutd.edu.sg/exchange/design-and-technology-experience/summer-sponsored/>       <https://www.sutd.edu.sg/Global/Summer-Programmes/glp>        <mailto:global@sutd.edu.sg>

Subject: RE: DRLI Designathon - Keeping our farmers healthy and safe!
Body:
Dear Students,

The Decent Rural Living Initiative (DRLI) is looking for innovators to help make working conditions safer for agricultural workers in Asia. 

The DRLI Designathon welcomes design professionals, students, and engineers to design personal protective equipment (PPE) solutions customised to Asian conditions. 

We believe this is a great opportunity for you to put your skills to the test, create an innovative solution with your peers in a fun setting, and ultimately make a positive difference to agricultural workers in Asia who are responsible for feeding us.

To learn more about this programme, join their Info Session on Wednesday, 25 August. They can register here: https://bit.ly/drli-info <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fbit.ly%2Fdrli-info&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7Cdaccd9cc75da4c04b7d808d95ca0508b%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637642666166677914%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=NJmXowujVcfBqNdBKlvxV62JpotZOHxue8ih1lMCPr4%3D&reserved=0> .

Subject: Advanced Architecture Laboratory longlisted for two Dezeen Awards 2021
Body:
Dear SUTD Community, 

We are exited to share that The Future of Us Pavilion by ASD Professor Thomas Schroepfer and the Advanced Architecture Laboratory has been longlisted in the 'Cultural Building' and 'Landscape Project' categories of the Dezeen Awards 2021:

https://www.dezeen.com/awards/2021/longlists/architecture/cultural-building/ <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.dezeen.com%2Fawards%2F2021%2Flonglists%2Farchitecture%2Fcultural-building%2F&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C3e9422354d014297efec08d95bc4a6b0%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637641722628380635%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=C4uRa1NgXnIk3XDGjaHq5lT7qErQwnJxNjACaA2gKj8%3D&reserved=0> 

https://www.dezeen.com/awards/2021/longlists/architecture/landscape-project/ <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.dezeen.com%2Fawards%2F2021%2Flonglists%2Farchitecture%2Flandscape-project%2F&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C3e9422354d014297efec08d95bc4a6b0%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637641722628380635%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=G9cNXs3PmxIC9zrd6C3EY5%2F2Am9q14HfVNzrnAn62%2FQ%3D&reserved=0> 

 

Dezeen Awards annually identifies the world's best architecture, interiors and design, as well as the studios and the individual architects and designers producing the most outstanding work.

Organised by Dezeen <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.dezeen.com%2F&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C3e9422354d014297efec08d95bc4a6b0%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637641722628390630%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=tsB0azKtdgzwbouZQ6r5uGDetopHflNa1RHdFegzgfk%3D&reserved=0> , the world's most popular and influential architecture and design website, Dezeen Awards is the benchmark for international design excellence and the ultimate accolade for architects and designers everywhere.

For more information on the Dezeen Awards 2021, please see https://www.dezeen.com/awards/about/ <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.dezeen.com%2Fawards%2Fabout%2F&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C3e9422354d014297efec08d95bc4a6b0%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637641722628400627%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=vQLJqGbU5UKUmaeBjE%2FUkDTsb4guvtayr3eKq9yXstQ%3D&reserved=0> .

 




Thank you

 

Sincerely

 



 

https://asd.sutd.edu.sg/ <https://asd.sutd.edu.sg/>

Subject: RE: [Call for Application] 2021 ZJU Alibaba Design Hackathon
Body:
Dear Students,

 

A gentle reminder: The ZJU Alibaba Design Hackathon application is closing this week.

Students who are interested in this opportunity please submit your name, Pillar, student ID, contact number via email by 11 Aug (Wednesday), before 5 pm.

 

Thank you.

 

Warm regards,

Office of International Relations

 

From: global@sutd.edu.sg 
Sent: Thursday, 5 August 2021 12:18 pm
Subject: [Call for Application] 2021 ZJU Alibaba Design Hackathon
Importance: High

 



Dear Students,

 

Call for application: 2021 ZJU Alibaba Design Hackathon – Campus Asia Design Workshop

 

Exciting opportunity to show off your design skills & to work with International students and companies such as Alibaba! 

 

We are pleased to inform you that Zhejiang University (ZJU) is inviting our students to participate in their 2021 ZJU Alibaba Design Hackathon – Campus Asia Design Workshop!

 

Better Responsibility Initiative – Design for Good Earth (BRIDGE) *Attached the full info sheet FYIP.

 

Hackathon background - Since the United Nations proposed the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, the significance and importance of the 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) have been increasingly growing and wide spreading. The outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020 has particularly started to make people think more about what on earth the “normal” world would be. 

 

In view of this situation, Zhejiang University is hosting BRIDGE (Better Responsibility Initiative - Design for Good Earth) Sustainable Design Action this summer. The BRIDGE Action is a design hackathon workshop focusing on working toward the SDGs and bringing together the design talents from universities and industries around the world to address the SDGs using the design language, attempting to "construct" a bridge to a sustainable future through the lens of design.

 

 

There are 3 stages for the workshop: Vision, Design, Action. ZJU is inviting us to join the Design Hackathon & the Action stage.

 

*         Design Hackathon Date: 4 Sep –11 Sep 2021

Available slots: 10 students

The best group will be awarded the trophy from ALIBABA DESIGN. All the participants will be awarded the certificate.

 

*         Action stage: Sep 12 – Dec 2021 (Optional)

The extremely outstanding students/teams have the opportunities to work with expertise mentors to improve the design proposals and put it into practice. 

 

Due to the long duration, we make it optional for students to join the Action stage however, if you are selected, do consider the pros of participating in such projects with companies like Alibaba, Cainiao, Tmall, etc..

 

Keen students please submit your name, Pillar, student ID, contact number via email by 11 Aug (Wednesday), before 5 pm.

 

2020 ZJU Alibaba Design Hackathon video: Here! <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.instagram.com%2Ftv%2FCSLXo9DHqj9%2F%3Futm_medium%3Dcopy_link&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7Cc70eee7b3710417445af08d95bac1df6%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637641617455235121%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=sn6HdNCbK3aZUPp8anQ6qSPcNBDF8CYdQDI%2FccKIg9w%3D&reserved=0> 

 

Tentative schedule:





 

Thank you.

 

Warm regards,

Office of International Relations

 

Any queries? Connect with us at global@sutd.edu.sg <mailto:global@sutd.edu.sg>  

 

 <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.instagram.com%2Fsutdsummer%2F&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7Cc70eee7b3710417445af08d95bac1df6%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637641617455235121%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=u1y8VWZS%2Bqg5CHMHcgI%2FlnikzLDMU9BgsIU15nQAHvA%3D&reserved=0>         <https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCrhQNW4JY6XGx789gma9lXA?view_as=subscriber>       <https://wearesutd.sutd.edu.sg/exchange/design-and-technology-experience/summer-sponsored/>       <https://www.sutd.edu.sg/Global/Summer-Programmes/glp>        <mailto:global@sutd.edu.sg>

Subject: Register : Are you ready? Preparing yourself for a savvy career in tech firms
Body:
Dear Students,

 

I hope you are having a reasonably good time during your summer break. For the final year students, this is your final lap, so keep up your spirits!

 

Prof Nina invited me to present this lecture in her class tomorrow at 5.30 pm. Since this topic could be of interest to all students, Prof Nina has graciously opened up this class to all other students interested. 

 

Please register with Prof Nina, Bonnie, and Samuel above with your SUTD email, if you would like to join the talk. We will only let SUTD students into the room.

 

Topic: Preparing yourself for a savvy career in tech firms

Time: Aug 11, 2021 05:30 PM Singapore

 

Join Zoom Meeting

https://sutd-edu.zoom.us/j/96068266787

 

Meeting ID: 960 6826 6787

Passcode: career@118
