Body:
Dear students,

Week 2’s classes have been moved online. For Modelling Uncertainty, we will conduct the classes on Zoom and MS Teams during the normal class times. Your instructors will share the details with you (if they haven’t done so already).

For those of you who could not attend the physical classes, you should be able to join the online classes (at the same time as the other students in your cohort) this week.

Please also note that recordings of Week 1’s classes have been uploaded.

Best wishes,

James (course lead for Modelling Uncertainty)

Subject: RE: INCIDENT OF ALTERCATION AT CANTEEN ON 16 SEP 2021
Body:
Hi SUTDents, 

 

When the cabinet first came into our role, we assured students that we would ensure transparency between senior management and students. As such, when we saw that there were rumours spreading about the incident in canteen, we talked to management to address it so that it would help to ensure that safety of students are not compromised. Hence, the statement was kindly released by Head of OCIF, Mr Foo Siang Chi.

 

We have noticed that he did not send the email out by bcc, which is a mistake that we have made sometimes as well. That being said, a student has decided to reply all to the email with a meme. Given the sensitivity of the situation where people got hurt, it was inappropriate for the student to have replied in such a manner and also during a time when management are doing their best to handle the ongoing COVID-19 positive case in SUTD for our safety as well. 

 

This is not the first time someone has replied to all on an email where someone forgot to bcc. At first it might have been all fun and games but when it gets carried away too far, we become aware of the consequences such as what has happened today. I agree that this is an email etiquette that should be adopted by students but I also believe that there are better ways to bring the message across to the sender. As such, I implore you all to next time be professional and email directly to the sender. Not bcc-ing could have went unnoticed unless someone brings it to light at the end of the day. We hope that these unnecessary incidents will not happen again in our community.

 

I have reached out to the student personally and since the email will also be shared with staff, I will accept full responsibility if management were to ask me about it as ultimately, I was the one who requested for the statement. Whether the student wants to apologise, I will leave it up to them to decide but I hope that this will be a lesson to everyone and hope that we can move past this incident all together as ONE SUTD and focus on more pertinent matters at hand. 

 

Thank you and have a good weekend ahead!

 

On behalf of the 9th Student Government, ROOT,

 

Best Regards,

 

Mohamad Arshad

 <https://root.sutd.edu.sg/> 

President

9th Student Government

Unwavering • Accountable • Collaborative

 

 

 

________________________________

From: Student - Hoon Wei Ting <weiting_hoon@mymail.sutd.edu.sg>
Sent: Friday, September 17, 2021 11:49:25 PM
To: Foo Siang Chi <siangchi_foo@sutd.edu.sg>; *All Staff Faculty and Researchers <allstafffacultyandresearchers@sutd.edu.sg>; *All Students <*AllStudents@sutd.edu.sg>
Subject: Re: INCIDENT OF ALTERCATION AT CANTEEN ON 16 SEP 2021 
 
Dear SUTD Community




Warmest regards,
I learned so much except how to BCC

Never change, SUTD, love yall ❤️
________________________________

From: Foo Siang Chi <siangchi_foo@sutd.edu.sg>
Sent: 17 September 2021 11:05 PM
To: *All Staff Faculty and Researchers <allstafffacultyandresearchers@sutd.edu.sg>; *All Students <*AllStudents@sutd.edu.sg>
Subject: INCIDENT OF ALTERCATION AT CANTEEN ON 16 SEP 2021 
 

 

Dear SUTD Community

 

 

On 16 September 2021, an argument between an employee at a canteen stall and one of our outsourced maintenance technicians led to a physical altercation. The stall employee suffered severe facial injuries in the process.  In turn, the stall employee chased the technician for a short distance before returning to the stall.  The incident was over in a matter of a few minutes. 

 

Upon being alerted, two of our security officers arrived on the scene promptly.  As part of our University Security Protocol, the security supervisor confirmed that there were no safety threats to other canteen users. They detained both parties involved while waiting for the arrival of the police and the paramedics. After receiving treatment for their injuries, both men were arrested.

 

Regardless of the subsequent penal actions arising from the Police investigation, the University has informed the employers of both men that they are barred from working on campus with immediate effect. We will also take punitive action under the contract against the two contractor companies.

 

From our preliminary investigation and interviews, this incident was a result of impulsive reactions to a situation rather than a premeditated intent to cause hurt. After both men had calmed down, they expressed regret for behaving recklessly.

 

For any security-related incidents or emergencies on campus, students and employees can call our 24/7 Security Hotline at Tel: 6303 6666 for assistance or the police at Tel: 999.

 

 

 

Warmest regards,

 

 

Foo Siang Chi
Director

Office of Campus Infrastructure and Facilities

Subject: Updated Notice for Students (17 September 2021)
Body:
Message Classification: Restricted

 

Dear Students,

 

With the new developing situation, the university will adjust the teaching plan of 17 September, Friday to 24 September 2021, Friday (dates inclusive) or until further notice to safeguard the health and safety of the SUTD Community. 

 

1.                All classes/lab/Studios sessions [UG Term 1, 3, 6, 10 (MArch), PG and Compact Physics] will move to online learning mode.

2.                Graduate students performing research who need to return to research-lab/facility, please continue to seek clearance via your advisors/project-PIs/lab-managers.  For those who need to access Graduate Student Clusters (GSC), please refer to the email circular by Office of Graduate Studies: [Reopen of GSCs] Effective 25 Aug 2021 on the SMMs for working in GSC.

3.                The rest of the Safe Management Measures remain.

 

We seek the understanding and cooperation of everyone in complying with the teaching plan and measures for the well-being of the community and their loved ones.

 

Best regards,

Office of Student Administration

Subject: Summary of coverage: Highlights of SUTD
Body:
Hi All,

 

Here’s the news coverage: 

 

-          Straits Times reported that Mindef and SUTD have partnered to build defences against cyber attacks. Associate Provost for Research and International Relations, Prof Yeo Kiat Seng was quoted in the article.

-          Straits Times published a commentary based on a study that showed young children from lower-income families are spending more unsupervised time than higher-income ones on digital devices, to their detriment. This article was co-written by HASS head, Prof Lim Sun Sun.

-          MSN Singapore published an article on the Mid-Autumn lantern displays at Gardens by the Bay, which included mention of the AIRMESH, that was designed by lecturers (ASD Assistant Prof Carlos Banon) from SUTD.

-          Tech Xplore wrote an article about a recently discovered family of two-dimensional semiconductors that could pave the way for high-performance and energy efficient electronics. This research was led by SMT Assistant Prof Ang Yee Sin.

-          Straits Times wrote an article about charity group Inspiring Girls International’s #ThisLittleGirlIsMe social media campaign, where prominent women share their experiences to spur girls to pursue their dreams. The article included a brief mention of HASS head, Prof Lim Sun Sun’s story.

-          Channel NewsAsia reported that local universities are looking to resume overseas exchange programmes from January 2022 and briefly mentioned that SUTD is still in the process of finalising plans to resume international exchanges.

-          Straits Times published an opinion piece by three Yale-NUS alumni written in response to NUS president's commentary to explain the closure of the school. One of the writers is MUSPP's Ng Yi Ming.

-          Channel 8 Chinese News reported the findings published by PUB regarding the serious flood that occurred in Tampines on 20 August, and included a small segment of SMT senior lecturer Dr Teo Tee Hui sharing his expert opinion.

________________________________

 

Straits Times, 17 Sep 2021, Mindef, SUTD join hands to build defences against cyber attacks (https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/mindef-sutd-join-hands-to-build-defences-against-cyber-attacks <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.straitstimes.com%2Fsingapore%2Fmindef-sutd-join-hands-to-build-defences-against-cyber-attacks&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C91494e27e6b849a84efa08d979c6ccc3%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637674717289566889%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=rrGZSpkzN1JybREWIkbe39TB46hvnUucdEnFZei6yIw%3D&reserved=0> )

 

With the growing threat of cyber attacks on critical infrastructure, the Ministry of Defence (Mindef) is seeking to tighten its defences by further training its experts and studying the methods employed by hackers.

 

It is doing so through a partnership with the Singapore University of Technology and Design (SUTD) to strengthen collaboration in several areas, including research and technology, threat modelling and training, Mindef said yesterday.

 

A memorandum of understanding on operational technology security for critical infrastructure was signed by defence cyber chief Brigadier-General (BG) Mark Tan and SUTD associate provost for research and international relations Yeo Kiat Seng.

 

The signing took place at the university on the sidelines of a two-week cyber-security exercise co-organised by the Singapore Armed Forces (SAF) and SUTD, called the Critical Infrastructure Security Showdown.

 

Mindef said that recent cyber attacks on critical infrastructure, such as fuel pipelines and power distribution systems, are "stark reminders of the increasingly sophisticated cyber threats that countries face".

 

"The MOU underscores Mindef's and the Singapore Armed Forces' commitment to build up cyber-security expertise and capabilities against potential operational technology cyber threats."

 

Operational technology (OT) systems include computer systems designed to be deployed in critical infrastructure, such as power, water, manufacturing and similar industries.

 

Such infrastructure overseas has been hit by hackers recently. Colonial Pipeline, which supplies about 45 per cent of fuel used on the east coast of the United States, was hit by a ransomware attack in May.

 

That same month, a cyber attack on Brazilian food giant JBS forced the closure of all its beef plants in the US.

 

OT infrastructure and enhancements have been used in projects such as energy-efficient buildings and the Republic of Singapore Air Force's Smart Airbase, said Mindef.

 

The agreement is expected to cement collaboration between Mindef/SAF and the SUTD iTrust Centre for Research in Cyber Security in several areas.

 

The iTrust centre will allow Mindef to test cyber-defence measures and better understand vulnerabilities in OT systems. The centre will provide training and training infrastructure, and cyber exercises will be conducted.

 

Both parties will also analyse emerging OT attacks and study the tactics, techniques and procedures employed by attackers.

 

Joint scholarships may be awarded to selected personnel under the Command, Control, Communications and Computers Expert vocation for undergraduate and postgraduate studies to develop deep expertise, said Mindef.

 

The vocation was introduced in 2019 to develop a highly skilled cyber force to guard defence systems and networks.

 

BG Tan said: "Mindef/SAF recognises the importance of working with key partners like SUTD to keep pace with the latest developments in cyber-security research and technology."

 

Professor Yeo said the iTrust centre's state-of-the-art critical infrastructure test beds enable complex simulations of cyber attacks and the development of defences.

 

"Under the MOU, we will also help to conduct research and groom the next generation of cyber experts who can help defend our nation's critical infrastructure."  

 

 

Straits Times, 17 Sep 2021, Mind the gap - income divide in children's use of digital devices (https://www.straitstimes.com/opinion/mind-the-gap-income-divide-in-childrens-use-of-digital-devices-0 <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.straitstimes.com%2Fopinion%2Fmind-the-gap-income-divide-in-childrens-use-of-digital-devices-0&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C91494e27e6b849a84efa08d979c6ccc3%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637674717289576884%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=HhHC%2Fof%2BdQNH87cOGmrCXaPwH6zF4Ma7fw4NfjfrAVg%3D&reserved=0> )

 

Covid-19 has highlighted the indispensability of digital devices in our everyday lives. From mundane tasks such as coordinating daily routines and ordering meals, to working and online learning, as well as keeping in touch with loved ones, these devices have made riding through this pandemic much more tolerable.

 

In families with children though, there is a constant struggle to strike a healthy balance between access and excess in their digital device use.

 

The vast majority of young families in Singapore are blessed with a plenitude of devices, including smartphones, tablets, laptop computers, e-readers and digital screen-based toys, for young children. The challenge lies in managing young children's use of these devices so that they derive maximum benefit while experiencing minimal harm.

 

Excessive device use is a definite concern, with previous research showing that pre-schoolers can be more prone to throwing tantrums when asked to stop using them, or even become less interested in non-digital toys. There is also evidence that too much screen time for toddlers reduces their interaction with people around them and this impedes valuable learning within social settings.

 

Despite these potential risks with excessive use, devices can offer a wealth of enjoyable and educational content for pre-schoolers. An extensive range of smartphone-and tablet-friendly apps has emerged to cater to this age group, including many that teach language skills, numeracy, art and music. Given their portability, interactivity and multimedia capabilities, touchscreen devices such as smartphones and tablets enable appealing audiovisual content that is accessible and engaging for young children.

 

PARENTS' CRITICAL ROLE

Toddlers can quickly grasp how to turn on and manoeuvre these touchscreens to demand the content they like. However, parents still play a critical role in ensuring that these everyday devices are populated with cognitively stimulating and age-appropriate apps, managing their use and guiding their children closely. Pre-schoolers cannot literally be left to their own devices.

 

This is where robust evidence on device ownership and use by young families in Singapore is vital to provide public education on how parents can choose suitable devices, cultivate healthy device-use habits, curate edifying content and provide requisite supervision.

 

Data from the Singapore Longitudinal Early Development Study (SG Leads), conducted by the Centre for Family and Population Research at the National University of Singapore and its collaborators, provides illuminating insights on the state of device ownership and use by young families.

 

This Ministry of Education-funded study (of which we are principal investigator and co-investigator respectively) collected data from 2018 to 2019 from a nationally representative sample of 5,017 Singaporean children aged six and below and their primary caregivers. Children from all socio-economic statuses and racial groups are properly represented in this study.

 

Among the families surveyed, smartphone ownership is nearly universal with only 0.1 per cent of households not owning any. Tablets, which are the next most accessible devices for pre-schoolers, are not as ubiquitous, with over half (52.8 per cent) of families in rental flats not owning them compared with only 10.1 per cent for families in private property.

 

RENTAL-FLAT KIDS SPEND MORE TIME ON E-DEVICES

Beyond ownership, figures on the extent and context of device use in households of different socio-economic status (SES) is even more revealing. Children's time diary data from SG Leads shows that those up to the age of six from rental flats spend four hours and 28 minutes a week on electronic devices such as computers, tablets or smartphones - almost four times the one hour and 12 minutes for children in private condominiums and landed property.

 

This difference could be due to the latter having greater access to other materials at home or other activities outside of the home, including professional childcare and enrichment classes. Notably, for children aged three to six, nearly half (47 per cent) of the children living in rental units have access to smartphones and use them more frequently and with less parental supervision as compared with children in other housing types.

 

The nature of device use also manifests notable trends. For children aged three to six in rental flats with access to digital devices, 21.4 per cent use it for learning and 27 per cent for games daily, compared with 10.5 per cent and 7.1 per cent respectively for children in condos and private property. The heavier device use and more intense use for games rather than for learning by children in rental flats is striking.

 

Children from lower-SES families are markedly less well-resourced and have fewer alternative diversions as reflected in data on the number of books they own. Over half of the children living in private condos or landed property have 50 books or more, compared with only one in 10 of children in rental flats.

 

How parents spend their time with their children is another key difference. Half of the parents living in private condos and landed homes read to their children every day, reflecting the greater flexibility of time higher-SES parents enjoy. Of families in rental flats, 14 per cent of the parents read to their children daily, and 31 per cent never read to their kids.

 

SUPPORT FOR LOWER-INCOME PARENTS

Arguably, digital devices can help to bridge the learning gap for children in lower-SES families if they are using them to engage with cognitively stimulating content. Consider for example a parent who is not fluent in English but whose child can access nursery rhyme videos, alphabet and spelling apps, or online storybooks with audio narration. The child could potentially be exposed to a great deal of English from such content.

 

However, that presupposes that the parent has the wherewithal to download those apps and access such content for the child to begin with. In higher-SES families, children necessarily thrive in home environments where parents are actively imparting language skills and have their learning further augmented by carefully selected digital content. Children in lower-SES families lack such natural and additional advantages.

 

Support for lower-SES families should, therefore, extend to boosting parents' digital literacy in these regards - learning to distinguish between high-and low-quality device use, understanding the types of online content that are beneficial for children, as well as knowing how to access the content and guide their children's usage.

 

We should also consider establishing more comprehensive device loan programmes where lower-SES families are loaned tablets that are pre-loaded with specially curated selections of apps with educational and cognitively stimulating content. Corporate sponsors can be tapped for such support.

 

We should also make access to educational online materials through the public libraries easier for parents. Such programmes can help to make up for the resource paucity in such households and the parents' lower levels of digital literacy.

 

Fundamentally, with device use at home, parental guidance is indeed key. Previous research has established that when parents use digital media together with their young children and interact with them in the process, they can boost their children's learning.

 

Notably, 34.2 per cent of children aged three to six whose mothers have up to secondary education use smartphones and tablets on their own as compared with only 19.5 per cent of children whose mothers have university education and above. For the former, 45 per cent use these devices with parents or other caregivers while for the latter, 62 per cent do so. Again, higher-SES parents possess both the latitude of time and awareness of the desirability of parental supervision to exercise guidance of children's device use.

 

The nature of device use also differs markedly with 35.7 per cent of children with mothers of university education and above never using them for learning, compared with 25.7 per cent for children with mothers of secondary education and below. This contrast can be explained by other research that has found that more educated parents seek to actively minimise or delay their young children's digital device use in favour of books, toys and other forms of experiential learning that they regard as superior.

 

Of children whose mothers have secondary education and below, 47.9 per cent use digital devices for TV shows, movies and music and 28.5 per cent for games every day, compared with 24.1 per cent and 11.2 per cent respectively for children whose mothers have university education and above.

 

SOBERING STARK DISTINCTIONS

These stark distinctions in families from two opposing ends of the socio-economic ladder are sobering. The systematic advantage that children in higher-SES families enjoy is further amplified by digital device use that is supervised and scaffolded with higher-quality content engagement. By extension, children in lower-SES families are further disadvantaged when their device use may not be ideal in terms of context or content.

 

SG Leads data shows that 15 per cent of children aged three to six spent more than 21 hours a week on electronic devices, including TV and other electronic devices. Among this group, 64 per cent of the time spent on such devices was not in the presence of parents.

 

If largely unsupervised and engaging with content that is less educational in nature, their device use could impede their cognitive development. Notably, SG Leads data shows that, for children aged three to six, spending longer hours with electronic devices is linked to lower scores in applied problems and letter-word identification tests. Furthermore, using these devices without parents for half or more of the time intensifies this negative relationship.

 

Clearly more can and must be done to level the playing field in this regard. In a country like Singapore that is technologising intensively, digital literacy and access of parents and children across the socio-economic spectrum must be buttressed so that parents and children can fully exploit the benefits and not be left behind.

 

•Wei-Jun Jean Yeung is provost chair professor in the Department of Sociology, National University of Singapore (NUS) and the founding director of the Centre for Family and Population Research at the Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences, NUS.

 

•Lim Sun Sun is professor of communication and technology and head of humanities, arts and social sciences at the Singapore University of Technology and Design.

 

 

MSN Singapore, 16 Sep 2021, Mid-Autumn lantern sets & displays at Gardens by the Bay from now till Oct. 3, 2021 (https://www.msn.com/en-sg/lifestyle/topstories/mid-autumn-lantern-sets-and-displays-at-gardens-by-the-bay-from-now-till-oct-3-2021/ar-AAOv1jh <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.msn.com%2Fen-sg%2Flifestyle%2Ftopstories%2Fmid-autumn-lantern-sets-and-displays-at-gardens-by-the-bay-from-now-till-oct-3-2021%2Far-AAOv1jh&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C91494e27e6b849a84efa08d979c6ccc3%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637674717289576884%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=eWxOkVxTRSp%2Bq6M1QyZ2M5MQjHVuvpxtVNhKLyLdq4s%3D&reserved=0> )

 

On Sep. 15, Gardens by the Bay launched its Mid-Autumn Festival 2021 that will run until Oct. 3, 2021.

 

It features a total of nine lantern sets and community displays across the outdoor garden and Flower Dome.

 

Outdoor Gardens displays

Located at the Golden Garden near the main entrance are the Sky Lanterns and Rabbit Trails.

 

Measuring 32m wide and 19m tall, the Sky Lanterns is the largest lantern set this year with 70 lanterns floating up the Supertrees.

 

It represents this year's theme, blessings, and is inspired by the eponymous Chinese lanterns that are traditionally released to the sky for good blessings.

 

Rabbit Trails is a series of eight rabbit-shaped lanterns that lead the way to the Flower Dome, where there are more rabbits.

 

Korean period drama lovers should check out the Korean Genre Painting at The Rose near the Floral Clock outside the Flower Dome.

 

It is a hybrid lantern set where digitalised paintings by traditional Korean artists Kim Hong-do and Kim Jun-gun are set against the backdrop of two 'hanok' (traditional Korean house) lantern frames.

 

The Colonnade of Lights community lantern display at the Supertree Grove showcases 1,000 paper lanterns hand-painted by people from 28 social service agencies.

 

In addition, community art installations involving 50 schools and social service agencies are on display at Active Garden near Bayfront Waterfront Promenade.

 

Created from used plastic bottles, the upcycling effort is put together by Extra•Ordinary People, a charity that supports children and individuals with special needs.

 

Designed by lecturers from the Singapore University of Technology and Design, the award-winning lantern-inspired pavilion AIRMESH will be on display near Bayfront Plaza.

 

Flower Dome displays

Housed in the Flower Dome, the Rabbits' Forest is inspired by the ancient Chinese folk game "Blessings Upon the One who Meets a Rabbit", in which the first person to find a rabbit in the osmanthus forest is said to receive good blessings.

 

Hop over to Miffy Gardens that features fictional character Miffy and her family and friends. Meet and greet sessions with Miffy will also be held in the Flower Dome on Sep. 25 and Oct. 2.

 

A work of the community, the Origami Crane Trees feature 2,000 colourful paper cranes written with words of blessings by individuals from social service agencies and Gardens by the Bay volunteers.

 

Symbolising autumn in traditional Chinese art, chrysanthemums in colours of red, pink, orange, and yellow will be featured in a floral display.

 

Show and performances

Visitors can enjoy Tales of the Moon, a Mid-Autumn edition of the popular free Garden Rhapsody light and sound show at Supertree Grove.

 

In addition, six local performing arts groups supported by the National Art Council will perform at the Flower Field Hall.

 

The line-up consists of:

 

*         Tang Renaissance, a registered arts charity promoting Shanghai Yue Opera on Sep. 18

*         PB&J, Singapore’s only indie crossover band, on Sep. 19

*         Ding Yi Music Company on Sep. 24

*         Wu Yue Dance Studio Arts Troupe on Sep. 25

*         A Bigger Bang – The Percussion Assembly, a dynamic percussion group, on Oct. 1

*         Singapore Chinese Dance Theatre, a homegrown professional Chinese dance company, on Oct. 2

 

Pre-registration online is required and entry does not include admission to Flower Dome.

 

Admission is only available to visitors who are fully vaccinated, with negative PET results within 24 hours from the end of performance, or with proof of recovery from Covid-19.

 

The performances will also be live-streamed via Gardens by the Bay's Facebook page.

 

 

Tech Xplore, 15 Sep 2021, Towards more energy-efficient 2D semiconductor devices (https://techxplore.com/news/2021-09-energy-efficient-2d-semiconductor-devices.html <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Ftechxplore.com%2Fnews%2F2021-09-energy-efficient-2d-semiconductor-devices.html&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C91494e27e6b849a84efa08d979c6ccc3%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637674717289586876%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=0q5zGCTmr47BW4niyXNCh9m5XXJ%2F86Vm3mbKXnFkScQ%3D&reserved=0> )

 

According to researchers from the Singapore University of Technology and Design (SUTD), a recently discovered family of two-dimensional (2D) semiconductors could pave the way for high-performance and energy-efficient electronics. Their findings, published in npj 2D Materials and Applications, may lead to the fabrication of semiconductor devices applicable in mainstream electronics and optoelectronics—and even potentially replace silicon-based device technology altogether.

 

In the quest of miniaturizing electronic devices, one well-known trend is Moore's law, which describes how the number of components in the integrated circuits of computers doubles every two years. This trend is possible thanks to the ever-decreasing size of transistors, some of which are so small that millions of them can be crammed onto a chip the size of a fingernail. But as this trend continues, engineers are starting to grapple with the inherent material limitations of silicon-based device technology.

 

"Due to the quantum tunneling effect, shrinking a silicon-based transistor too small will lead to highly uncontrollable device behaviors," said SUTD Assistant Professor Ang Yee Sin, who led the study. "People are now looking for new materials beyond the 'silicon era', and 2D semiconductors are a promising candidate."

 

2D semiconductors are materials that are only a few atoms thick. Because of their nanoscale size, such materials are strong contenders as replacements for silicon in the quest of developing compact electronic devices. However, many currently available 2D semiconductors are plagued by high electrical resistance when they come into contact with metals.

 

"When you form a contact between metal and semiconductor, often there will be what we call a Schottky barrier," explained Ang. "In order to force electricity through this barrier, you need to apply a strong voltage, which wastes electricity and generates waste heat."

 

This piqued the team's interest in Ohmic contacts, or metal-semiconductor contacts with no Schottky barrier. In their study, Ang and collaborators from Nanjing University, the National University of Singapore and Zhejiang University showed that a recently discovered family of 2D semiconductors, namely MoSi2N4 and WSi2N4, form Ohmic contacts with the metals titanium, scandium and nickel, which are widely used in the semiconductor device industry.

 

Furthermore, the researchers also showed that the new materials are free from Fermi level pinning (FLP), a problem that severely limits the application potential of other 2D semiconductors.

 

"FLP is an adverse effect that happens in many metal-semiconductor contacts, and is caused by defects and complex materials interactions at the contact interface," Ang said. "Such an effect 'pins' the electrical properties of the contact to a narrow range regardless of the metal used in the contact."

 

Because of FLP, engineers are unable to tune or adjust the Schottky barrier between the metal and semiconductor—diminishing the design flexibility of a semiconductor device.

 

To minimize FLP, engineers usually employ strategies like very gently and slowly positioning the metal on top of the 2D semiconductor, creating a buffer layer between the metal and semiconductor or using a 2D metal as a contact material with the 2D semiconductor. While these methods are feasible, they are not yet practical and are incompatible with mass fabrication using mainstream industry techniques available today.

 

Amazingly, Ang's team showed that MoSi2N4 and WSi2N4 are naturally protected from FLP due to an inert Si-N outer layer that shields the underlying semiconducting layer from defects and material interactions at the contact interface.

 

Because of this protection, the Schottky barrier is 'unpinned' and can be tuned to match a wide array of application requirements. This improvement in performance helps put 2D semiconductors in the running as replacements for silicon-based technology, with major players like TSMC and Samsung already expressing interest in 2D semiconductor electronics.

 

Ang hopes that their work will encourage other researchers to probe more members of the newly discovered 2D semiconductor family for interesting properties, even those with applications beyond electronics.

 

"Some of them might be very poor in terms of electronics applications but very good for spintronics, photocatalysts or as a building block for solar cells," he concluded. "Our next challenge is to systematically scan through all of these 2D materials and categorize them according to their potential applications."

 

 

Straits Times, 15 Sep 2021, Prominent women share experiences to spur girls to pursue their dreams (https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/prominent-women-share-experiences-to-spur-girls-to-pursue-their-dreams <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.straitstimes.com%2Fsingapore%2Fprominent-women-share-experiences-to-spur-girls-to-pursue-their-dreams&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C91494e27e6b849a84efa08d979c6ccc3%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637674717289596867%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=cw462QfAIQkTM68uCwogSctknwWgeMWDdAAR%2BITysHo%3D&reserved=0> )

 

After her father died when she was five, her mother worked hard as a nurse to raise her and her siblings. So the little girl wanted to make her mother proud by doing well.

 

She would go on to pursue a career in law before becoming Minister in the Prime Minister's Office.

 

Yesterday, Ms Indranee Rajah, who is also Second Minister for Finance and Second Minister for National Development, shared her growing-up experiences as part of the #ThisLittleGirlIsMe social media campaign.

 

The campaign, launched on Monday by the Singapore arm of charity Inspiring Girls International, encourages women to post photos of their younger selves with their personal tales to show girls that they, too, can achieve their dreams.

 

Said Ms Indranee: "Take each day one step at a time. And one day, you will get to where you want to be."

 

Other women who shared their stories include Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu, Minister for Communications and Information and Second Minister for Home Affairs Josephine Teo, and Professor Lim Sun Sun, head of humanities at the arts and social sciences faculty of the Singapore University of Technology and Design.

 

Prof Lim recalled how she "read so voraciously that her parents parked her at the supermarket's book section while they grabbed the groceries".

 

Describing herself as a "little girl who asked too many questions", the communication and technology lecturer said she would have loved to see more female role models while she was growing up.

 

Ms Jacqueline Chua, president of Financial Women's Association of Singapore, who also shared her stories, said she once thought she was a "lost cause" as teachers did not understand her and she was brought up to think that being born a girl was a disadvantage.

 

Although she was academically challenged and socially awkward, she did not let that stop her from becoming a wealth management banker and an advocate for women in finance, she said.

 

Ms Chua, who is also chairman of Inspiring Girls Singapore, said in a Facebook post: "My advice to this little girl would be you are a hidden gem and don't give up!"

 

 

Channel NewsAsia, 14 Sep 2021, Local universities looking to resume overseas exchange programmes from Jan 2022 (https://www.channelnewsasia.com/singapore/local-universities-looking-resume-overseas-exchange-programmes-jan-2022-2176216 <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.channelnewsasia.com%2Fsingapore%2Flocal-universities-looking-resume-overseas-exchange-programmes-jan-2022-2176216&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C91494e27e6b849a84efa08d979c6ccc3%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637674717289596867%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=IynRA5VzPGqoPvo4shQW%2B0bSHMSYJXBczaPGWGwx62Y%3D&reserved=0> )

 

SINGAPORE: The National University of Singapore (NUS), Nanyang Technological University (NTU) and Singapore Management University (SMU) are looking to resume overseas student exchange programmes from January 2022. 

 

Responding to queries, an NUS spokesperson said the university has been in discussion with its partner universities in 40 countries to resume its student exchange programme in January. 

 

About 1,600 students have signed up for the programme, and the university has also started accepting applications from international students from partner universities, the spokesperson said. 

 

“The commencement of these programmes will be subject to prevailing health and travel advisories,” the spokesperson said, adding that NUS will continue to offer online programmes with partner universities and remote overseas internships for students. 

 

NUS is also resuming its NUS Overseas Colleges programme in Munich, New York, Silicon Valley, Stockholm and Toronto. The programme allows students to take up internships in technology-based start-ups overseas while attending classes in partner universities in those cities. 

 

Eighty of the 151 students in the programme have signed up to travel to these locations from October to January 2022, said the NUS spokesperson. 

 

Currently, these students have been placed in remote internships with start-ups from their preferred locations

Subject: RE: [Restricted] Updated Fifth Row Advisory WEF 13 Sep 2021
Body:
Dear students

 

All face-to-face Fifth Row activities have been suspended until the end of Friday 24 Sep 2021.

 

Following new advice from the Expert Committee on COVID-19 Vaccination, please take note that all students should abstain from strenuous activities for 14 days after the first or second dose of the COVID-19 vaccine. Those leading or facilitating the activity must screen participants before the start of each session. They must also remind those who have had a vaccination dose more than 14 days ago to inform them immediately if the participants develop chest pain, shortness of breath on exertion or abnormal heart beats at any point during strenuous physical activities – stop immediately and seek medical attention.

 

Thank you.

 

Regards,

Office of Student Life

 

From: Student Life 
Sent: Friday, 10 September 2021 3:34 pm
Subject: [Restricted] Updated Fifth Row Advisory WEF 13 Sep 2021

 

Message Classification: [Restricted]

 

Dear students,

 

Please refer to the attached guidelines for latest details.

 





 

Regards,

Office of Student Life

Subject: Strategic Financiers Program
Body:
Inviting all freshies and SUTDents!

 



 

SUTD Strategic Financiers

SUTD Strategic Financiers is a sub-category of SUTD MarketWatch where it aims to equip students with the relevant skillset to achieve a better financial future through a practical and theoretical approach!

 

At the end of the modules, we aim students to have the means to set up their financial independence goals and be better informed about the financial industry. Moreover, they would master Personal Finance and know what how and what it means to be an investor.

 

This is supported by Mr. Wong Choon Yuan, a CFA lecturer who was previously the Vice-President of Valuation Control with Barclays. Strategic Financiers is very grateful to him as he has volunteered his time towards this cause.

 



 

The modules covered throughout the course are as follows:

 

Topic 1: Personal Finance (29 Sep 2021 –  3 Nov 2021)

1.	Passive income: Dividend Stocks
2.	Plan ahead: How to handle Student Repayment Loan and BTO
3.	Career in the Finance Industry
4.	Protect yourself: Basic Insurance

 

Topic 2: Investment: Assets Allocation & Risk Management (10 Nov 2021 – 24 Nov 2021)

5.	ETFs & Index Funds
6.	Stock Valuation, Accounting Statement
7.	Fundamental and Technical analysis

 

 

Practical Discussions

 

As we identified that another major barrier to financial planning and investments is that young adults don't even know the practical steps to get started, the practical aspect touches on guiding and teaching students how to apply and use the knowledge gained to their advantage. This entails the full spectrum of market discussion, stock valuation, and even boiling down to the bolts and nuts such as teaching them how to get their CDP accounts started to start investing and the technicalities behind the various brokers. This touch would give life to the knowledge taught through the core modules, as students who be able to put to use what they have learnt- taking their first step towards financial planning as they embrace adulthood. At the end of the day, we hope to create a community of financially equipped students!

 

Opportunities

 

Beyond equipping students with the skills and knowledge to take part in external competitions, we aim to provide opportunities by organising competitions and inviting our corporate partners as panellists. This would give students the opportunity to put themselves out there for potential internship opportunities. Stay tuned as we roll out more details!

 

Information and Introductory Opening

 

Our sessions are conducted online every Thursday 1930-2030 weekly. A short Introductory Opening brief will be held on 21st Sep 2021, 1930 – 2030, where we will be sharing more about what you can expect from the club as well as the calendar of upcoming events before the program commences shortly.

 

Everyone is welcomed regardless of investment knowledge!

Click here <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.office.com%2FPages%2FResponsePage.aspx%3Fid%3Ddrd2NJDpck-5UGJImDFiPdO3o3jdGW9LgZqHtWvUDiFUOUNFNk5VNjk1TTJOWkRKTzJUSVVRT09KTiQlQCN0PWcu&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7Cda62dce0020f4c62dbc508d9799dcea4%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637674541393347220%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=G8F6JoaWzgJGkoZLyRnIT9t%2FGwNRqVyISrg0X26k3ig%3D&reserved=0>  to sign up!

Subject: Ladies in Cyber Learning Journey and Fireside Chat at Cisco on 25th October for female students
Body:
Hi Everyone,

 

AiSP will be organising a Ladies in Cyber Learning Journey and Fireside Chat at Cisco on 25th October for female students. Join SMS Sim Ann, Catherine, Sherin & Wendy - our female leaders from Cybersecurity industry on 25 Oct 21 (Mon) at 6.15pm as they share their experience, advice and provide guidance on career in IT industry for females. This is also part of Cyber Security Agency of Singapore SG Cyber Women X Series. More details on the event below.

 

This is a hybrid event - there are 6 available slots for physical attendees and no limits for virtual attendees.

 

(For physical attendees) Programme:

1815: Registration, collection of Goodie Bag & T-Shirt

1830: Tour of CISCO Office, Data Centre & Lab

1900: Dinner

1930: Sharing by CISO Netacad on the Cybersecurity Courses and Activities that can join in for free

1940: Welcome Address by AiSP Vice-President, Ms Sherin Y Lee

1945: Panel Discussion with SMS Sim Ann, Wendy, Catherine and Sherin

2030: Q&A

2035: Presentation of Token of Appreciation

2040: Photo Taking

2045: End of Event

 

(For virtual attendees) The link to join the fireside chat virtually will be sent out nearing the date of the event.

 

Limited slots are available. Please sign up using the link below by Thursday, 23rd Sept. A confirmation email will be sent out to students who have registered successfully. 

 

[Sign Up Link] https://forms.office.com/r/QUAgN9YMtZ <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.office.com%2Fr%2FQUAgN9YMtZ&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7Cc4986cd6f5274bed6b6b08d97c04bf6a%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637677182571399467%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=hI03XCzpMEHrFr8fS4Dp2BjTgJuVHVNSw1F%2Bz9bSrOo%3D&reserved=0>   




Warm Regards,
Li Wen Ong

Subject: Virtual Book Launch - Divine Custody: A History of Singapore’s Oldest Teochew Temple
Body:
Dear SUTD Community,

 

We are pleased to inform you that Associate Professor Yeo Kang Shua’s latest book, Divine Custody: A History of Singapore’s Oldest Teochew Temple, published by NUS Press will be launched virtually this Saturday 25 September (4pm Singapore Time) online: https://buff.ly/38V26Lr <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fbuff.ly%2F38V26Lr&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7Ced31a137457d4fa570c608d97ca2fe8f%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637677862239115456%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=1jWaHVrLSrWBy6BGmB9jcaZHOYjWONfG4VnUam7%2FX%2Fg%3D&reserved=0> . 

 

Kang Shua will be joined by discussant,  Associate Professor Hui Yew Foong, an anthropologist from Hong Kong Shue Yan University, Contemporary China Research Center. 

 



 

Thank you

 

Sincerely

 

 



 

https://asd.sutd.edu.sg/ <https://asd.sutd.edu.sg/>

Subject: Design Odyssey (DO) DiscoverSUTD Workshops
Body:
Hi SUTDents!!!

 

Ever had an idea for a solution to benefit the society, but you don't know where to begin? How about having a dream to help those who really need help in our midst, but you do not know how to help them? 

 

Well, Design Odyssey’s (DO) DRIVE program is that one thing you can look forward to if you do not know where to start! Haven't heard about us before? You might be wondering, hmmm why such a complex naming?  It's simple! DO is the place where you are guided to uncover the root causes of the problems where you want to be the spark for change. A unique program by DO , DRIVE is where you can learn to Discover, Define, Develop and Deliver innovative solutions that help improve our society and the environment! 

 

Now that classes are online, you may feel that you are missing out on the fun, but fret not!!! Come join us for 2 virtual workshops during the Discover SUTD season to get a taste of what you can look forward to doing in DRIVE! You will also get a chance to meet like-minded individuals with whom you can share ideas and collaborate, while also getting a head start and insight into design thinking! We will also be answering all your questions about us :) So what are you waiting for? Join us now and stand the chance to receive UglyFood ice cream vouchers 🥳!!!!

 

 

Workshop: Introduction and Induction to Business 360

 

Date: 24 Sep 2021 (Friday)

Time: 3pm-5:30pm

Venue: Zoom

 

Workshop: Introduction and Ideation

 

Date: 1 Oct 2021 (Friday)

Time: 3pm- 5:30pm

Venue: Zoom

 

Sign up now for the workshops here <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.office.com%2Fpages%2Fresponsepage.aspx%3Fid%3Ddrd2NJDpck-5UGJImDFiPTtI_CxEKk5Atq9WZiRjmXdUNzdTTkxPWVVIOFlDWTVKVkg4R1VTUFVEOS4u&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C2e64146ad50149873e8c08d97c41d068%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637677444564726745%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=ixwr8E2qtd61xWj2Zu%2BoOvcIHf52lRb1XDBS6Ej8h98%3D&reserved=0>  😊! Hope to see y’all there!!!

 

Curious to know more about DO and DRIVE? Check out our video here: https://youtu.be/jrvaNGuXen4 <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fyoutu.be%2FjrvaNGuXen4&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C2e64146ad50149873e8c08d97c41d068%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637677444564736747%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=GDnsFTBmwsQH8MuD%2Byw5GpZt%2BekF2zRVWLp6mmnQNRQ%3D&reserved=0>  😊 😎 😊 !!! 

 

Do also join our TELEGRAM GROUP here <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Ft.me%2Fjoinchat%2F7JBQMnY_frNkMTE1&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C2e64146ad50149873e8c08d97c41d068%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637677444564736747%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=gxmRVoJazdtdMOq0cQ%2BgaqEMeG4EMGz%2Fsf2dtROEpr4%3D&reserved=0>  and follow us on INSTAGRAM @designodysseysg <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.instagram.com%2Fdesignodysseysg%2F%3Fhl%3Den&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C2e64146ad50149873e8c08d97c41d068%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637677444564746738%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=bdsuRAlJYTNyYs21o2sn8zhEbMma87a%2FPa85RlfmwuE%3D&reserved=0>  to be updated on upcoming events!!! 

 



 

All our best,

Design Odyssey Team

Subject: PhotogCircle Presents: Photog Challenge [September-October 2021]
Body:
Hi SUTD,

 

Here at PhotogCircle, we are keen on engaging our members and the wider community to discover and enjoy capturing moments in their daily life. Our event, 'Photog Challenge' is the chance for you to take your favourite photo and share with others what makes it special to you.

 

If you have favourite moments that you have captured recently or just need a springboard to dive into this creative and diverse world of photography, our 'Photog Challenge' is the perfect opportunity for you to showcase your photos!

 

For this month, the theme for the submissions is 'New Normal'. With the world now adjusting to live with COVID-19, we would like to see photos of how our lifestyles are moving forward with this virus now endemic in the community.

 

Submit your photos via this online form: https://forms.office.com/Pages/ResponsePage.aspx?id=drd2NJDpck-5UGJImDFiPawmVfnE9HRPuklUk58tCohUQ0dXVTBNNUhDTExHVEQ1QzVCVzFINEkyWi4u <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.office.com%2FPages%2FResponsePage.aspx%3Fid%3Ddrd2NJDpck-5UGJImDFiPawmVfnE9HRPuklUk58tCohUQ0dXVTBNNUhDTExHVEQ1QzVCVzFINEkyWi4u&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C980e2ad136d04bd31f9208d97c2e356e%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637677360455855186%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=OyzUXOGPK%2FvJS5av9JAT%2Bi6LDk5eUF6Qq6sTzonZ7uw%3D&reserved=0>  

 

All submissions close by 15th October 2021. The best photos will be featured on our Instagram and you may stand a chance to win attractive prizes (and bragging rights)! So grab your camera or smartphone and get snapping!

Subject: BANDSCAMP 2021 SUTD BANDS RECRUITMENT

 

HEY SUTDFAM!

 

Did you manage to catch Pandemic @ The Disco 2 last saturday 😮

Did it inspire to take up your instruments once again and jam like there's no tomorrow? 🎸🎸🎸

 

If SOOooooo...

 

SUTD Bands might be the perfect fifth row for you 🤩

We’re looking for passionate individuals who love making music to join us. No experience or auditions required! 


 

If this sounds like your jam, come join us at our official freshie induction camp, SUTD BANDSCAMP 2021.  We’ll share all you need to know about SUTD Bands, play some games and make amazing music with your talented batch mates :) Be sure to bring your instruments and equipment to school to jam with your friends too!

 

📍 Where: Virtual (Link will be sent later!)

🕐 When: 25th September, Saturday, 2-6pm 

🎒 What to bring: Your unique music tastes and your undying love for music 🤘

 

Sign up for SUTD Bandscamp 2021 now using this link <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.office.com%2FPages%2FResponsePage.aspx%3Fid%3Ddrd2NJDpck-5UGJImDFiPXVVhj-PHDBGmpgREr3QUxZUNldERktVMDFNWUxRSTVBWFI4VlEyUFdESC4u)!&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C1545190b5e0b4fb83b7208d97c2add1d%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637677346557503070%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=l9x4dgAN98B3UaHiY5mwdWsdEtHIdeRVw65hU22XJPM%3D&reserved=0> !!!

Who knows, maybe you'll be headlining our next concert 😉😉😉

 

 

psst.. if you missed sutd's hottest concert last week, here's the link <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fyoutu.be%2FG1iuYSJRc0g%3Ft%3D840&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C1545190b5e0b4fb83b7208d97c2add1d%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637677346557503070%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=TrdVAuse7hWRNdyj%2F5e4hZV%2FueGhSIs6VTOAg1jPAdY%3D&reserved=0>  ;)

Subject: Application for Choice of Degree Major
Body:
Dear Freshmore Students,

 

You have reached another milestone in SUTD – Choice of Degree Major!

From 27 Sept to 1 Oct 2021, you are required to make your preferred choice of degree major via MyPortal >  > Navigator > Self Service > Preferred Choice of Major. Your major choice will be recorded on the last day of the application window period. No changes will be allowed after this date. 

 

Note that you will be allowed to proceed to the major of study only if you have passed all 5 Required Freshmore subjects and passed at least 5 out of 7 of the Non-Prerequisite Freshmore subjects which is the minimum requirement to proceed to the major years pursuant to the Policy on Academic Warning, Academic Probation and Required Withdrawal for the Freshmore Terms. 

 

You will be notified via email of your confirmed major choice by 6 Oct 2021.

 

Thank you.

 

Regards

Eileen LIM

Associate Head Registrar Services

Office of Student Administration

Subject: RE: ADDX Career Day 2021 - 6 Oct 2021, 5.00- 6.00pm
Body:
Thinking of a career in Fintech? 

How about rolling up your sleeves in a potential unicorn? Come join us for our webinar on 6 October from 5 - 6pm!

ADDX is blockchain based fintech start up fully regulated by the MAS and backed by esteemed investors, such as Singapore Exchange and Heliconia, a subsidiary of Temasek! We are democratizing the financial markets by giving investors access to high quality private market opportunities such as Private Equity, Venture Capital Funds and Unicorns. At ADDX, you will get the opportunity to work alongside high calibre, passionate individuals who have a wealth of professional experience. Furthermore, you will be supported throughout to take on projects from the planning stage all the way to the execution stage & gain extensive hands-on experience. If you believe in a future of fair financial markets just like we do, we’ve been waiting for you at ADDX! We welcome students studying in Business School, School of Computing, Faculty of Law, Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences, Faculty of Science, Faculty of Engineering, School of Design and Environment to join us at our recruitment talk to learn more about ADDX & how you can make a lasting impact in making private markets accessible for all. Have a passion to create change from day 1 in a fast-growing industry? Then do register for our webinar by 3 October 2021 if you are interested to find out more about full-time internships or job opportunities with ADDX.

 

Agenda:
1. Introduction to ADDX
2. Internship experience sharing
3. Q&A

 

This event will be hosted by Manuel Jaeger, Co-founder & Head of Product, and Alexander Lee, Customer Experience Manager. You will also hear from past ADDX interns. We look forward to meeting you!

 

https://us02web.zoom.us/webinar/register/1216321277673/WN_HkGn4l2VTzWxs7FFFR-AIA

 

 

 <https://us02web.zoom.us/webinar/register/1216321277673/WN_HkGn4l2VTzWxs7FFFR-AIA> 

Best regards,

 

Davina Tham
Employer Relations
Career Development Centre

Subject: Graduate Studies Newsletter - Issue 1
Body:
Dear Fellow members of the SUTD Community,

 

The Office of Graduate Studies (OGS) is pleased to launch the inaugural issue of the Graduate Studies Newsletter (GSN).

 

Graduate students make up about a third of the student population in SUTD, and the newsletter aims to help promote greater awareness about the happenings within the SUTD graduate student community including highlights of recent events, awards & achievements of our graduate students, alumni sharing and much more.

 

If you have any feedback, suggestions or contributions for future GSN issues, please send them to us via gradoffice@sutd.edu.sg <mailto:gradoffice@sutd.edu.sg> .

 

Enjoy the issue! 

 

Thank You.

 

Best Regards,

Office of Graduate Studies

Subject: SOAR Challenge - Workshop Series
Body:
Hi everyone!

 

Interested to learn more about robotics, want to up your hardware or software game? If you’re interested to find out more about SOAR, do look at the attached slides!

 

SOAR Challenge - Workshop Series are a series of free workshops to prepare your hardware and/or software skills for SOAR Challenge 2021, held during recess week. While we would highly encourage participants of the workshops to join SOAR Challenge, it is not compulsory to do so. SOAR Challenge registration will be held at a later date (sneak peak in the powerpoint slide attached).

 

 <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Flinktr.ee%2Fsutdsoar&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C0cc2d71dfd9e4381bbcf08d97e455f5d%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637679659751662859%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=IVGnvZBn6dmp5f2%2FJb1EBDV1aDDtxgdZhJ8RsdBLIX8%3D&reserved=0> 

 

Details of the workshops are as follow:

Hardware workshops: Mondays, 7pm-9pm. (27th Sep, 4th Oct and 11th Oct)

*	Mech Design
*	CAD (Sketching)
*	CAD (Assembly)
*	CAD (Simulation)

 

Software workshops: Thursdays, 7pm-9pm. (30th Sep, 7th Oct, 14th Oct)

*	Introduction to Arduino
*	Programming
*	PWM
*	Ultrasound
*	Motor Driver

(workshops will be held physically, where possible. Participants will be informed of the mode of workshop online/physical before the session.)

 

Interested to join our workshops? Subject: AI Course for Students!
Body:
Dear SUTDents,

 

Want to learn more about AI, but just not sure where to start? Searching for certification courses in machine learning that can boost your portfolio?

 

Then fret not, for we at SUTD-AISG have just the solution for you!

 

The AI4S course by the AISG parent organization is open for registrations for all students!

 

AI4S (click here <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Flearn.aisingapore.org%2Fcourses%2Fai-for-students%2F&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C6ff2b1b2987b4481146a08d97df3d2b2%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637679308896606001%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=P0PhHIS%2B8yeYrX0r71xhsb4NGoc%2FGFRucPfnSDPDDQU%3D&reserved=0>  for AI4S syllabus) covers the important AI concepts including data science in python, regression techniques, classification, machine learning, as well as important data analysis concepts like SQL!

 

With 80 hours of learning content spread across 31 modules and 11 quizzes, earn your AI4S certification now!

 

To sign up for the AI4S course and/or ask any questions, please reach out to @Anirudh181001 or @timtameater on telegram, or feel free to reply to this mail with any questions!

 

To sign up for SUTD-AISG membership, click here <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.office.com%2FPages%2FResponsePage.aspx%3Fid%3Ddrd2NJDpck-5UGJImDFiPbAE8J5NASpDrs2cVRnSweJUQUo3RjI3SThFVEhUOVVaWkpWMUI2T0NEUS4u&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C6ff2b1b2987b4481146a08d97df3d2b2%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637679308896606001%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=MqA9SREM0H25tAgS3vigRuqTnuim0na8%2F%2FPeINxKPAw%3D&reserved=0> !




To sign up for our introductory session/ data analysis and visualisation workshop, click here <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.office.com%2Fr%2F2qS5HGx4He&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C6ff2b1b2987b4481146a08d97df3d2b2%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637679308896616007%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=YIgPh81aJjVrpQHg2Nfg6xr4d6gpsu76K9TxGrTgd0E%3D&reserved=0> !




Best Regards,

Anirudh Shrinivason

SUTD-AISG - President

Subject: 01.020 Design Thinking Project III
Body:
Dear Students,

 

Indeed, it is FrankLion again.

This is to gladly inform you that we (various faculty members) have put together a series of design thinking projects for you.  

 

Note the following details of the project:

1.       Projects are elective-driven.

2.       You will have to choose between 2 elective-driven projects.

3.       The projects are team-based.  We will follow the OSA groupings.

4.       Each OSA group will choose ONLY ONE project.

5.       Entire project is worth 10 % for each participating subject (Elective + HASS + Modelling Uncertainty).

6.       Project is graded in an integrated fashion, but the grade obtained in the project will be given to all participating subjects.

7.       Passing grade means a TRANSCRIPT ENTRY as in previous semesters.

8.       For the elective not chosen, your grade will be pro-rated from 90% to 100% (as the project is 10%).

9.       There will be a ZOOM Meeting next WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON (most likely 3:30-4:30pm) to describe each project technical details and EXPECTATIONS, and Q&A. 

10.   Check eDimension to see the projects already uploaded and meeting confirmation time next time.

 

Keep safe and strong!

 

Regards,

 

Franklin Anariba, PhD

Science, Mathematics, and Technology (SMT)

Affiliated with Engineering Product Development (EPD)

Singapore University of Technology and Design (SUTD)

08 Somapah Road, Singapore 487372

Subject: [PADI] Batik Day - Exclusive PADI Merchandise!
Body:
Dear SUTD,

Hope all of you are starting this new term with a blast!

 

In Indonesia, we celebrate 2nd October, the date Batik was designated as Humanitarian Heritage, as Batik Day. 
As the date is coming, SUTD Indonesian Cultural Club (PADI) would like to introduce an exclusive merchandise <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Ftinyurl.com%2FPADIBatikMask2021&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7Cdd2ba103728d4caa131308d97dbfdcbf%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637679085616560115%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=rzDEroj5dTCo%2BeP6TtUCeXpiZ2BoJh0YgmGcgC3%2Fwgw%3D&reserved=0> :

 



 

SUTD Indonesian Cultural Club (PADI) is launching out our Batik Mask editions, with 4 variations of Batik motifs!

Each batik represents a region in Indonesia as well as their culture and history.
You can choose whichever motifs you find fascinating! 
(We will share the history of each batik In the upcoming emails, stay tuned!)



We are selling it at: 
1 for SGD$6

4 for SGD$20 (Save $4!)

Purchase yours now through the link below: 
https://tinyurl.com/PADIBatikMask2021 <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Ftinyurl.com%2FPADIBatikMask2021&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7Cdd2ba103728d4caa131308d97dbfdcbf%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637679085616560115%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=rzDEroj5dTCo%2BeP6TtUCeXpiZ2BoJh0YgmGcgC3%2Fwgw%3D&reserved=0> 

Option for self-collection in the order form will be closed on 29th of September,
& we will open a booth for collection at SUTD on 30th September 2021 and 1st October 2021.
Alternatively, you may also opt for mailing!

Collect the different designs and wear it to university with your friends!

Check out below on how the mask would look like on you:

 



 

With Love,



PADI Exco 2021 💛


If you have any questions, feel free to reach out to us on our Instagram <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.instagram.com%2Fpadigraphy&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7Cdd2ba103728d4caa131308d97dbfdcbf%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637679085616570098%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=2Ar%2BLpiaVXyIq7znUq55Jl5BVXuZ%2BzOj5df3y%2FS2XDY%3D&reserved=0>  or Email us at indonesiancultural@club.sutd.edu.sg <mailto:indonesiancultural@club.sutd.edu.sg> !

Subject: Invitation to participate in an eye-tracking experiment
Body:
Dear students, 




We are researchers from the Language and Social Cognition (LASC) Lab in SUTD. We are writing to you to describe a research study on social cognitive development. The study aims to investigate the impact of online classes on how we learn. An online method- the eye-tracking technology- is used to help to understand the underline mechanism during online learning. It is a non-invasive and effective method for examining cognitive performance.


  

We would like to invite normal healthy individuals who are at least 18 years of age to participate in this study. In addition, if you are short-sighted, your degree should not be over 800. You will take part in a session lasting for approximately 20 to 30 minutes. During this study, you will be watching a recorded lecture and you will be asked to answer some questions after watching the video. You will be reimbursed with a S$5 voucher for your time.




Venue: Behavioral Design Lab in IDC (Room 3.305, Level 3, Building 3) 

  

If you are interested in participating in the study, please indicate your preferred time slot at this link: https://doodle.com/poll/t4tfabuxg27pnr4p?utm_source=poll&utm_medium=link <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fdoodle.com%2Fpoll%2Ft4tfabuxg27pnr4p%3Futm_source%3Dpoll%26utm_medium%3Dlink&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C62fc025c63354336493608d97d9d8f58%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637678938061918838%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=a7HDP4g4s%2BCkE8ISace6N1D%2F%2FWEHxnCVDbSNinIXsto%3D&reserved=0> . The study will be starting on the 27th of September. Do provide your name and email address! Thank you!




This is a project by Assoc Prof Yow Wei Quin and Assoc Prof Tan U-Xuan. For more information, please contact us at Tel: (65) 6486 7022 or psychlab@sutd.edu.sg. 

  

We look forward to hearing from you soon! 





Best regards,


Yisih


on behalf of the Research Team

(Located on Level 2 of Block 61 Sports and Recreation Centre, near the grandstand, facing the running track)

 

 

About SUTD Chinese Orchestra (SUTDCO)

Since its formation in 2015, SUTDCO has been involved in many internal and external engagements, showcasing an eclectic mix of musical pieces of various styles and genres.

 



  

If you are

🌟 interested in joining a community of passionate musicians  🌟

👥 looking for opportunities to perform in an orchestra/ensemble/solo  👥

🥁 keen to learn a musical instrument 🪕

then join us for this introductory session!

(Due to the current COVID-19 measures, trying out of wind instruments is not allowed during this intro session)

 

 

Sign up for a session through the link below or by scanning the QR code in the poster!

https://forms.office.com/r/KsvSqJ6JLY <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.office.com%2Fr%2FKsvSqJ6JLY&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C4729cae5b24f4702d8c708d97d7cd51c%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637678797620646323%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=di4EZCBIMNPObUoC4XFW9YssqfsO5LQkekjxIc5tT5A%3D&reserved=0> 

Join the Telegram group for updates: https://t.me/joinchat/WZVW_IQ0h6YzYzVl <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Ft.me%2Fjoinchat%2FWZVW_IQ0h6YzYzVl&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7C4729cae5b24f4702d8c708d97d7cd51c%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637678797620656318%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=AVwZIY5rEVXRkp%2BQfW5sZUA4V5AG7LvKCZUbsw3P%2FHA%3D&reserved=0> 

 

 

Sign-ups close on 20 September 2021!

Due to safe distancing measures, each intro session is limited to only 7 sign-ups. 

Don't miss this opportunity and indicate your interest early! 😄

 

 

Our weekly practice days and timings

Mondays 7.30pm - 9.30pm (CO sectionals / combined rehearsals)

Tuesdays 7.30pm – 9.30pm (percussion sectionals)

 

 

Drop @lowryan or @kewennnnn a DM on Telegram if you have any other enquiries.

Thank you, and we hope to see you there!

 

 

Warmest Regards,



SUTD Chinese Orchestra (SUTDCO)

Subject: EV Club Introductory Session TODAY
Body:
Hey everyone!

Reminder that EV Club's Introductory Session is going to be happening today from 6pm to 8pm. Join us on Microsoft Teams to learn more about the exciting projects that we are working on and what you can expect from becoming an EV Club Member.

Subject: Re: Makerspace Club SUTD Introductory Session 2021
Body:
🛠️🛠️✨Hello Freshies and SUTDents!✨🛠️🛠




Unfortunately, due to the current COVID situation, we have decided to cancel the first session. Instead, we will be live streaming our intro session (workshop not included) during our second session that will be held physically in campus.




While sign-ups for the second session are now closed, you can still sign up for the virtual introduction session here <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.office.com%2Fr%2Fq2c05FxHpN&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7Cebd35fe885ec4db90d7608d97d25b216%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637678423705948914%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=vwBg314Lzvztsk2ydJeEI6yFlNTlwzNCm1Q%2BJNb6bF8%3D&reserved=0> !

Do note that only those that have signed up for the second session will be allowed to join us for our physical stationery holder workshop on 29/9. However, fret not as we will be reaching out and giving the materials to those that have signed up for the first session so that you can build it during your own time.




You may check whether you have successfully reserved a slot for the upcoming physical stationery case workshop on 29/9 here <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fdocs.google.com%2Fspreadsheets%2Fd%2F1xAJR-19i9Ys_MnLaDyVqJX2W7W9RkGWplxoI76dF3bc%2Fedit%3Fusp%3Dsharing&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7Cebd35fe885ec4db90d7608d97d25b216%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637678423705948914%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=xuM8ygy5YPWhW66x3Z5rdXDwCkP%2BG%2BevcDWPdue5rlo%3D&reserved=0> ! We will be reaching out to you to confirm your attendance.










Timing details:

*	Physical Workshop + Intro 
	29/9, Week 3, 3:30 - 4:30pm 
	Think Tank 26
*	Online Intro Session 
	29/9 Week 3, 4:00 - 4:30pm 
	Zoom (Livestreamed from TT26)

Also, we apologise for the last-minute changes and hope to see you there! Should you have any questions, you may reach out to @bryanstelegram (Makerspace President).

 

See you there!

Makerspace Club SUTD

From: Student Club - Makerspace
Sent: Monday, 13 September 2021 12:46 pm
Subject: Makerspace Club SUTD Introductory Session 2021 
 

🛠️🛠️✨Hello Freshies and SUTDents!✨🛠️🛠️





Looking for a place to participate in cool projects both software and hardware? Interested in being part of a maker community?




Then SUTD's Makerspace Club is here for you! Bring your tinkering dreams come to life as here in Makerspace we make anything and everything. No matter how big or small, be it hardware, software or crafts, Makerspace provides it.




We will be holding our Introductory Session this coming DiscoverSUTD 2021 and would like to invite anyone interested in maker culture to come and sign up! Create your very own personalised stationery holder and learn more about Makerspace and the future projects we have in store for you!




More importantly, we are also looking forward to brainstorming about ideas that YOU have for projects that we can work on future!
















Details 

Week 2, 24th Sept (4:25pm - 5:30pm) 
Week 3, 29th Sept (3:25pm - 4:30pm) 
Venue: Think Tank 26







Sign up here for Makerspace’s Freshmore Introductory Session:

<https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.office.com%2Fr%2F5fg8iwePEP&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7Cebd35fe885ec4db90d7608d97d25b216%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637678423705969162%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=jTwyewB12gYq%2B1VMK2irLAUwf9O%2FGKtSS8RNLOll98c%3D&reserved=0> https://forms.office.com/r/5fg8iwePEP <https://apc01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.office.com%2Fr%2F5fg8iwePEP&data=04%7C01%7Caxel_liew%40mymail.sutd.edu.sg%7Cebd35fe885ec4db90d7608d97d25b216%7C3476b776e9904f72b95062489831623d%7C0%7C0%7C637678423705978898%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=vZWOBrTxMcXulmQR1%2FvKsqfL4t%2FC4s80To%2Fdil0Syqs%3D&reserved=0>

Subject: Graduating senior made a life changing decision by Joining FUNKtion - FUNKy News Issue 3
Body:
Hi!

About 3 months ago, a graduating term 8 senior decided that he wanted to join FUNKtion in his last 2 months of University. 🤯
WHAT MADE HIM MAKE THIS DECISION? 🤔

Subject: (Invitation) Webinar: Blockchain and its potential in SEA by The Young SEAkers (TYS) - 25 Sep 2021
Body:
<https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZcudu2hrjopHdwUaEgMq06yDHqx8rWCjd04>  

Dear SUTD Students,

We would like to share with you an invitation from The Young SEAkers (TYS) about their upcoming webinar on the topic of blockchain and its potential in Southeast Asia on 25 Sep 2021, 8pm – 9pm.

The growing blockchain market in Southeast Asia is vital for development in the region. Blockchain technology has far-reaching applications across many industries, from cross border payments, identity management and smart contracts.

Join TYS in their 26th SEAkers Connect webinar to explore this exciting sector in Southeast Asia! Hear from their panel of speakers:

*	Samuel Lee, Business Development and Sales Director, Matrixport, Asia’s fastest growing one-stop digital asset financial services platform.

*	Elias Tan, Singapore Leader, Neo Smart Economy, an open-source platform that utilizes blockchain technology and digital identities to digitize and automate the management of assets using smart contracts.

Keen to learn more about:
UNDERSTANDING what blockchain means for you
Getting a GLIMPSE into what a job in the sector entails
What are some of the future DEVELOPMENTS happening in the sector.

For registration, click on the image above or refer to this link as follow: https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZcudu2hrjopHdwUaEgMq06yDHqx8rWCjd04


Best Regards,

Office of International Relations 
Singapore University of Technology and Design (SUTD)

Subject: SMT Newsletter Issue 2
Body:
Dear SUTD Community,

 

Proudly present you the Second Issue of SMT Newsletter, covering SMT new course – Science for a Sustainable World, research highlight, a fun interview with the recipients of Excellent in Team Teaching and a story shared by our Freshmore student. 

 

In this issue, we chat with Associate Professor Dario Poletti - Associate Head of SMT Cluster for Graduate Programme and Research & the Programme Director for the SUTD-SHARP. Find out which superhero power would he have and new skill he learns during the pandemic. 

 

Enjoy reading :)

 

Best Regards,

SMT Newsletter Editorial Team

'Introduction to Test-Driven Development (TDD)' Workshop
Participants would be able to explore the TDD process through specially curated hands-on activities in this workshop. Learn to write test-driven code, do TDD effectively and improve code quality through refactoring. 

At the end of the workshop, we would receive applications for Software Developer role and Software Developer internship. 

25 Sep 2021 | 1000hrs | Virtual Platform 

 <https://www.meetup.com/Titansoft-Meetup/events/280333427/>

#DevelopHER
Twitter is hosting #DevelopHER Singapore, a program curated for female-identifying second-year computer science students to explore career opportunities at Twitter.

#DevelopHER is a two-day virtual event on 7 & 8 October 2021. Participants will be divided into small groups to work on coding challenges, and attend technical workshops and mentorship sessions with our engineers.

 <https://join.smartrecruiters.com/Twitter2/580868c3-03f3-479a-a245-2699ef0f8d8e-developher-2021-singapore>  
Female Juniors & Seniors 
from CSD & ESD








	
Career Tips & Advice	

 

7 Tips for a Successful Career Change
A career change is a serious step that requires a lot of effort. And the more drastic the change, the more daunting it can be. However, with the right preparation (and determination), a career shift won’t just be a leap of faith.  Read more <https://access.vault.com/recordurl?nid=268617&wid=274402&vid=1> 


Click HERE  <http://access.vault.com/career-insider-login.aspx?aid=274402>  for full access and more career resources on Vault.com.
The service is free of charge for SUTD students and Alumni.
6 Great Questions to Ask Your Interviewer
In interviews, hiring managers and recruiters will inevitably ask, “So, do you have any questions for me?” And when they do, you better have at least a few questions prepared to ask. As for which questions you should ask, below are six great ones, all of which will show that you’ve prepared for your interview and are very interested in the job you’re interviewing for. Read more <https://access.vault.com/recordurl?nid=267036&wid=274402&vid=1>
